The study is designed to collect information about factors influencing a child's social, emotional and behavioural development and to monitor the impact of these factors on the child's development over time.

Title: Canadian Population Census
Dataset Title (French): Recensement de la population
Summary:
Statistics Canada conducts the Census of Population in order to develop a statistical portrait of Canada and Canadians on one specific day. The census is designed to provide information about people and housing units in Canada by their demographic, social and economic characteristics. You can read a brief history of the Census on the Canadian encyclopedia.

Please note that additional documentation is available for this survey. Please contact your RDC analyst to request this documentation.

The Sex and Gender Diversity Module for the Census of Population (2021) dataset is a separate data module for the Census of Population (2021) main file that contains the variables: sex, three-category gender, transgender, and gender diversity status of persons, couples (married and common-law unions) and one-parent families. Access to this module is granted separately from the main census long-form data. Please contact your analyst for more information.

Title: Survey of Labour and Income Dynamics
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te sur la dynamique du travail et du revenu
Summary: At the heart of the survey's objectives is the understanding of the economic well-being of Canadians: what economic shifts do individuals and families live through, and how does it vary with changes in their paid work, family make-up, receipt of government transfers or other factors? Starting with the 2012 reference year, annual individual and family income data is produced by the Canadian Income Survey (CIS). The CIS is a new cross-sectional survey developed to provide information on the income and income sources of Canadians, along with their individual and household characteristics. The CIS reports on many of the same statistics as the Survey of Labour and Income Dynamics (SLID), which last reported on income for the 2011 reference year. Prior to SLID, income data came from the Survey of Consumer Finances (SCF).
Summary French: Au coeur des objectifs vis√©s par l'enqu√™te, on trouve le d√©sir de comprendre le bien-√™tre √©conomique des Canadiens : √† travers quels changements √©conomiques doivent passer les personnes et les familles, et quel r√¥le jouent √† cet √©gard les changements touchant le travail r√©mun√©r√©, la composition de la famille, la r√©ception de paiements de transfert gouvernementaux, ou d'autres facteurs? Depuis l‚Äôann√©e de r√©f√©rence 2012, des donn√©es annuelles sur le revenu des particuliers et des familles sont produites par l‚ÄôEnqu√™te canadienne sur le revenu (ECR). L‚ÄôECR est une nouvelle enqu√™te transversale visant √† fournir des renseignements sur le revenu et les sources de revenu des Canadiens, de m√™me que sur leurs caract√©ristiques personnelles et celles de leur m√©nage. L‚ÄôECR produit, dans une large mesure, les m√™mes statistiques que l‚ÄôEnqu√™te sur la dynamique du travail et du revenu (EDTR), dont les derni√®res donn√©es sur le revenu portaient sur l‚Äôann√©e de r√©f√©rence 2011. Avant l‚Äôav√®nement de l‚ÄôEDTR, les donn√©es sur le revenu provenaient de l‚ÄôEnqu√™te sur les finances des consommateurs (EFC).
Subjects: Population and demography>Census counts>Families, households and marital status>Families|Families, households and marital status|Income, pensions, spending and wealth>Household, family and personal income|Labour|Income, pensions, spending and wealth>Low income and inequality
Content:
At the heart of the survey's objectives is the understanding of the economic well-being of Canadians: what economic shifts do individuals and families live through, and how does it vary with changes in their paid work, family make-up, receipt of government transfers or other factors?

Starting with the 2012 reference year, annual individual and family income data is produced by the Canadian Income Survey (CIS). The CIS is a new cross-sectional survey developed to provide information on the income and income sources of Canadians, along with their individual and household characteristics.

The CIS reports on many of the same statistics as the Survey of Labour and Income Dynamics (SLID), which last reported on income for the 2011 reference year. Prior to SLID, income data came from the Survey of Consumer Finances (SCF).

Title: National Population Health Survey
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te nationale sur la sant√© de la population
Summary: The NPHS collects information related to the health of the Canadian population and related socio-demographic information. It is composed of three components: the Households, the Health Institutions, and the North components. The Household component started in 1994/1995 and is conducted every two years. The first three cycles (1994/1995, 1996/1997 and 1998/1999) were both cross- sectional and longitudinal. Beginning in Cycle 4 (2000/2001) the survey became strictly longitudinal (collecting health information from the same individuals each cycle).
Summary French: L'ENSP recueille des renseignements sur la sant√© de la population canadienne ainsi que des renseignements sociod√©mographiques connexes. Elle compte trois volets : le volet m√©nages, le volet √©tablissements de soins de sant√© et le volet Nord. rnrnLe volet m√©nages a d√©but√© en 1994-1995 et est men√© tous les deux ans. Les trois premiers cycles (1994-1995, 1996-1997, 1998-1999) √©taient √† la fois transversaux et longitudinaux. √Ä compter du cycle 4 (2000-2001), l'enqu√™te est devenue strictement longitudinale (c'est-√†-dire que l'information sur la sant√© est recueillie aupr√®s des m√™mes personnes pour chaque cycle). La documentation transversale et longitudinale du volet m√©nages est pr√©sent√©e s√©par√©ment, de m√™me que la documentation des volets √©tablissements de soins de sant√© et Nord.

Content: The NPHS collects information related to the health of the Canadian population and related socio-demographic information. It is composed of three components: the Households, the Health Institutions, and the North components. The Household component started in 1994/1995 and is conducted every two years. The first three cycles (1994/1995, 1996/1997 and 1998/1999) were both cross- sectional and longitudinal. Beginning in Cycle 4 (2000/2001) the survey became strictly longitudinal (collecting health information from the same individuals each cycle).

Title: National Graduates Survey
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te nationale aupr√®s des dipl√¥m√©s
Summary:
This survey was designed to determine such factors as: the extent to which graduates of postsecondary programs had been successful in obtaining employment since graduation; the relationship between the graduates' programs of study and the employment subsequently obtained; the graduates' job and career satisfaction; the rates of under-employment and unemployment; the type of employment obtained related to career expectations and qualification requirements; and the influence of postsecondary education on occupational achievement.

The National Graduates Survey (NGS) Class of 2020 master and income analytical files are now available in Research Data Centers. In the master file, data collected in 2023 cover the education and labour market experiences of students who graduated from a Canadian public postsecondary institution in 2020. The income analytical file for postsecondary graduates in the Class of 2020 is derived from administrative income files.

These two data files are part of the Education and Labour Market Longitudinal Platform (ELMLP). Note that since the NGS sample was selected from the Postsecondary Student Information System (PSIS) for the academic years 2019-2020 and 2020-2021, the ‚ÄúRegister group ID‚Äù and ‚ÄúCohort group ID‚Äù have been integrated directly into the NGS master and income analytical files (as REGISTID and COHORTID, respectively). They are unique person level IDs which can be used to link NGS data with other administrative and survey data within an ELMLP.

Please note that additional documentation is available for this survey. Please contact your RDC analyst to request this documentation.
Summary French:
Cette enqu√™te vise √† d√©terminer dans quelle mesure les personnes ayant obtenu leur dipl√¥me d'√©tudes postsecondaires ont r√©ussi √† se trouver un emploi par la suite, le lien entre le programme d'√©tudes du dipl√¥m√© et son emploi subs√©quent, la satisfaction des dipl√¥m√©s √† l'√©gard de leur emploi et de leurs perspectives de carri√®re, les taux de sous-emploi et de ch√¥mage, le type d'emploi obtenu par rapport aux possibilit√©s de carri√®re et aux qualifications exig√©es, et l'incidence des √©tudes postsecondaires sur la r√©ussite professionnelle. Chaque promotion est interrog√©e deux fois : deux ans apr√®s l'obtention du dipl√¥me (Enqu√™te nationale aupr√®s des dipl√¥m√©s) et cinq ans apr√®s l'obtention du dipl√¥me (Enqu√™te de suivi aupr√®s des dipl√¥m√©s).

Le fichier principal et le fichier analytique sur le revenu de l'Enqu√™te nationale aupr√®s des dipl√¥m√©s de la promotion 2020 sont maintenant disponibles dans les Centres de donn√©es de recherche. Les donn√©es recueillis en 2023 dans le fichier principal portent sur les √©tudes et les exp√©riences sur le march√© du travail des √©tudiants qui ont obtenu un dipl√¥me d'un √©tablissement d'enseignement postsecondaire public au Canada en 2020. Le fichier analytique des revenus des dipl√¥m√©s postsecondaires de la promotion 2020 provient des donn√©es des fichiers administratifs des revenus.

Ces deux fichiers font d'ailleurs partie de la Plateforme longitudinale entre l'√©ducation et le march√© du travail (PLEMT). √Ä noter que l‚ÄôEND est un sous-ensemble du Syst√®me d‚Äôinformation sur les √©tudiants postsecondaires (SIEP) des ann√©es acad√©miques 2019-2020 et 2020-2021, le ¬´ Register group_ID ¬ª et le ¬´ Cohort group_ID ¬ª ont √©t√© int√©gr√©s directement dans les fichiers principal et analytique sur le revenu de l‚ÄôEND (en tant que REGISTID et COHORTID, respectivement). Il s'agit d'un identifiant unique au niveau de la personne qui peut √™tre utilis√© pour relier les donn√©es de l'END √† d'autres donn√©es administratives et d'enqu√™te pr√©sentes dans PLEMT.

Title: Indigenous Peoples Survey
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te aupr√®s des peuples autochtones
Summary:
The purpose of the Indigenous Peoples Survey (IPS) (formerly the Aboriginal Peoples Survey (APS) before 2022) is to provide data on the social and economic conditions of Aboriginal people in Canada. More specifically, its purpose is to identify the needs of Aboriginal people and focus on issues such as education, employment, health, language, income, housing and mobility.

The 2022 Indigenous Peoples Survey (IPS) Sex and Gender Diversity module contains the variables sex at birth, three-category gender, and sexual orientation. Crossings with these sensitive variables can allow for the identification of transgender or non-binary persons. As the population falling under the category ‚Äòtransgender‚Äô or ‚Äònon-binary‚Äô is very small, care needs to be taken to ensure the confidentiality of individuals within these categories.

Please note that additional documentation is available for this survey. Please contact your RDC analyst to request this documentation.

Le module sur le sexe et la diversit√© des genres de L‚ÄôEnqu√™te aupr√®s des peuples autochtones (EAPA) 2022 contient les variables sexe √† la naissance, genre √† trois cat√©gories et orientation sexuelle. Les croisements avec ces variables sensibles peuvent permettre d‚Äôidentifier les personnes transgenres ou non binaires. √âtant donn√© que la population appartenant √† la cat√©gorie ¬´ transgenre ¬ª ou ¬´ non binaire ¬ª est tr√®s petite, il faut faire preuve d‚Äôextr√™me prudence pour assurer la confidentialit√© des renseignements des personnes qui en font partie.

Title: Workplace and Employee Survey
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te sur le milieu de travail et les employ√©s
Summary:
The Workplace and Employee Survey (WES) is designed to explore a broad range of issues relating to employers and their employees. The survey aims to shed light on the relationships among competitiveness, innovation, technology use and human resource management on the employer side and technology use, training, job stability and earnings on the employee side. The survey is unique in that employers and employees are linked at the micro data level; employees are selected from within sampled workplaces. Thus, information from both the supply and demand sides of the labour market is available to enrich studies on either side of the market.

To create the best conditions for growth in the knowledge-based economy, governments need to fine-tune their policies on education, training, innovation, labour adjustment, workplace practices, industrial relations and industry development. The results from the survey will help clarify many of these issues and will assist in policy development.

The Workplace and Employee Survey offers potential users several unique innovations: chief among these is the link between events occurring in workplaces and the outcomes for workers. In addition, being longitudinal, it allows for a clearer understanding of changes over time.
Summary French:
L'Enqu√™te sur le milieu de travail et les employ√©s (EMTE) est con√ßue pour explorer un large √©ventail de questions reli√©es aux employeurs et √† leurs employ√©s. Du c√¥t√© de l'employeur, l'enqu√™te vise √† mettre en lumi√®re les relations entre la comp√©titivit√©, les innovations, l'utilisation de la technologie et la gestion des ressources humaines et, du c√¥t√© de l'employ√©, l'utilisation de la technologie, la formation, la stabilit√© d'emploi et les revenus. L'enqu√™te est unique en ce sens que les employeurs et les employ√©s sont li√©s au niveau des micro-donn√©es; les employ√©s sont s√©lectionn√©s dans les milieux de travail √©chantillonn√©s. On dispose donc d'information provenant tant du c√¥t√© de l'offre que de celui de la demande du march√© du travail pour enrichir des √©tudes sur l'un ou l'autre c√¥t√© du march√©. Il y a plus de 100 projets de recherche en cours ou compl√©t√©s qui utilisent l'EMTE.

Afin de mettre en place les conditions optimales √† la croissance de l'√©conomie ax√©e sur la connaissance, les gouvernements doivent remanier les politiques en mati√®re d'√©ducation, de formation, d'innovation, de r√©am√©nagement des effectifs, de pratiques en milieu de travail, de relations industrielles et de d√©veloppement industriel. Les r√©sultats de l'EMTE aideront √† clarifier bon nombre de ces questions, ce qui facilitera l'√©tablissement de politiques.

L'EMTE permet aux utilisateurs potentiels plusieurs innovations uniques dont la plus importante est le lien entre les √©v√®nements qui ont lieux dans un milieu de travail et les r√©sultats pour les employ√©s. Aussi, l'aspect longitudinal de l'enqu√™te permettra une meilleure compr√©hension des changements dans le temps.
Subjects: Education, training and learning>Adult learning|Education, training and learning>Educational attainment and qualifications|Labour>Hours of work and work arrangements|Labour>Earnings, wages and non-wage benefits>Non-wage benefits|Labour>Workplace organization, innovation and performance
Content: The overall goal of the survey is to examine the way in which employers and their employees respond to the changing competitive and technological environment.

Title: Survey of Household Spending
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te sur les d√©penses des m√©nages
Summary: The main purpose of the survey is to obtain detailed information about household spending as well as limited information on dwelling characteristics and household equipment. A series of pooled microdata files are also available. Each combine 4 years of SHS data into one cross-section: 2010-2013, 2012-2015 and 2014-2017. The files contain household-level data from the 10 provinces only. The advantage of using data pooled from multiple years is the larger sample size which generally reduces the variance associated with an estimate. This may enable data users to produce quality estimates for detailed expenditure categories and/or population groups that would not have been possible with only one year of SHS data. Certain adjustments were made to the data in these files so that the 4 pooled years can be used as one cross-section: For each set of pooled years, survey weights have been recalibrated so that the records in all four years combined are representative of the survey‚Äôs target population in the 10 provinces in the most recent year pooled. For example, the weights in the 2014-2017 files were recalibrated to represent the 2017 population. Income and expenditures have been adjusted so that they represent the values in the most recent year of the pooled data. For example, for the pooled 2014-2017 files, values from the 2014 to 2016 surveys have been converted to constant 2017 dollars. Adjustments were made to certain variables to account for differences in concepts or measurement between the 4 years pooled.
Summary French: Le but principal de l'enqu√™te est d'obtenir des renseignements d√©taill√©s sur les d√©penses des m√©nages ainsi que de l'information limit√©e sur les caract√©ristiques du logement et l'√©quipement m√©nager.Trois ensembles de fichiers de donn√©es sont disponibles, chacun combinant 4 ann√©es de donn√©es de l‚ÄôEDM pour former un seul √©chantillon transversal : 2010 √† 2013, 2012 √† 2015, et 2014 √† 2017. Les fichiers contiennent des donn√©es au niveau du m√©nage pour les 10 provinces seulement. L‚Äôavantage d‚Äôutiliser des donn√©es regroup√©es sur plusieurs ann√©es est la taille plus grande de l‚Äô√©chantillon, qui r√©duit g√©n√©ralement la variance associ√©e √† une estimation. Cela pourrait permettre aux utilisateurs de ces donn√©es de produire des estimations de qualit√© pour des cat√©gories de d√©penses ou des groupes de population d√©taill√©s, ce qui n‚Äôaurait pas √©t√© possible avec une seule ann√©e de donn√©es de l‚ÄôEDM. Certains ajustements ont √©t√© apport√©s aux donn√©es dans ces fichiers afin que les 4 ann√©es regroup√©es puissent √™tre utilis√©es comme un √©chantillon transversal : Pour chaque ensemble d‚Äôann√©es regroup√©es, les poids de sondage ont √©t√© recal√©s pour √™tre repr√©sentatifs de la population cible de l‚Äôenqu√™te dans les 10 provinces √† l‚Äôann√©e la plus r√©cente de donn√©es regroup√©es. Par exemple, les poids dans les fichiers pour l‚Äôensemble de 2014 √† 2017 ont √©t√© recal√©s pour √™tre repr√©sentatifs de la population en 2017.Les revenus et les d√©penses ont √©t√© ajust√©s afin qu‚Äôils repr√©sentent les valeurs de l‚Äôann√©e la plus r√©cente des donn√©es regroup√©es. Par exemple, pour les fichiers regroup√©s de 2014 √† 2017, les valeurs provenant des enqu√™tes de 2014 √† 2016 ont √©t√© converties en dollars constants de 2017.Des ajustements ont √©t√© apport√©s √† certaines variables pour tenir compte des diff√©rences de concepts ou de mesure entre les 4 ann√©es regroup√©es.
Subjects: Population and demography>Census counts>Families, households and marital status>Families|Families, households and marital status|Children and youth>Health of children and youth|Income, pensions, spending and wealth|Children and youth>Other content related to Children and youth
Content: The main purpose of the survey is to obtain detailed information about household spending as well as limited information on dwelling characteristics and household equipment. A series of pooled microdata files are also available. Each combine 4 years of SHS data into one cross-section: 2010-2013, 2012-2015 and 2014-2017. The files contain household-level data from the 10 provinces only. The advantage of using data pooled from multiple years is the larger sample size which generally reduces the variance associated with an estimate. This may enable data users to produce quality estimates for detailed expenditure categories and/or population groups that would not have been possible with only one year of SHS data. Certain adjustments were made to the data in these files so that the 4 pooled years can be used as one cross-section: For each set of pooled years, survey weights have been recalibrated so that the records in all four years combined are representative of the survey‚Äôs target population in the 10 provinces in the most recent year pooled. For example, the weights in the 2014-2017 files were recalibrated to represent the 2017 population. Income and expenditures have been adjusted so that they represent the values in the most recent year of the pooled data. The Longitudinal Administrative Databank (LAD) is a longitudinal file designed as a research tool on income and demographics. It comprises a 20% sample of the annual T1 Family File (record number 4105) and the Longitudinal Immigration Data Base (record number 5057). Variables have been harmonized where possible and individuals can be linked year to year starting with 1982 data. The file is augmented annually with new data. The longitudinal file contains many annual demographic variables about the individuals represented and annual income information for both the individual and their census family in that year. For immigrants landed between 1980 and 2014, the file also contains certain key characteristics observed at landing. The longitudinal nature of the LAD permits custom-tailored research into dynamic phenomena, as well as representative cross-sectional patterns. Data are mainly used by government departments to evaluate programs and support policy recommendations. Academics, private consultants and Statistics Canada researchers also use the data for analyses of socio-economic conditions.

A supplementary list of firm-level variables is linkable to the LAD to facilitate an understanding of the labour market connection for individuals in the LAD. These variables are drawn from the Canadian Employer-Employee Dynamic Database. A linkage key is also available to join the landing records from the IMDB to to the LAD.

Title: Uniform Crime Reporting Survey
Dataset Title (French): Programme de d√©claration uniforme de la criminalit√©
Summary:
The Uniform Crime Reporting Survey was designed to measure the incidence of crime in Canadian society and its characteristics. The information is used by federal and provincial policy makers as well as public and private researchers.

It is important to note that there have been a few notable changes since the UCR data were last available on the repository:
  • Effective January 2018, new standards for reporting incidents by clearance status were established for the UCR Survey and disseminated to all police service respondents, with most police services updating their information systems throughout 2018. The 2019 data are the first year of complete data that follows the new reporting standards. This shift in reporting methodology has been documented in technical publications released by Statistics Canada on July 12, 2018.
  • The collection of gender information has been expanded to include gender diverse information; however, researchers are asked to pay close attention to the vetting requirements.
  • The Canadian Forces Military Police (CFMP) became an active respondent to the UCR survey in 2022 and are required to provide the same information provided by other police services. They have provided incidents going back to January 2020.

Il est important de noter que quelques changements notables ont √©t√© apport√©s depuis la derni√®re fois o√π les donn√©es du Programme DUC √©taient disponibles :

Les donn√©es de 2019 sont la premi√®re ann√©e o√π les donn√©es compl√®tes suivent les nouvelles normes de d√©claration. Ce changement dans la m√©thodologie de d√©claration a √©t√© document√© dans des publications techniques publi√©es par Statistique Canada
  • La collecte de donn√©es sur le genre a √©t√© √©largie pour inclure des informations sur la diversit√© des genres; cependant, on demande aux chercheurs d‚Äôaccorder une attention particuli√®re aux exigences en mati√®re de v√©rification.
  • La Police militaire des Forces canadiennes (PGFC) est devenue un r√©pondant actif au Programme DUC en 2022 et doit fournir les m√™mes renseignements que ceux fournis par les autres services de police. Ils ont √©t√© en mesure de fournir des donn√©es sur des incidents remontant √† janvier¬†2020.

Summary:

The main objective of the GSS on Social Identity (SI) is to provide an overall picture of Canadians' identification, attachment, belonging and pride in their social and cultural environment. The key components of the survey include the following topics: social networks, civic participation and engagement, knowledge of Canadian history, appreciation of national symbols, shared values, confidence in institutions, and trust in people. In addition, the survey also covers people's possible experiences of discrimination before and during the Covid-19 pandemic.

Summary: The Health Institutions component started in 1994-1995 and has been conducted every two years. The first two cycles (1994-1995 and 1996-1997) were both cross-sectional and longitudinal. Beginning in Cycle 3 (1998-1999) the survey became strictly longitudinal (i.e. collecting information from the same individuals each cycle). After five cycles of collection, the institutions component has ended. The NPHS Health Institutions component data are primarily used to study prevalence and incidence of disease, to make projections and perform demographic trend analyses. The data are used by the research community and other health professionals.

Title: Longitudinal and International Study of Adults
Dataset Title (French): √âtude longitudinale et internationale des adultes
Summary: The Longitudinal and International Study of Adults collects information from people across Canada about their jobs, education, health and family. The study is also interested in how changes in these areas have affected people's lives. This survey aims to help improve education, employment, training and social services in Canada. Statistics Canada has introduced administrative data for LISA family members. For each LISA respondent with valid T1 Family File (T1FF) administrative data, any family member ever identified in the T1FF is historically flagged. Each family member is then linked to their own historical T1FF administrative data. With this wide breadth of information for LISA family members, past and present, data users can now examine historical intergenerational connections and the course of factors that may influence whole families, as well as individuals, over time.

Title: Canadian Survey on Disability
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te canadienne sur l'incapacit√©
Summary:
The purpose of the Canadian Survey on Disability (CSD) is to provide information about Canadian adults whose daily activities are limited because of a long-term condition or health-related problem. This information will be used to plan and evaluate services, programs and policies for adults with disabilities to help enable their full participation in Canadian society. Previous surveys dedicated to providing information on persons with disabilities are the Health and Activity Limitations Survey and the Participation and Activity Limitations Survey.

The 2022 Canadian Survey on Disability (CSD-R) Restricted file is a separate data module for the 2022 CSD that contains the variables: sex at birth, three-category gender, and sexual orientation. Populations identifiable in this file can be quite small and care needs to be taken to ensure that results of research will meet confidentiality guidelines.

This survey release includes non-confidential documentation. Please contact your analyst if you would like to receive a copy.

A longitudinal concordance file exists to merge the 2013, 2016, and 2019 data files . It contains a randomly generated id called LINKID and the masterid for 2013, 2016 and 2019 by record. Records on this file are respondents to the 2013 LASS and have INSCOP16 = 1, there are 3,270 records.

Title: Childhood National Immunization Coverage Survey
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te sur la couverture vaccinale nationale des enfants
Summary:
The purpose of the Childhood National Immunization Coverage Survey (CNICS) is to collect information on national immunization coverage rates for childhood vaccines. CNICS is conducted every two years. The 2021 CNICS is the second iteration of the CNICS to include pregnant women in the sample to estimate the rates of vaccines received during pregnancy. The survey is intended to: determine whether children are vaccinated in accordance with recommended immunization schedules for publicly funded vaccines; determine whether pregnant women are being vaccinated against pertussis (whooping cough) and the flu, which is recommended during pregnancy; provide the World Health Organization and the Pan American Health Organization with estimates of national vaccine coverage for childhood vaccines, such as those against measles, diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus and; polio provide information on parents‚Äô or guardians‚Äô knowledge and beliefs about vaccines.

Childhood vaccinations¬†¬†¬†
The 2021 CNICS collected information about the vaccines a child received from various sources. The first phase of collection was conducted through a self-response electronic questionnaire or a computer-assisted telephone interview (CATI) during which the person most knowledgeable about the child‚Äôs immunizations (PMK) provided information about vaccines the child had received. Parents and guardians of 2- and 14-year-old children were also asked questions regarding their knowledge and beliefs about immunization. In the second phase of collection, respondents were asked to complete and return by mail a form that provides consent for Statistics Canada to contact their child‚Äôs immunization providers to obtain their child‚Äôs vaccine history. The receipt of the consent form triggered the third phase‚Äîthe Immunization Record Request form, a mail-out mail-back questionnaire, was sent to the child‚Äôs health care providers, who filled out and returned the form with the child‚Äôs detailed immunization history. The data from the health care providers were used to enhance the PMK reported data.
The 2021 CNICS asked respondents for permission to access their child‚Äôs vaccination record held by regional, provincial and territorial immunization registries. Where available, and where permission was given, the linked data will be used to evaluate the potential to integrate immunization registry data in future cycles of the survey. To access this information, Statistics Canada must have data sharing agreements and data acquisition agreements in place with each individual jurisdiction. So far, Statistics Canada has completed an assessment of the registry coverage for Prince Edward Island and Manitoba (after having put in place data sharing and data acquisition agreements) for childhood vaccination. As a result, parents and guardians living in these two provinces were given the opportunity to skip the detailed questions about vaccination, provided they agreed to share their child‚Äôs identifiers with the respective provincial immunization registry. When consent was provided, registry immunization data were used in place of parent or immunization provider data.
The data from one or multiple sources, when available, were used to produce national immunization coverage estimates for 7-year-olds, 14-year-olds (male and female separately) and 17-year-olds, and provincial- or territorial-level results for 2-year-olds.

Vaccination during pregnancy
For the second time in its history, the CNICS surveyed women who had recently given birth to determine whether they were vaccinated against pertussis and influenza during pregnancy. Questions were then asked about the mother‚Äôs knowledge and beliefs about the vaccines received during pregnancy, and vaccination in general. Unlike the section of the CNICS that collected data on childhood vaccinations, the section about vaccines received during pregnancy did not ask for the respondent‚Äôs consent to allow Statistics Canada to contact their health care providers to obtain their immunization record. They were, however, asked for permission to access their vaccination record held by regional, provincial and territorial immunization registries. Where available, and where permission was given, the linked data will be used to evaluate the potential to integrate these immunization registry data in future cycles of the survey.
¬†¬†¬†¬† The data from the survey were used to produce national, provincial and territorial (excluding Nunavut which remains included in the national estimates) immunization coverage estimates for vaccines given during pregnancy.
Summary French:
L‚ÄôEnqu√™te nationale sur la couverture vaccinale des enfants (ENCVE) vise √† recueillir des renseignements sur les taux de couverture vaccinale √† l‚Äô√©chelle nationale concernant les vaccins administr√©s aux enfants. L‚ÄôENCVE est men√©e √† chaque 2 ans. L‚ÄôENCVE de 2021 est le deuxi√®me cycle de l‚Äôenqu√™te √† inclure les femmes enceintes dans l‚Äô√©chantillon afin d‚Äôestimer les taux de vaccination durant la grossesse. L‚Äôenqu√™te vise √†¬†: D√©terminer si les enfants sont vaccin√©s conform√©ment au calendrier de vaccination recommand√©e dans le cadre des programmes de vaccination subventionn√©e par le secteur public; D√©terminer si les femmes enceintes sont vaccin√©es contre la coqueluche et la grippe, des vaccins recommand√©s pendant la grossesse; Fournir √† l‚ÄôOrganisation mondiale de la Sant√© et √† l‚ÄôOrganisation panam√©ricaine de la sant√© des estimations de la couverture vaccinale √† l‚Äô√©chelle nationale en lien avec les vaccins administr√©s aux enfants, comme ceux administr√©s contre la rougeole, le t√©tanos, la dipht√©rie, la coqueluche et la poliomy√©lite; Fournir des renseignements sur les connaissances et les croyances des parents et des tuteurs √† l‚Äô√©gard des vaccins.

La vaccination des enfants¬†¬†¬†
L‚ÄôENCVE de 2021 a permis de recueillir des renseignements sur les vaccins re√ßus par un enfant aupr√®s de diverses sources. La premi√®re phase de collecte a √©t√© men√©e par l‚Äôentremise d‚Äôun questionnaire √©lectronique ou d‚Äôune interview t√©l√©phonique assist√©e par ordinateur (ITAO) dans le cadre duquel ou de laquelle la personne la mieux renseign√©e (PMR) sur l‚Äôimmunisation de l‚Äôenfant a r√©pondu √† des questions portant sur les vaccins re√ßus par l‚Äôenfant. Les parents et les tuteurs des enfants √¢g√©s de 2 et de 14 ans ont √©galement √©t√© interrog√©s sur leurs connaissances et leurs croyances √† l‚Äô√©gard de la vaccination. Lors de la deuxi√®me phase de la collecte, les r√©pondants ont √©t√© invit√©s √† remplir et √† retourner par la poste un formulaire de consentement qui autorise Statistique Canada √† communiquer avec les professionnels de la sant√© de leur enfant pour obtenir son historique de vaccination. La r√©ception du formulaire de consentement a d√©clench√© la troisi√®me phase, soit l‚Äôenvoi du formulaire de demande de dossier de vaccination, qui est un questionnaire envoi/retour par la poste envoy√© aux professionnels de la sant√© de l‚Äôenfant pour qu‚Äôils y inscrivent l‚Äôhistorique de vaccination d√©taill√© de l‚Äôenfant. Les donn√©es fournies par les professionnels de la sant√© servent √† am√©liorer la qualit√© des donn√©es d√©clar√©es par la PMR.
Dans le cadre de l‚ÄôENCVE de 2021, on a demand√© aux r√©pondants l‚Äôautorisation d‚Äôacc√©der aux donn√©es sur la vaccination de leur enfant qui sont contenues dans les registres de vaccination r√©gionaux, provinciaux ou territoriaux. Lorsqu‚Äôelles sont accessibles et que l‚Äôautorisation a √©t√© obtenue, les donn√©es coupl√©es serviront √† √©valuer la possibilit√© d‚Äôutiliser les donn√©es de ces registres dans les prochains cycles de l‚Äôenqu√™te. Pour acc√©der aux donn√©es des registres, Statistique Canada doit conclure des accords de partage et d‚Äôacquisition de donn√©es avec chaque secteur de comp√©tence particulier qui tient un registre de vaccination. Jusqu‚Äô√† pr√©sent, Statistique Canada a proc√©d√© √† l‚Äô√©valuation de la couverture des registres de l‚Äô√éle-du-Prince-√âdouard et du Manitoba (apr√®s avoir mis en place des accords de partage et d‚Äôacquisition de donn√©es) pour la vaccination des enfants. En cons√©quence, les parents et les tuteurs qui r√©sident dans ces deux provinces et qui ont accept√© que les identificateurs de l‚Äôenfant soient communiqu√©s √† leur registre provincial de vaccination ont pu sauter les questions d√©taill√©es sur la vaccination. Lorsque le consentement a √©t√© donn√©, les donn√©es contenues dans le registre de vaccination √©taient utilis√©es √† la place des donn√©es fournies par les parents ou les professionnels de la sant√©.
Les donn√©es de l‚Äôune ou de plusieurs sources, lorsqu‚Äôelles √©taient disponibles, ont servi √† estimer les couvertures vaccinales nationales des enfants de 7,14 (gar√ßons et filles s√©par√©ment) et 17¬†ans, et √† l‚Äô√©chelon provincial ou territorial pour les enfants de 2 ans.

Vaccination durant la grossesse
Pour la deuxi√®me fois au cours de son histoire, l‚ÄôENCVE a men√© une enqu√™te aupr√®s des femmes ayant r√©cemment accouch√© afin de d√©terminer si elles ont √©t√© vaccin√©es contre la coqueluche et la grippe pendant leur grossesse. Des questions ont ensuite √©t√© pos√©es sur les connaissances et les croyances de la m√®re concernant les vaccins administr√©s pendant la grossesse et la vaccination en g√©n√©ral. Contrairement √† la composante qui a permis de recueillir des donn√©es sur la vaccination des enfants, la section relative aux vaccins administr√©s durant la grossesse ne demandait pas le consentement des r√©pondantes pour permettre √† Statistique Canada de communiquer avec leurs professionnels de la sant√© dans le but d‚Äôobtenir leur dossier de vaccination. On leur a cependant demand√© la permission d‚Äôacc√©der √† leur dossier de vaccination d√©tenu par les registres de vaccination r√©gionaux, provinciaux et territoriaux. Lorsqu‚Äôelles sont accessibles, et lorsque la permission a √©t√© obtenue, les donn√©es coupl√©es seront utilis√©es pour √©valuer la possibilit√© d‚Äôint√©grer les donn√©es des registres de vaccination dans les prochains cycles de l‚Äôenqu√™te.
¬†¬†¬†¬† Les donn√©es de l‚Äôenqu√™te ont √©t√© utilis√©es pour produire des estimations nationales, provinciales et territoriales (excluant le Nunavut, qui demeure tout de m√™me repr√©sent√© dans l‚Äôestimation nationale) de la couverture vaccinale pour les vaccins administr√©s pendant la grossesse.
Subjects: Children and youth|Health>Prevention and detection of disease
Content: The purpose of the Childhood National Immunization Coverage Survey is to collect information on national immunization coverage for childhood vaccines. In 2019, the scope of the survey was expanded to include immunizations provided to pregnant women. Results are being published independently with data for vaccination during pregnancy being released in November 2020 and the results for childhood vaccinations scheduled for release in the spring of 2021.

Title: Ontario Ministry of Health and Long Term Care data

Summary: We are pleased to announce the availability of the historical Ontario Ministry of Health and Long Term Care (MOHLTC) data on physician claims and hospitalization. This is the first integrated dataset which has information on physicians claim information. The MOHLTC historical files provides access to a set of health care administrative datasets that covers the period between 1994/95 and 2009/10 (with some exceptions). There is no Ontario Health Insurance Plan (OHIP) data for the years between 1994/95 and 1999/00 fiscal years and the Discharge Abstract Database (DAD) Day Procedures ends in 2002/03 fiscal year and is incorporated into National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NACRS) from 2003/04 fiscal year onwards, which can be linked to responses of survey respondents from Ontario for the Canadian Community Health Survey (1.1, 2.1 and 3.1) and the National Population Health Survey 1996/97 cross-sectional datasets. The administrative records are of the whole Ontario population in those years that appear one or more of the following records: Name of the administrative records - Years covered: Ontario Health Insurance Plan (OHIP) - 1994/95, 1999/00-2009/10, Discharge Abstract Database In-Patient (DAD_IP) - 1994/95 ‚Äì 2009/10, Discharge Abstract Database Day Procedures (DAD_DP) - 1994/95 ‚Äì 2002/03, National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NARCS) - 2003/04 ‚Äì 2009/10 Currently, discussions are underway between Statistics Canada and MOHLTC to enter into a new agreement to provide access to more recent and additional MOHLTC data files. For any MOHLTC related questions please contact your local Research Data Centre.

Title: Future to Discover Project
Dataset Title (French): projet Un avenir √† d√©couvrir
Summary:
The overall objective of the Future to Discover Project is to try to understand whether better information about career choices and/or a promise of financial incentives can encourage students who might not normally decide to pursue post-secondary education (PSE), to complete high school and go on to PSE. Since the release of the public use microdata files in 2013, there were a few developments regarding the FTD pilot project:
  • Users reported that the variable of program group membership has not been included in the 2013 release of public use microdata files.
  • SRDC had received updated postsecondary education records from New Brunswick.
  • The raw data of the baseline student survey and parent survey had not been made available with the SRDC released public use microdata file in Statistics Canada‚Äôs Research Data Centre Network.
As a result, SRDC is releasing additional data files to supplement the originally released public use microdata files. All supplementary datasets can be linked to previously released public used microdata files by the unique individual identifier Sample ID (sampleid). The linkage of the Future to Discover Pilot Project (FTD Project) and the T1 Family File (T1FF) and select records from the Statement of Pension, Retirement, Annuity and Other Income (T4A SUPP) is a record linkage study funded by the Social Research and Demonstration Corporation (SRDC). The study‚Äôs purpose is to examine the impact of the FTD Project‚Äôs student interventions on enrolment in post-secondary education programs and education and labour market outcomes.

The FTD data are also linked to Education and Labour Market Longitudinal Platform (ELMLP), the Discharge Abstract Database, National Ambulatory Care Reporting System, and Canadian Vital Statistics - Death; please contact your analyst to learn how to access this linkage.

L'objectif global du projet Un avenir √† d√©couvrir (UAD) est de tenter de voir si de meilleurs renseignements sur les choix de carri√®re ou la promesse d'une aide financi√®re peuvent encourager des √©l√®ves qui, normalement, n'envisageraient peut¬≠√™tre pas de faire des √©tudes postsecondaires (EPS) √† terminer leur secondaire et √† entreprendre ensuite un programme EPS.   • La Soci√©t√© de recherche sociale appliqu√©e (SRSA) a re√ßu des dossiers mis √† jour du Nouveau-Brunswick concernant l‚Äôenseignement postsecondaire.
  • Les donn√©es brutes de l‚Äôenqu√™te de r√©f√©rence men√©e aupr√®s des parents et de celle men√©e aupr√®s des √©l√®ves n‚Äôont pas √©t√© rendues disponibles avec les fichiers de microdonn√©es √† grande diffusion diffus√©s par la SRSA dans le R√©seau des centres de donn√©es de recherche de Statistique Canada.
Par cons√©quent, la SRSA diffuse des fichiers de donn√©es suppl√©mentaires pour compl√©ter les fichiers de microdonn√©es √† grande diffusion diffus√©s initialement. Tous les ensembles de donn√©es suppl√©mentaires peuvent √™tre coupl√©s avec les fichiers de microdonn√©es √† grande diffusion diffus√©s pr√©c√©demment √† l‚Äôaide du num√©ro d‚Äô√©chantillon servant d‚Äôidentificateur individuel unique. (sampleid).Le couplage du projet pilote Un avenir √† d√©couvrir (Projet UAD) avec le fichier sur la famille T1 (FFT1) et certains enregistrements de l‚Äô√âtat du revenu de pension, de retraite, de rente ou d'autres sources (T4A SUPP) constitue une √©tude de couplage d‚Äôenregistrements financ√©e par la Soci√©t√© de recherche sociale appliqu√©e (SRSA). Cette √©tude a pour but d‚Äôexaminer l‚Äôincidence des interventions effectu√©es aupr√®s des √©l√®ves dans le cadre du Projet UAD sur l‚Äôinscription aux programmes d‚Äôenseignement postsecondaire et sur les r√©sultats en mati√®re d‚Äô√©ducation et sur le march√© du travail.

Summary: The two primary objectives of the General Social Survey (GSS) are: to gather data on social trends in order to monitor changes in the living conditions and well-being of Canadians over time; and to provide information on specific social policy issues of current or emerging interest. A specific topic is usually repeated every five years. The purpose of this survey is to collect data regarding unpaid volunteer activities, charitable giving and participation. The results will help build a better understanding of these activities which can in turn be used to help develop programs and services.

Title: Integrated Criminal Courts Survey
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te int√©gr√©e sur les tribunaux de juridiction criminelle
Summary:
The objective of the Integrated Criminal Court Survey (ICCS) is to develop and maintain a national database of statistical information on appearances, charges, and cases in youth courts and adult criminal courts. The survey is intended to be a census of pending and completed federal statute charges heard in provincial-territorial and superior courts in Canada. Appeal courts, federal courts (e.g., Tax Court of Canada) and the Supreme Court of Canada are not covered by the survey.

The survey includes information on the age and sex of the accused, case decisions, sentencing information regarding the length of prison and probation, and amount of fine, as well as case-processing and court workload indicators such as case elapsed time and case completion rates. These survey data are collected by the Canadian Centre for Justice and Community Safety Statistics (CCJCSS) in collaboration with provincial and territorial government departments responsible for criminal courts. The collection of data is from administrative records, in which data are derived from records originally kept for non-statistical purposes. The data are collected to respond to the needs of the provincial, territorial and federal departments of justice and attorneys-general, researchers and policy analysts, academics and the media, as well as to inform the public on how youths and adults appearing in provincial-territorial and superior criminal courts are dealt with in Canada.

The ICCS is an annual administrative data survey that was implemented to replace two previous micro-data surveys: the Adult Criminal Court Survey (ACCS, see legacy versions of record number 3312) and the Youth Court Survey (YCS, see record number 3309). The purpose of redevelopment was to collect new information related to the Youth Criminal Justice Act (YCJA). At the same time, it was an opportunity to integrate data collection and processing, implement a snapshot data collection strategy (collect appearances as they occurred rather than once the case was completed), and change survey definitions to more closely reflect court processing.

Where available, preliminary data are processed and published quarterly. A complete, final ICCS data file is processed and published annually.
Summary French:
L'Enqu√™te int√©gr√©e sur les tribunaux de juridiction criminelle (EITJC) vise √† cr√©er et mettre √† jour une base de donn√©es nationales dans laquelle se trouvent des renseignements statistiques sur les comparutions, les accusations et les causes devant les tribunaux de la jeunesse et les tribunaux de juridiction criminelle pour adultes. L'enqu√™te se veut un recensement des causes en instance et des causes r√©gl√©es qui sont entendues devant les cours provinciales ou territoriales et les cours sup√©rieures au Canada relativement aux infractions √† des lois f√©d√©rales. Les cours d'appel, les cours f√©d√©rales (p. ex. la Cour canadienne de l'imp√¥t) et la Cour supr√™me du Canada ne font pas partie du champ de l'enqu√™te.

L'enqu√™te fournit des renseignements sur l'√¢ge et le sexe de l'accus√©, les d√©cisions rendues, la dur√©e des peines d'emprisonnement et de probation, et le montant de l'amende, ainsi que des indicateurs sur le traitement des causes, comme le temps √©coul√© depuis l'introduction de la cause. Les donn√©es de l'enqu√™te sont recueillies par le Centre canadien de la statistique juridique et de la s√©curit√© des collectivit√©s (CCSJSC) en collaboration avec les minist√®res des gouvernements provinciaux et territoriaux responsables de l'administration des tribunaux de juridiction criminelle. Les donn√©es recueillies proviennent des dossiers administratifs, c'est-√†-dire des dossiers tenus √† l'origine √† des fins non statistiques. Les donn√©es sont recueillies afin de r√©pondre aux besoins des minist√®res provinciaux, territoriaux et f√©d√©raux de la Justice et des procureurs g√©n√©raux, des chercheurs et des analystes des politiques, des universitaires et des m√©dias, de m√™me que pour informer le public sur la fa√ßon dont les causes impliquant des jeunes et des adultes sont trait√©es devant les cours provinciales ou territoriales et les cours sup√©rieures de juridiction criminelle au Canada.

L'Enqu√™te int√©gr√©e sur les tribunaux de juridiction criminelle (EITJC) est une enqu√™te administrative qui est r√©alis√©e chaque ann√©e. Elle remplace les deux enqu√™tes pr√©c√©dentes qui √©taient fond√©es sur des microdonn√©es - l'Enqu√™te sur les tribunaux de juridiction criminelle pour adultes (ETJCA, voir les anciennes versions du num√©ro d'enregistrement 3312) et l'Enqu√™te sur les tribunaux de la jeunesse (ETJ, voir le num√©ro d'enregistrement 3309). Ce remaniement visait √† recueillir de nouveaux renseignements en lien avec la Loi sur le syst√®me de justice p√©nale pour les adolescents (LSJPA). De plus, c'√©tait une occasion d'int√©grer la collecte et le traitement des donn√©es, de mettre en oeuvre une strat√©gie de collecte des donn√©es instantan√©e (recueillir les donn√©es sur les comparutions lorsqu'elles surviennent plut√¥t que lorsque la cause est r√©gl√©e) et de modifier les d√©finitions de l'enqu√™te afin qu'elles refl√®tent mieux le traitement judiciaire.
Subjects: Children and youth|Crime and justice
Content: The Integrated Criminal Court Survey (ICCS) is an annual administrative data survey that gathers national statistical information on appearances, charges, and cases in youth courts and adult criminal courts. The survey is intended to be a census of pending and completed federal statute charges heard in provincial-territorial and superior courts in Canada. Appeal courts, federal courts (e.g., Tax Court of Canada) and the Supreme Court of Canada are not covered by the survey. The ICCS includes information on the age and sex of the accused, case decisions, sentencing information regarding the length of prison and probation terms, and the amount of fines, as well as case-processing indicators such as case elapsed time. The adult component of the survey includes persons aged 18 years or older at the time of the offence. The youth component of the survey includes persons aged 12 to 17 years old at the time of the offence.

Title: Canadian Community Health Survey - Annual Component
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te sur la sant√© dans les collectivit√©s canadiennes - Composante annuelle
Summary:
The CCHS collects information on health status, health care use and determinants of health. It relies upon a large sample of respondents and is designed to provide reliable estimates at the regional level. In 2007, changes were made to the survey design to improve its effectiveness and flexibility. Since then, data collection occurs every year rather than every two years as was the case prior to 2007. With the redesign, the option for interested parties to add a rapid response section to the CCHS became available. More information on this content is available here.

Every two years, a file combining the most recent two years is released. The two-year data file includes all respondents and the questions that were in the survey over the two year reference period. Unless otherwise specified, it is the question component from the common annual and two-year content and selected optional content over the two year period. The one-year common content and optional content selected for one year only are not available in the two-year data file.

Please note that additional documentation is available for this survey. Please contact your RDC analyst to request this documentation.

L'objectif principal de l'Enqu√™te sur la sant√© dans les collectivit√©s canadiennes (ESCC) est la collecte de donn√©es dans le domaine de la sant√©, √† des niveaux g√©ographiques intra-provinciaux (r√©gions sociosanitaires ou r√©gions sociosanitaires regroup√©es). Elle s'appuie sur un large √©chantillon de r√©pondants et est con√ßue pour fournir des estimations fiables au niveau r√©gional. En 2007, des changements ont √©t√© apport√©s √† la conception de l'enqu√™te afin d'am√©liorer son efficacit√© et sa flexibilit√©. Le fichier de deux ans inclut tous les r√©pondants ainsi que l‚Äôensemble des questions qui sont demeur√©es dans l‚Äôenqu√™te au cours de cette p√©riode. √Ä moins d‚Äôexception, il s‚Äôagit de la composante des questions du contenu commun annuel, deux ans et le contenu optionnel choisi pour deux ans. Le contenu commun un an et le contenu optionnel choisi pour une ann√©e seulement ne sont pas disponibles dans le fichier de donn√©es de deux ans.

Title: Permanent Resident Landing File - Immigration Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Summary: The Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) permanent resident landing file contains approximately 2.75 million records corresponding to all individuals who landed in Canada during the 2003 ‚Äì 2013 time frame. Title: Ontario Ministry of Children Community and Social Services - Social Assistance Data
Dataset Title (French): Donn√©es sur l‚Äôaide sociale en provenance du minist√®re des Services sociaux et communautaires de l‚ÄôOntario
Summary:
Statistics Canada and Ontario Ministry of Community, Children and Social Services (MCCSS) are pleased to announce the availability of the MCCSS/Ontario Social Assistance Data derived from the case management records of the Ontario Social Assistance programs. The Ontario‚Äôs social assistance programs provide income and employment support to single adults and families who are in financial need. There are two social assistance programs: Ontario Works (OW) provides financial and employment assistance to help people move towards paid employment and independence. Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP) provides financial assistance and employment support to enable people with disabilities and their families to live as independently as possible in their communities.
Social assistance policy directives can be accessed through the following link: http://www.mcss.gov.on.ca/en/mcss/programs/social/directives/index.aspx
The available microdata contain de-identified client-level administrative income support information for the period 2003 to 2014 (October) organized into five (5) separate files: benefit unit (family) information; member information; pay detail (benefit) information; income/deduction information; and skills information
Access to monthly time-series data on OW and ODSP provincial caseloads from 1990 to 2014 is also available consistent with the microdata.
Researchers may find the data useful in examining: disability (including financial and human impacts); effects of social assistance on demographic sub-groups (e.g. urban/rural clients, immigrants, newcomers, etc.); effective, sustainable employment outcomes and motivating people to work; social assistance caseloads and long-term attachments/dependency, including influence of policy instruments and external factors (i.e. socio-economic and labour market conditions); and inter-jurisdictional comparisons.
Linkages have been made to these casefiles. Please see the linkages available below: T1 Family File subset (1998 to 2019); T4 Statement of Remuneration (1998 to 2019); T4E Statement of Employment Insurance and Other Benefits (1998 to 2019); T5007 Statement of Benefits (1998 to 2019)
If required for approved analytical projects, subsequent linkage keys would allow mapping of the Ontario IA tax analytical file as described above to *one* other type of data source at a time among the following: Census: 2016 Census of Population Long form; Employment: Record of Employment, Employment Insurance Status Vector; Immigration: Longitudinal Immigration Database; Health: Discharge Abstract Database, National Ambulatory Care Reporting System, Canadian Cancer Registry, Ontario Mental Health Reporting System Database, Vital Statistics ‚Äì Death Database; Education: Postsecondary Student Information System, Registered Apprenticeship Information System
Summary French:
Statistique Canada et le minist√®re des Services √† l'enfance et des Services sociaux et communautaires de l‚ÄôOntario (MSESSC) ont le plaisir d‚Äôannoncer la disponibilit√© de Base de donn√©es sur l'aide sociale en Ontario - le Minist√®re des Services √† l'enfance et des Services sociaux et communautaires (MSESSC) d√©riv√©es des dossier de gestion de cas des programmes d‚Äôaide sociale de l‚ÄôOntario. Les programmes d‚Äôaide sociale de l‚ÄôOntario fournissent un soutien du revenu et de l‚Äôemploi √† des adultes c√©libataires et √† des familles qui √©prouvent des difficult√©s financi√®res. Il y a deux programmes d‚Äôaide sociale : Le programme Ontario au travail offre une aide financi√®re et une aide √† l‚Äôemploi pour permettre aux b√©n√©ficiaires d‚Äôacc√©der √† des emplois r√©mun√©r√©s et de jouir d‚Äôune plus grande autonomie ; Le Programme ontarien de soutien aux personnes handicap√©es (POSPH) offre une aide financi√®re et un soutien de l‚Äôemploi pour permettre aux personnes handicap√©es et √† leurs familles de vivre de mani√®re aussi autonome que possible dans leurs collectivit√©s.
Les microdonn√©es accessibles contiennent des renseignements administratifs sur le soutien au revenu √† l‚Äô√©chelon du client anonymis√©s pour la p√©riode de 2003 √† 2014 (octobre), s√©par√©s en cinq (5) fichiers distincts : donn√©es sur les groupes de prestataires (familles); donn√©es sur les membres; donn√©es sur les d√©tails du versement (prestations); donn√©es sur les revenus/les retenues; donn√©es sur les comp√©tences. Les donn√©es des s√©ries chronologiques mensuelles sur les volumes de cas du Programme Ontario au travail et du Programme ontarien de soutien aux personnes handicap√©es de 1990 √† 2014 correspondant aux microdonn√©es sont √©galement accessibles. Les chercheurs pourront utiliser ces donn√©es pour √©tudier l‚Äôincapacit√© (y compris les r√©percussions financi√®res et humaines) ; les effets de l‚Äôassistance sociale sur certains sous-groupes d√©mographiques (ex. clients en r√©gion urbaine ou rurale, immigrants, nouveaux arrivants, etc.); les r√©sultats efficaces et durables sur le plan de l‚Äôemploi et la stimulation des gens √† travailler; les volumes de cas associ√©s √† l‚Äôassistance sociale et la d√©pendance qui y est associ√©e √† long terme, y compris l‚Äôinfluence des instruments de politique et de facteurs externes (c.-√†-d. les conditions socio√©conomiques et du march√© du travail) ; les comparaisons d‚Äôun secteur de comp√©tence √† un autre.
Les couplages de donn√©es sont aussi disponibles: Sous-ensemble du Fichier des familles T1 (de 1998 √† 2019); Feuillet T4 √âtat de la r√©mun√©ration (de 1998 √† 2019); Feuillet T4E √âtat des prestations d‚Äôassurance-emploi et autres prestations (de 1998 √† 2019); Feuillet T5007 √âtat des prestations (de 1998 √† 2019)
Par la suite, des cl√©s de coupage, si elles sont n√©cessaires pour des projets d‚Äôanalyse approuv√©s, permettront de mettre en correspondance le fichier de donn√©es fiscales sur le soutien au revenu de l‚ÄôOntario et *un autre* type de source de donn√©es √† la fois parmi les suivants :
Recensement : Recensement de la population de 2016, questionnaire d√©taill√©; Emploi : Relev√© d‚Äôemploi, Profil vectoriel de l‚Äôassurance-emploi; Immigration : Base de donn√©es longitudinales sur l‚Äôimmigration; Sant√© : Base de donn√©es sur les cong√©s des patients, Syst√®me national d‚Äôinformation sur les soins ambulatoires, Registre canadien du cancer, Syst√®me d‚Äôinformation ontarien sur la sant√© mentale, Base canadienne de donn√©es de l‚Äô√©tat civil ‚Äî D√©c√®s; √âducation : Syst√®me d‚Äôinformation sur les √©tudiants postsecondaires, Syst√®me d‚Äôinformation sur les apprentis inscrits
Subjects: Seniors and aging>Income, pensions and wealth|Income, pensions, spending and wealth>Low income and inequality

Title: Canadian Census Health and Environment Cohort
Dataset Title (French): Cohorte sant√© et environnement du recensement canadien
Summary:
The Canadian Census Health and Environment Cohorts (CanCHECs) are population-based probabilistically linked datasets. The CanCHECs combine long-form census respondents (or National Household Survey (NHS) respondents) with administrative health data (e.g. mortality, cancer, hospitalizations, ambulatory care) and annual mailing address postal codes. These data can be used to examine health outcomes by population characteristics measured by the long-form census or NHS (e.g. income, education, occupation, language, ethnicity, immigrant status, or Indigenous identity). Environmental data can be attached to the CanCHECs using the annual postal code file in order to examine the association between environmental exposure and a health outcome. Individuals who appear in more than one CanCHEC can be identified using the CanCHEC Overlap file (this is exclusively for the purposes of removing duplicate observations and must not be used to link individuals across different waves of CanCHEC).

Please note that additional documentation is available for this dataset. Please contact your RDC analyst to request this documentation.
Summary French:

Ces donn√©es peuvent ensuite servir √† examiner les r√©sultats en mati√®re de sant√© par caract√©ristiques de la population, mesur√©s √† l'aide du questionnaire d√©taill√© du recensement ou l'ENM (p. ex. revenu, scolarit√©, profession, langue, ethnicit√©, statut d'immigrant ou identit√© autochtone). Il est possible de joindre des donn√©es environnementales aux CSERCan √† l'aide du fichier du code postal annuel, afin d'examiner l'association entre l'exposition environnementale et le r√©sultat en mati√®re de sant√©. Les personnes qui apparaissent dans plus d'un CSERCan peuvent √™tre identifi√©es √† l'aide du fichier de chevauchement CSERCan (cela sert uniquement √† √©viter les observations en double et ne peut pas √™tre utilis√© pour relier les individus entre les vagues du CSERCan).

Notez que la documentation suppl√©mentaire est disponible pour cette base de donn√©es. Veuillez contacter votre analyste du CDR pour demander cette documentation.

Title: Canadian Birth-Census Cohort
Dataset Title (French): Cohorte Canadienne de Naissance du Recensement
Summary:
The primary purpose of the Canadian Birth-Census cohorts is to add long-form Census information to births, stillbirths and infant deaths in Canada, including socio-economic information about the parents, to study the associations between these characteristics and birth and perinatal outcomes.

The cohorts are based on the intersection between in-scope births (those occurring in the two years prior to Census Day) and the Census long-form sample. A further modest reduction (about 10%) in cohort size can be attributed to missed links. The final sizes are 97 006 births for the 1996 cohort (out of a possible 466 170 in-scope births), and 135 426 births for the 2006 cohort (out of a possible 687 340 in-scope births). A cohort weight - which adjusts for the census sampling design, census non-response, and missed linkages between the birth and census databases - and 500 bootstrap weights ‚Äì to account for the variability arising from sampling, non-response, the linkage process and the stochastic variability inherent in vital events - have been generated for each of these cohorts. The 2016 CANBCC also includes a linkage with the T1 Family File (T1FF), for the 2010 to 2017 tax years.
Summary French:
L‚Äôobjectif premier des cohortes canadiennes de naissances du recensement consiste √† ajouter l‚Äôinformation du questionnaire d√©taill√© du recensement aux naissances, aux mortinaissances et aux d√©c√®s d‚Äôenfants en bas √¢ge au Canada, y compris des renseignements socio√©conomiques au sujet des parents, afin d‚Äô√©tudier les corr√©lations entre ces caract√©ristiques et les issues des grossesses et les issues p√©rinatales.

Les cohortes sont bas√©es sur l‚Äôintersection entre les naissances admissibles (celles survenues dans les deux ann√©es pr√©c√©dant le jour du recensement) et l‚Äô√©chantillon de questionnaires d√©taill√©s du recensement. De plus, une r√©duction modeste (d‚Äôenviron 10 %) de la taille de la cohorte peut √™tre attribu√©e aux appariements manqu√©s. Les tailles finales sont de 97 006 naissances pour la cohorte de 1996 (sur un total possible de 466 170 naissances admissibles), et de 135 426 naissances pour la cohorte de 2006 (sur un total possible de 687 340 naissances admissibles). Un facteur de pond√©ration de la cohorte (qui neutralise l‚Äôeffet du plan d‚Äô√©chantillonnage du recensement, de la non-r√©ponse au recensement et des appariements manqu√©s entre les bases de donn√©es sur les naissances et celles du recensement) et 500 poids bootstrap (pour tenir compte de la variabilit√© d√©coulant de l‚Äô√©chantillonnage, de la non-r√©ponse, du processus d‚Äôappariement et de la variabilit√© stochastique inh√©rente aux statistiques de l‚Äô√©tat civil) ont √©t√© g√©n√©r√©s pour chacune de ces cohortes. La CCanNR de 2016 comprend √©galement un couplage avec le Fichier des familles T1 (FFT1), pour les ann√©es d'imposition 2010 √† 2017.

Content: The primary purpose of the Canadian Birth-Census cohorts is to add long-form Census information to births, stillbirths and infant deaths in Canada, including socio-economic information about the parents, to study the associations between these characteristics and birth and perinatal outcomes. A cohort weight - which adjusts for the census sampling design, census non-response, and missed linkages between the birth and census databases - and 500 bootstrap weights ‚Äì to account for the variability arising from sampling, non-response, the linkage process and the stochastic variability inherent in vital events - have been generated for each of these cohorts.

Title: Survey of Union Membership
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te sur l'adh√©sion syndicale
Summary: The Survey of Union Membership was conducted by Statistics Canada, in co- operation with Labour Canada. In recent years there has been increased interest in the impact of labour unions on the labour market as a result of a reduction in economic growth, the rapid introduction of technological innovations in the workplace, a slowdown in the growth of unions, the increased participation of women in the workplace and growing expectations among workers regarding the quality of their working conditions and their work environment. This survey hopes to answer a number of questions, some of which are: 1) How many workers have their wages and other conditions of work determined by a collective agreement? 2) Among those employees who are covered by collective agreements, how many are actually union members? 3) Which industries and provinces are the most highly unionized? 4) Do the wages and pension plans of union members and non union workers differ significantly?
Summary French:
L'enqu√™te sur l'adh√©sion syndicale a √©t√© men√©e par Statistique Canada en collaboration avec Travail Canada. Les derni√®res ann√©es ont √©t√© marqu√©es par un fl√©chissement de la croissance √©conomique, une mise en place acc√©l√©r√©e de nouveaut√©s technologiques, un ralentissement de la syndicalisation, une augmentation de la main-d'oeuvre f√©minine et un accroissement des exigences des travailleurs vis-√†-vis de leurs conditions et de leur milieu de travail. C'est pourquoi l'influence des syndicats sur le march√© du travail suscite de plus en plus d'int√©r√™t. Afin d'√©tudier ces questions et de conna√Ætre les tendances qui se dessinent sur le march√© du travail, il fallait rassembler davantage de donn√©es pour bien faire le point sur l'adh√©sion syndicale et le r√©gime de n√©gociation collective au Canada.

Nous esp√©rons qui cette enqu√™te nous permettra de r√©pondre √† diverses questions. Par exemple: 1)Quel est le nombre de travaileurs dont le salaire et les conditions de travail sont r√©gis par une convention collective? 2) Parmi ces travailleurs, combien sont syndiqu√©s? 3) Dans quels secteurs √©conomiques et dans quelles provinces le degr√© de syndicalisation est-il le plus √©lev√©? 4) Y a-t-il une diff√©rence significative entre les travailleurs syndiqu√©s et non syndiqu√©s sur le plan des salaires et des r√©gimes de pension?
Subjects: Labour>Unionization and industrial relations
Content: The Survey of Union Membership was conducted by Statistics Canada, in co- operation with Labour Canada. In recent years there has been increased interest in the impact of labour unions on the labour market as a result of a reduction in economic growth, the rapid introduction of technological innovations in the workplace, a slowdown in the growth of unions, the increased participation of women in the workplace and growing expectations among workers regarding the quality of their working conditions and their work environment. This survey hopes to answer a number of questions, some of which are: 1) How many workers have their wages and other conditions of work determined by a collective agreement? 2) Among those employees who are covered by collective agreements, how many are actually union members? 3) Which industries and provinces are the most highly unionized? 4) Do the wages and pension plans of union members and non union workers differ significantly?

Title: Census linked to Discharge Abstract Database
Dataset Title (French): Recensement coupl√©e √† la Base de donn√©es sur les cong√©s des patients
Summary:
The 2006 Census (long-form) was linked to the DAD for 2006/07-2008/09 to support analysis of hospital use by sub-populations and socio-economic status of Canadians. The long-form Census represents approximately 20% of the Canadian population and provides comprehensive information on demography, family, household and dwelling characteristics, geography, Aboriginal identity, activity limitations, education, ethnic origin, citizenship and immigration, income, journey to work, labour market activity, language, mobility, unpaid work and visible minorities. The DAD includes all acute-care and some psychiatric, chronic, rehabilitation and day-surgery hospital discharges in Canada (excluding Quebec) provided to Statistics Canada by CIHI.

Approximately 4.652 million long-form respondents were eligible for linkage to the DAD. The linkage was conducted using a hierarchical deterministic linkage approach. Approximately 5.3% of Census respondents were linked to at least one DAD record between 2006/07 and 2008/09. The 2006 Census-DAD linked data have been used by Statistics Canada to better understand patterns of hospitalization use for key sub-populations including immigrants and Aboriginal peoples.
Summary French: Le recensement de 2006 (version longue) a ÈtÈ reliÈ ‡ la BDCP pour la pÈriode 2006/07-2008/09 afin de faciliter l'analyse de l'utilisation des hÙpitaux par sous-population et du statut socio-Èconomique des Canadiens. Le formulaire long du recensement reprÈsente environ 20 % de la population canadienne et fournit des informations complËtes sur la dÈmographie, les caractÈristiques des familles, des mÈnages et des logements, la gÈographie, l'identitÈ autochtone, les limitations d'activitÈ, l'Èducation, l'origine ethnique, la citoyennetÈ et l'immigration, le revenu, le trajet pour se rendre au travail, l'activitÈ sur le marchÈ du travail, la langue, la mobilitÈ, le travail non rÈmunÈrÈ et les minoritÈs visibles. La BDCP comprend toutes les sorties d'hÙpitaux de soins aigus et de certains hÙpitaux psychiatriques, chroniques, de rÈadaptation et de chirurgie d'un jour au Canada (‡ l'exclusion du QuÈbec), fournies ‡ Statistique Canada par l'ICIS.
Subjects: Health>Health care services
Content:

The long-form Census represents approximately 20% of the Canadian population and provides comprehensive information on demography, family, household and dwelling characteristics, geography, Aboriginal identity, activity limitations, education, ethnic origin, citizenship and immigration, income, journey to work, labour market activity, language, mobility, unpaid work and visible minorities. The DAD includes all acute-care and some psychiatric, chronic, rehabilitation and day-surgery hospital discharges in Canada (excluding Quebec) provided to Statistics Canada by CIHI.

Approximately 4.652 million long-form respondents were eligible for linkage to the DAD. The linkage was conducted using a hierarchical deterministic linkage approach. Title: Canadian Community Health Survey linked to the Canadian Vital Statistics Death Database
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te sur la sant√© dans les collectivit√©s canadiennes coupl√©e aux donn√©es sur les d√©c√®s de la Base canadienne de donn√©es sur l'√©tat civil
Summary:
As part of its record linkage program, Statistics Canada linked the Canadian Community Health Survey cycles 1.1 ‚Äì 2011, and CCHS Focus Content cycles on mental health (1.2) and healthy aging (4.2), to the Canadian Vital Statistics Death Database for years 2000 to 2011. These linked data allow for analysis of the impact of behavioural, socio-economic and environmental risk factors on mortality outcomes. For more information on the linkage of this dataset, please see Linking the Canadian Community Health Survey and the Canadian Mortality Database: An enhanced data source for the study of mortality published in Health Reports (December 2016).

Summary French:

Title: Extending the Relevance of the Longitudinal Files
Dataset Title (French): √âlargissement de la pertinence des fichiers de donn√©es longitudinales
Summary:
Longitudinal data allow researchers to be able to better understand the factors behind events or problems. Given the importance of longitudinal data in research, it was important to find a way to extend the usefulness of Statistics Canada‚Äôs longitudinal data for research purposes. The outcome files contain only the survey identifier and the specific file‚Äôs outcome variables that were approved for this linkage project. Users will need to merge the survey file with these outcome files to build a linked analysis file for their analytical purposes and instructions for merging files is provided in the user guide.
Description of Administrative Datasets: T1 Family File (1993-latest available): The T1 is the personal tax return filled out each year by Canadians. This data allows users to see the tax data for the family as opposed to ungrouped individuals. The ‚Äúfamily‚Äù is defined as a census family: the census family data include parent(s) and children (i.e., children who do not live with their spouse or partner and do not have children of their own) living in the same dwelling. The individual T1 file is combined with the T4 tax file and the Canada Child Tax Benefit (CCTB) file. More details can be found at the StatCan website.
Canadian Vital Statistics Death Database (1993-latest available): This file contains demographic and cause of death information for all decedents. Specifically, the following information is available:
  • Age, sex, marital status, place of residence and birthplace of the deceased
  • Date of death
  • Underlying cause of death classified to the " World Health Organization
  • International Statistical Classification of Disease and Related Health Problems" (ICD)
  • Province or territory of occurrence of death
  • Place of accident (for most non-transport accidental deaths)
  • Autopsy (whether one was held, and if so, whether the results of it were taken into account in establishing the cause of death)
Further information regarding the death database is available on the Statistics Canada website.
Canadian Cancer Registry (1992-latest available): The Canadian Cancer Registry contains comprehensive data on all tumours recorded in a patient over time. Diagnostic codes and basic demographic information (sex, age) are available in addition to numerous details about all recorded cancers. Full details regarding the cancer registry is available.
Details of the longitudinal survey data linked to these administrative files are accessible through the links under "available cycles".
