Title: T2-Longitudinal Employment Analysis Program
Dataset Title (French): Programme d'analyse longitudinale de l'emploi T2
Summary:
Since 2011, professional researchers have been accessing Statistics Canada‚Äôs holdings of business microdata to conduct approved research projects at its headquarters in Ottawa, through the Canadian Centre for Data Development and Economic Research program (CDER).

In March 2018, Statistics Canada launched a pilot project to help support the introduction of business microdata in the Research Data Centres (RDCs). As through CDER, researchers will work directly with synthetic business microdata before submitting their programs to Statistics Canada staff to be run on the actual microdata.  The pilot will consider only research proposals using the T2-Longitudinal Employment Analysis Program (LEAP), an enterprise-level database that contains key information on firm entry and exit, demographics, finances, and performance. The T2-LEAP has been used to study: employment and business dynamics, industry turnover, productivity growth, high-growth firms, and firm financing, survival and performance.
Summary French:
Depuis 2011, les chercheurs professionnels acc√®dent aux fonds de microdonn√©es d‚Äôentreprises de Statistique Canada afin de mener des projets de recherche approuv√©s √† son bureau central √† Ottawa, par l‚Äôentremise du programme du Centre canadien d‚Äô√©laboration de donn√©es et de recherche √©conomique (CDRE).

En mars 2018, Statistique Canada a lanc√© un projet pilote pour soutenir l‚Äôacc√®s √† ces donn√©es dans les Centres de donn√©es de recherche (CDR). Les propositions sont accept√©es, et seront √©valu√©es en continu, jusqu‚Äôau 30 avril. Comme pour le CDRE, les chercheurs travailleront directement avec des microdonn√©es d‚Äôentreprises synth√©tiques avant de soumettre leurs programmes aux employ√©s de Statistique Canada pour qu‚Äôils soient ex√©cut√©s avec les microdonn√©es comme telles.

Le projet pilote tiendra compte uniquement des propositions de recherche qui utilisent le Programme d‚Äôanalyse longitudinale de l‚Äôemploi T2 (PALET2), une base de donn√©es pr√©sent√©es au niveau de l‚Äôentreprise qui comprend des renseignements cl√©s sur l‚Äôentr√©e et la sortie des entreprises, leurs caract√©ristiques d√©mographiques, leurs finances et leur performance. Le PALET2 est utilis√© pour √©tudier la dynamique de l‚Äôemploi et des entreprises, le chiffre d‚Äôaffaires de l‚Äôindustrie, la croissance de la productivit√©, les entreprises √† forte croissance, et le financement, la survie et la performance des entreprises.
Subjects: Labour>Hours of work and work arrangements
Content:
Since 2011, professional researchers have been accessing Statistics Canada‚Äôs holdings of business microdata to conduct approved research projects at its headquarters in Ottawa, through the Canadian Centre for Data Development and Economic Research program (CDER).

In March 2018, Statistics Canada launched a pilot project to help support the introduction of business microdata in the Research Data Centres (RDCs). As through CDER, researchers will work directly with synthetic business microdata before submitting their programs to Statistics Canada staff to be run on the actual microdata.  The pilot will consider only research proposals using the T2-Longitudinal Employment Analysis Program (LEAP), an enterprise-level database that contains key information on firm entry and exit, demographics, finances, and performance. The T2-LEAP has been used to study: employment and business dynamics, industry turnover, productivity growth, high-growth firms, and firm financing, survival and performance.

Proposals should be submitted by email at: statcan.cder-cdre.statcan@canada.ca Proposals will be accepted and evaluated on an ongoing basis until April 30, 2018. 

Update April 18, 2018: 

We are pleased to inform you that the CRDCN together with the Productivity Partnership is offering funds to assist researchers in the use of the T2-LEAP syn data in the RDCs. At least two research projects will be funded (up to a maximum of $6000 each). These funds are intended to be used for research costs, including hiring a student research assistant (any level), travel, conference presentation and attendance, ungating of journal articles, and other knowledge mobilization items. Note that researchers are expected to report to the CRDCN KT Coordinator and the Productivity Partnership research coordinator any materials they produce. In addition, they are expected to acknowledge the financial contribution of the CRCDN and the Productivity Partnership in these materials.
 
Please submit your request for funding online, with the following information: Name and contact information of the lead researcher; title of project; an abstract including research questions (approx. 250 words); and budget breakdown.
Proposals will be accepted and evaluated on an ongoing basis until May 15, 2018. The results will be announced shortly after projects accepted to take part in the pilot are announced by Statistics Canada.

Title: University and College Academic Staff System
Dataset Title (French): Syst√®me d'information sur le personnel d'enseignement dans les universit√©s et les coll√®ges
Summary:
The UCASS collects data on a wide range of socioeconomic characteristics that provide a detailed portrait of full-time university academic staff in Canada. The data collected include gender, age, principal subject taught, salary and administrative stipends, province or country of degrees earned, and academic rank. The target population of this survey is full-time academic staff in public universities whose term of appointment is not less than 12 months. This includes all teaching staff within faculties who are full-time teachers, researchers and or senior academic staff, full-time academic staff in teaching hospitals, visiting academic staff in faculties, and full-time research staff who have an academic rank and salary similar to those of teaching staff. Other staff, such as administrative non-academic support staff, librarians, and teaching and research assistants, post-doctoral fellows are not included in the survey.

This mandatory survey is a census of all public universities in Canada; therefore, there is no sampling. The information is collected for each individual academic staff member employed by universities as of October 1 of the academic year.
Summary French:
Le SPEUC recueille des donn√©es sur un √©ventail de caract√©ristiques socio√©conomiques du personnel universitaire enseignant √† plein temps au Canada, qui permettent d‚Äôen dresser un portrait d√©taill√©. Ces donn√©es comprennent l‚Äô√¢ge, le sexe, la principale mati√®re enseign√©e, le salaire et les honoraires vers√©s pour des fonctions administratives, la province ou le pays dans lequel les grades universitaires ont √©t√© obtenus et le rang professoral.

La population cible du SPEUC est constitu√©e des membres du personnel enseignant √† plein temps des universit√©s publiques, dont la dur√©e du mandat est d‚Äôau moins 12 mois. Cela englobe tous les membres du personnel enseignant qui travaillent √† plein temps comme enseignants, chercheurs ou cadres administratifs sup√©rieurs, le personnel enseignant √† plein temps dans les h√¥pitaux universitaires, le personnel enseignant √† plein temps invit√© dans les facult√©s, et le personnel de recherche √† plein temps dont le rang professoral et l‚Äô√©chelle de traitement sont semblables √† ceux du personnel enseignant. Sont exclus de l‚Äôenqu√™te le personnel de soutien administratif non enseignant, les biblioth√©caires, les adjoints √† l‚Äôenseignement et √† la recherche, et les boursiers postdoctoraux.

Cette enqu√™te √† participation obligatoire consiste en un recensement de toutes les universit√©s publiques du Canada; il n‚Äôy a donc pas d‚Äô√©chantillonnage. Les renseignements seront recueillis pour chaque personne qui √©tait membre du corps professoral d‚Äôune universit√© au 1er octobre de l‚Äôann√©e universitaire.
Subjects: Children and youth>Education|Education, training and learning>Elementary and secondary education>Teachers and educators
Content:
Statistics Canada is conducting a pilot project to provide access to the University and College Academic Staff System (UCASS) data base for 1970 to 2010.  The pilot project will give researchers access to these data in a Statistics Canada Research Data Centre (RDC) and will aim to evaluate and improve confidentiality vetting rules and help to improve documentation for researchers.

UCASS

The UCASS collects data on a wide range of socioeconomic characteristics that provide a detailed portrait of full-time university academic staff in Canada. The data collected include gender, age, principal subject taught, salary and administrative stipends, province or country of degrees earned, and academic rank.

The target population of this survey is full-time academic staff in public universities whose term of appointment is not less than 12 months. This includes all teaching staff within faculties who are full-time teachers, researchers and or senior academic staff, full-time academic staff in teaching hospitals, visiting academic staff in faculties, and full-time research staff who have an academic rank and salary similar to those of teaching staff. Other staff, such as administrative non-academic support staff, librarians, and teaching and research assistants, post-doctoral fellows are not included in the survey.

This mandatory survey is a census of all public universities in Canada; therefore, there is no sampling. The information is collected for each individual academic staff member employed by universities as of October 1 of the academic year.

Title: Intergenerational Income Database
Dataset Title (French): Base de donn√©es sur la mobilit√© interg√©n√©rationnelle du revenu
Summary:
The Intergenerational Income Database (IID) is a database that links children and their parents using administrative tax data, allowing researchers and analysts to study intergenerational phenomena such as transmission of earnings from parents to children, income mobility, etc.
Since its introduction in the mid-1990s, the IID has been the main source of analytical research on intergenerational income mobility in Canada. The database has been updated several times, most recently in 2024 when a new cohorts (2006) was added to the IID sample. New cohorts are planned to be added in the future to maintain the five-year interval between the cohorts. The IID has detailed information about various income sources, including earnings, self-employment income, dividends and investment income as well as government transfers. Information about federal and provincial taxes paid by individuals is also available. A particular strength of the IID is that it allows for identifying children‚Äôs families and therefore analyzing income mobility at the family level.
Summary French:
La base de donn√©es sur la mobilit√© interg√©n√©rationnelle du revenu (BDMIR) est une base de donn√©es qui couple les enfants √† leurs parents √† partir de donn√©es fiscales administratives, permettant ainsi aux chercheurs et analystes d‚Äô√©tudier les ph√©nom√®nes interg√©n√©rationnels comme la transmission des gains des parents aux enfants, la mobilit√© du revenu, etc.
Depuis sa cr√©ation au milieu des ann√©es 1990, la BDMIR est la principale source de recherche analytique sur la mobilit√© interg√©n√©rationnelle du revenu au Canada. Cette base de donn√©es a √©t√© mise √† jour plusieurs fois; la derni√®re datant de 2024, lorsqu'une nouvelle cohorte (2006) a √©t√© ajout√©e √† l‚Äô√©chantillon de la BDMIR. Il est pr√©vu que de nouvelles cohortes soient ajout√©es √† l‚Äôavenir pour maintenir l‚Äôintervalle de cinq ans entre les cohortes. La BDMIR pr√©sente des renseignements d√©taill√©s sur diverses sources de revenus, notamment les gains, le revenu provenant d‚Äôun travail autonome, les dividendes, le revenu d‚Äôinvestissements ainsi que les transferts gouvernementaux. Des renseignements sur les imp√¥ts f√©d√©raux et provinciaux pay√©s sont √©galement disponibles. L‚Äôune des forces particuli√®res de la BDMIR est qu‚Äôelle permet de d√©terminer les familles des enfants et donc d‚Äôanalyser la mobilit√© du revenu au niveau de la famille.
Subjects: Income, pensions, spending and wealth>Personal and household taxation
Content:
The Intergenerational Income Database (IID) is a database that links children and their parents using administrative tax data, allowing researchers and analysts to study intergenerational phenomena such as transmission of earnings from parents to children, income mobility, etc. Since its introduction in the mid-1990s, the IID has been the main source of analytical research on intergenerational income mobility in Canada. The database has been updated several times, most recently in 2016 when three new cohorts (1991, 1996 and 2001) were added to the IID sample. New cohorts are planned to be added in the future to maintain the five-year interval between the cohorts. The IID has detailed information about various income sources, including earnings, self-employment income, dividends and investment income as well as government transfers. Information about federal and provincial taxes paid by individuals is also available. A particular strength of the IID is that it allows for identifying children‚Äôs families and therefore analyzing income mobility at the family level.

Title: Canadian Armed Forces Transition and Well-being Survey

Summary French: L'objectif de cette enqu√™te est d'arriver √† mieux comprendre la transition des membres des Forces arm√©es canadiennes √† la vie civile, ainsi que ses r√©percussions sur leur sant√©, et de fournir de l'information pouvant aider √† am√©liorer les programmes et les services offerts par le minist√®re de la D√©fense nationale et Anciens Combattants Canada aux membres des Forces arm√©es canadiennes en transition et √† leur famille.

Title: General Social Survey Cycle 25 linked to annual tax files TIFF 1982-2020 and Immigrant Landing File ILF 2014
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te sociale g√©n√©rale cycle 25 coupl√©e aux les fichiers fiscaux TIFF de 1982 √† 2013 et le fichier d‚Äô√âtablissement des immigrants FEI de 2014
Summary: This record linkage project brings together data from the 2011 General Social Survey (cycle 25), the annual tax files (TIFF) from 1982 to 2020, and the 2014 Immigrant Landing File (ILF). The purpose of the linkage project is to better understand and quantify the impact of family transitions experienced (i.e. union formation or dissolution, birth or adoption of a child, etc.) by Canadians on their socio-economic well-being. This project also adds socio-economic measures to extend the analytical relevance of the GSS-2011. The GSS survey compiled conjugal, parental and work histories of a large sample of respondents. It also collected several socio- economic characteristics. However, most of these can only be used on a cross- sectional basis, as they refer to 12 months preceding the survey date. These linkages of past tax data will allow researchers to document and examine associations from a longitudinal perspective.
Summary French: Le pr√©sent projet de couplage d‚Äôenregistrements r√©unit les donn√©es de l‚ÄôEnqu√™te sociale g√©n√©rale de 2011 (cycle 25), les fichiers fiscaux (TIFF) de 1982 √† 2020 ainsi que le fichier d‚Äô√âtablissement des immigrants de 2014 (FEI). Le but de ce projet de couplage est de mieux comprendre et quantifier l‚Äôincidence des diff√©rents √©v√©nements familiaux v√©cus par les Canadiens (par. ex. la formation ou la dissolution d‚Äôunion, la naissance ou l‚Äôadoption d‚Äôun enfant, etc.) sur leur bien-√™tre √©conomique.Avec ce projet, des mesures socio√©conomiques seront ajout√©es, permettant d‚Äôaccro√Ætre la pertinence analytique de l‚ÄôESG-2011. Cette enqu√™te recueillait des histoires conjugales, parentales et socio-professionnelles d‚Äôun large √©chantillon de r√©pondants. Elle recueillait aussi quelques caract√©ristiques socio√©conomiques. Toutefois, ces derni√®res ne peuvent √™tre utilis√©es que de fa√ßon transversale, puisqu‚Äôelles r√©f√®rent aux 12 mois pr√©c√©dant l‚Äôenqu√™te. Les couplages aux donn√©es fiscales ant√©rieures permettront aux chercheurs de documenter et d‚Äôexaminer les liens d‚Äôune perspective longitudinale.
Subjects: Society and community
Content: This record linkage project brings together data from the 2011 General Social Survey (cycle 25), the annual tax files (TIFF) from 1982 to 2013, and the 2014 Immigrant Landing File (ILF). The purpose of the linkage project is to better understand and quantify the impact of family transitions experienced (i.e. union formation or dissolution, birth or adoption of a child, etc.) by Canadians on their socio-economic well-being. This project also adds socio-economic measures to extend the analytical relevance of the GSS-2011. The GSS survey compiled conjugal, parental and work histories of a large sample of respondents. It also collected several socio- economic characteristics. However, most of these can only be used on a cross- sectional basis, as they refer to 12 months preceding the survey date. These linkages of past tax data will allow researchers to document and examine associations from a longitudinal perspective.

Title: Canadian Cancer Registry linked to Canadian Vital Statistics Death Database and death information from the T1 Personal Master File
Dataset Title (French): Registre canadien du cancer - Statistique de l'√©tat civil-Base de donn√©es sur les d√©c√®s - d√©c√®s du fichier ma√Ætre des particuliers T1
Summary:
The Canadian Cancer Registry (diagnosis years 1992 to 2014) linked to the Canadian Vital Statistics Death data (1992 to 2014), and death information from the T1 Personal Master File (1992 to 2014), is now accessible at Statistics Canada‚Äôs Research Data Centres (RDC) across the country. The linked file will enable broader analytical use of the Canadian Cancer Registry, by facilitating epidemiological research on cause of death and permitting the estimation of cancer survival and prevalence rates.

As part of its record linkage activities, Statistics Canada linked the patient records in the Canadian Cancer Registry to death information available in the Canadian Vital Statistics Death Database and from income tax returns (T1 Personal Master File).

The death-linked analytic file contains all CCR variables and a selection of CVSD variables. Researchers will be able to merge the linked file to the full CVSD and the multiple cause of death file available in the RDC if additional variables are required.
Summary French: Le RCC (ann√©es de diagnostic de 1992 √† 2014) coupl√© aux donn√©es de la Base de donn√©es sur les d√©c√®s de la Statistique de l‚Äô√©tat civil (1992 √† 2014), et √† l‚Äôinformation sur les d√©c√®s du fichier ma√Ætre des particuliers T1 (1992 √† 2014), est maintenant accessible dans les centres de donn√©es de recherche (CDR) de l‚Äôensemble du pays; les chercheurs n‚Äôont pas √† se rendre √† Ottawa pour acc√©der aux donn√©es.Le fichier coupl√© permettra une utilisation plus vaste du RCC √† des fins analytiques en facilitant la recherche √©pid√©miologique sur les causes de d√©c√®s et en permettant d‚Äôestimer le taux de survie √† la suite d‚Äôun cancer et le taux de pr√©valence du cancer. Dans le cadre de ses activit√©s de couplage d‚Äôenregistrements, Statistique Canada a coupl√© les enregistrements de patients se trouvant dans le RCC √† des renseignements sur les d√©c√®s accessibles dans la Base de donn√©es sur les d√©c√®s de la Statistique de l‚Äô√©tat civil et les d√©clarations de revenus (fichier ma√Ætre des particuliers T1).Le fichier analytique coupl√© aux d√©c√®s contient toutes les variables du RCC et certaines variables s√©lectionn√©es de la BCDECD. Si d‚Äôautres variables sont requises, les chercheurs pourront fusionner le fichier coupl√© √† l‚Äôensemble de la BCDECD ainsi qu‚Äôau fichier des causes multiples de d√©c√®s accessibles dans les centres de donn√©es de recherche.
Subjects: Health>Life expectancy and deaths|Population and demography
Content:
The Canadian Cancer Registry (diagnosis years 1992 to 2014) linked to the Canadian Vital Statistics Death data (1992 to 2014), and death information from the T1 Personal Master File (1992 to 2014), is now accessible at Statistics Canada‚Äôs Research Data Centres (RDC) across the country. The linked file will enable broader analytical use of the Canadian Cancer Registry, by facilitating epidemiological research on cause of death and permitting the estimation of cancer survival and prevalence rates.

As part of its record linkage activities, Statistics Canada linked the patient records in the Canadian Cancer Registry to death information available in the Canadian Vital Statistics Death Database and from income tax returns (T1 Personal Master File).

The death-linked analytic file contains all CCR variables and a selection of CVSD variables. Researchers will be able to merge the linked file to the full CVSD and the multiple cause of death file available in the RDC if additional variables are required.

Title: Longitudinal Immigration Database
Dataset Title (French): Base de donn√©es longitudinales sur l'immigration
Summary:
The Longitudinal Immigration Database (IMDB) combines linked administrative immigration and tax data files. It is a comprehensive source of data on the socio-economic outcomes of the immigrant tax filer population in Canada. The database is managed by Statistics Canada on behalf of a federal-provincial consortium led by Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC). The IMDB provides detailed and reliable information on the labour market behaviour of different categories of immigrants over a period that is long enough to assess the impact of characteristics at admission, such as education and knowledge of French or English. The database also provides information on pre-admission work or study experience in Canada, provincial mobility and family composition.

The benefits of analysis using the IMDB include:
  • Support for evidence based policy making;
  • Increase the use of administrative data sources for research, thereby reducing the cost of data collection and the burden on respondents for surveys;
  • Allow inferential statistical analysis on the confidential microdata and analytical work complex in nature or not suitable for other forms of data access.


    • Since 1980, over 2.2 million immigrants who were admitted to Canada were aged less than 18 years old at the time of admission. This represents almost 25% of immigrants admitted during that timeframe. Children will most likely receive all or part of their education in Canada and have different challenges than adult immigrants. Little information is available about immigrant children during their childhood in the Longitudinal Immigration Database (IMDB), as they are not tax filers. In order to increase the analytical capability of the IMDB a children module was produced. The ability to study the impact of the childhood socioeconomic condition on adulthood economic outcome is an added value to the IMDB.

    Please note that additional documentation is available for this survey. Please contact your RDC analyst to request this documentation.

    A supplementary list of firm-level variables is linkable to the IMDB to facilitate an understanding of the labour market connection for individuals in the database. These variables are drawn from the Canadian Employer-Employee Dynamic Database. A supplementary child-module is available and linkable to the IMDB to facilitate understanding of immigrants admitted below the age of majority.
Summary French:
La Base de donn√©es longitudinales sur l‚Äôimmigration (BDIM) rassemble des fichiers coupl√©s de donn√©es administratives sur l‚Äôimmigration et l‚Äôimp√¥t. La BDIM est une source exhaustive de donn√©es sur la situation socio√©conomique de la population des immigrants qui produisent une d√©claration de revenus au Canada. Statistique Canada g√®re cette base de donn√©es pour le compte d‚Äôun consortium f√©d√©ral-provincial dirig√© par Immigration, R√©fugi√©s et Citoyennet√© Canada (IRCC). La BDIM fournit des renseignements d√©taill√©s et fiables sur le comportement de diff√©rentes cat√©gories d‚Äôimmigrants sur le march√© du travail pendant une p√©riode suffisamment longue pour √©valuer les r√©percussions de leurs caract√©ristiques √† l‚Äôadmission, comme le niveau de scolarit√© et la connaissance du fran√ßais ou de l‚Äôanglais. La base de donn√©es fournit aussi des renseignements sur l‚Äôexp√©rience de travail ou d‚Äô√©tudes acquise au Canada avant l‚Äôadmission, sur la mobilit√© interprovinciale et sur la composition de la famille.

Les avantages du recours √† la BDIM aux fins d‚Äôanalyse comprennent :
  • un soutien √† l‚Äô√©laboration de politiques fond√©es sur des donn√©es probantes;
  • une utilisation accrue des sources de donn√©es administratives aux fins de recherche, ce qui diminue les co√ªts de collecte de donn√©es et le fardeau impos√© aux r√©pondants lors des enqu√™tes;
  • la possibilit√© d‚Äôeffectuer des analyses statistiques inf√©rentielles sur des microdonn√©es confidentielles ainsi que du travail d‚Äôanalyse dont la nature est complexe ou qui ne se pr√™te pas √† d‚Äôautres formes d‚Äôacc√®s aux donn√©es.
La d√©cision de lancer un projet pilote au centre de donn√©es de recherche (CDR) vise √† √©valuer la faisabilit√© de permettre une utilisation accrue de la BDIM. Cela permettra de soumettre les r√®gles de contr√¥le de confidentialit√© √† des tests suppl√©mentaires et d‚Äô√©valuer les ressources en technologies de l‚Äôinformation n√©cessaires au transfert et √† l‚Äôanalyse de ces volumineux fichiers de donn√©es. Les donn√©es: La BDIM comprend, tous les immigrants admis au Canada depuis 1980, tous les permis des r√©sidents non permanents depuis 1980 et les fichiers de donn√©es fiscales depuis 1982 pour les immigrants coupl√©s. Les donn√©es sont combin√©es √† partir de fichiers administratifs au moyen de techniques d‚Äôappariement exact pour le couplage d‚Äôenregistrements. La BDIM regroupe des donn√©es sur l‚Äôimmigration provenant d‚ÄôIRCC, des donn√©es fiscales provenant de l‚ÄôAgence du revenu du Canada (Estimations annuelles du revenu des familles de recensement et des particuliers ‚Äì Fichier des familles T1) et la date de d√©c√®s provenant de la Base de donn√©es combin√©es sur la mortalit√© de Statistique Canada. Chaque ann√©e, la BDIM est mise √† jour avec l‚Äôajout d‚Äôune nouvelle cohorte d‚Äôimmigrants, de leurs renseignements de r√©sidents non permanents et de nouvelles donn√©es fiscales. Les personnes admises au cours des ann√©es pr√©c√©dentes peuvent √™tre ajout√©es si elles sont coupl√©es √† un enregistrement fiscal par la suite. Les chercheurs ayant peu d‚Äôexp√©rience avec les donn√©es administratives doivent √™tre avis√©s que la BDIM exige la manipulation de plusieurs fichiers de donn√©es volumineux par l‚Äôentremise de couplages d‚Äôenregistrements. Par cons√©quent, de nombreux chercheurs ont constat√© qu‚Äôil faut un certain temps avant de se familiariser avec la Base de donn√©es longitudinales sur l‚Äôimmigration et d‚Äô√™tre en mesure de l‚Äôint√©grer de fa√ßon op√©rationnelle √† leurs recherches.

Depuis 1980, plus de 2.2 millions d‚Äôimmigrants qui ont √©t√© admis au Canada √©taient √¢g√©s de moins de 18 ans au moment de leur admission. Ce nombre repr√©sente 25 % des immigrants admis pendant cette p√©riode. Les enfants feront fort probablement leurs √©tudes en totalit√© ou en partie au Canada et ils devront relever des d√©fis diff√©rents de ceux des immigrants adultes. Peu de renseignements sur les enfants immigrants pendant leur enfance sont accessibles dans la Base de donn√©es longitudinales sur l‚Äôimmigration (BDIM), √©tant donn√© que ces derniers ne produisent pas de d√©claration de revenus. Dans le but d‚Äôaccro√Ætre la capacit√© analytique de la BDIM, un module sur les enfants a √©t√© cr√©√©. La capacit√© d‚Äô√©tudier l‚Äôincidence des conditions socio√©conomiques pendant l‚Äôenfance sur la situation √©conomique √† l‚Äô√¢ge adulte est une valeur ajout√©e √† la BDIM.

Notez que la documentation suppl√©mentaire est disponible pour cette enqu√™te. Veuillez contacter votre analyste du CDR pour demander cette documentation.

Une liste suppl√©mentaire de variables au niveau de l'entreprise peut √™tre reli√©e √† la BDIM pour faciliter la compr√©hension du lien avec le march√© du travail pour les individus de la BDIM. Ces variables sont tir√©es de la Base de donn√©es dynamique employeur-employ√© du Canada. Un module enfant suppl√©mentaire est disponible et peut √™tre reli√© √† la base de donn√©es IMDB pour faciliter la compr√©hension des immigrants admis avant l'√¢ge de la majorit√©.

Title: Extended Longitudinal Survey of Immigrants to Canada
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te longitudinale aupr√®s des immigrants du Canada, version √©largie
Summary:
The Longitudinal Survey of Immigrants to Canada (LSIC), an immigration panel survey, and tax data information from the Longitudinal Immigration Database (IMDB) have been combined to provide an extended analytical file (LSIC-IMDB). Topics covered in the survey include language proficiency, housing, education, foreign credential recognition, employment, health, values and attitudes, the development and use of social networks, income, and perceptions of settlement in Canada. Latest additional socio-economic outcomes are then provided from tax filing information.

In addition to the IMDB-LSIC linkage keys, researchers do need to request and be approved for access to IMDB-Allcycles and LSIC. For any IMDB-LSIC related questions please contact your local Research Data Centre.

The extended file: There exists a constant need for information on immigrants to Canada. As part of adapting to life in Canada, many immigrants face challenges such as finding suitable accommodation, learning or becoming more fluent in one or both of Canada's official languages, participating in the labour market or accessing education and training opportunities. The LSIC provides indicators of how immigrants are meeting these and other challenges. While settlement process may take many years, the LSIC is designed to examine the first four years, a time when newcomers establish economic, social and cultural ties to Canadian society. To this end, the objectives of the survey are two-fold: to study how new immigrants adjust to life in Canada over time; and, to provide information on the factors that can facilitate or hinder this adjustment.

The linkage to IMDB tax data offers a unique opportunity to connect the respondents‚Äô social characteristics to long term socioeconomic outcomes without adding a new wage of interviews. With IMDB tax files updated yearly, LSIC respondents can be followed longitudinally without any sort of respondent burden. Additional detailed economic outcomes increase the analytical capacity of the survey.

This linkage is deterministic, it uses the immigrants‚Äô Serial number from admission file provided by Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC). Additionally, the IMDB brings together immigration from IRCC, taxation data from the Canada Revenue Agency (Annual Income Estimates for Census Families and Individuals ‚ÄìT1 Family files), and the date of death from Statistics Canada‚Äôs Amalgamated Mortality Database (AMDB). The benefits of analysis using the LSIC-IMDB include:
  • Support for evidence based policy making;
  • Increase the use of administrative data sources for research, thereby reducing the cost of data collection and the burden on respondents for surveys;
  • Allow inferential statistical analysis on the confidential microdata and analytical work complex in nature or not suitable for other forms of data access.
The target population for the LSIC survey consists of immigrants who meet all of the following criteria:
  1. arrived in Canada between October 1, 2000 and September 30, 2001;
  2. were age 15 years or older at the time of landing;
  3. landed from abroad, must have applied through a Canadian Mission Abroad.
Refugees claiming asylum from within Canada are excluded from the scope of the survey. To be linked to the IMDB, the respondent will have filed at least one tax return since 1982. This extended survey has a longitudinal design where data from tax are collected on a yearly basis, no additional sampling is done.
Summary French:
L'Enqu√™te longitudinale aupr√®s des immigrants du Canada (ELIC) ; et les donn√©es fiscales de la Base de donn√©es longitudinales sur l'immigration (BDIM) ont √©t√© appari√©es pour donner un fichier √©largi ELIC-BDIM. Le couplage avec les donn√©es fiscales de la BDIM repr√©sente une occasion unique de relier les caract√©ristiques sociales des r√©pondants √† leur situation socio√©conomique √† long terme sans devoir ajouter une nouvelle vague d‚Äôinterviews. Les fichiers de donn√©es fiscales de la BDIM √©tant mis √† jour chaque ann√©e, les r√©pondants √† l‚ÄôELIC peuvent √™tre suivis longitudinalement sans le moindre fardeau de r√©ponse. L‚Äôajout de donn√©es d√©taill√©es sur la situation √©conomique augmente la capacit√© analytique de l‚Äôenqu√™te.

Ce couplage d√©terministe ; utilise le num√©ro de s√©rie d‚Äôimmigrant du dossier d‚Äôadmission fourni par Immigration, R√©fugi√©s et Citoyennet√© Canada (IRCC). De plus, la BDIM regroupe des donn√©es sur l‚Äôimmigration provenant d‚ÄôIRCC, des donn√©es fiscales provenant de l‚ÄôAgence du revenu du Canada (Estimations annuelles du revenu des familles de recensement et des particuliers ‚Äì Fichier des familles T1) et la date de d√©c√®s provenant de la Base de donn√©es combin√©es sur la mortalit√© de Statistique Canada.

En plus de demander les cl√©s du couplage BDIM-ELIC, les chercheurs doivent avoir re√ßu l‚Äôapprobation d‚Äôacc√©der √† la BDIM - Tous les cycles et ELIC. Pour de plus amples renseignements concernants ce fichier √©largi, veuillez communiquer avec votre Centre de donn√©e de recherche.

Les avantages du recours √† l‚ÄôELIC-BDIM aux fins d‚Äôanalyse comprennent :
  • un soutien √† l‚Äô√©laboration de politiques fond√©es sur des donn√©es probantes;
  • une utilisation accrue des sources de donn√©es administratives aux fins de recherche, ce qui diminue les co√ªts de collecte de donn√©es et le fardeau impos√© aux r√©pondants lors des enqu√™tes;
  • la possibilit√© d‚Äôeffectuer des analyses statistiques inf√©rentielles sur des microdonn√©es confidentielles ainsi que du travail d‚Äôanalyse dont la nature est complexe ou qui ne se pr√™te pas √† d‚Äôautres formes d‚Äôacc√®s aux donn√©es
. La population cible de l'ELIC consiste en l'ensemble des immigrants qui r√©pondent aux crit√®res suivants :
  1. immigrants arriv√©s au Canada entre le 1er octobre 2000 et le 30 septembre 2001;
  2. √¢g√©s de 15 ans et plus au moment de leur arriv√©e au Canada;
  3. re√ßus de l'ext√©rieur du Canada et qui ont pr√©sent√© une demande par l'entremise d'une mission canadienne √† l'√©tranger.
Exclus du champ de l'enqu√™te sont les r√©fugi√©s faisant leur demande d'asile ici au Canada. Pour √™tre coupl√© √† la BDIM, le r√©pondant doit avoir produit au moins une d√©claration de revenus depuis 1982. Cette enqu√™te plus large suit un plan longitudinal, et les donn√©es sont recueillies chaque ann√©e √† partir des dossiers fiscaux; aucun √©chantillonnage suppl√©mentaire n‚Äôest effectu√©.
Subjects: Children and youth>Education|Education, training and learning|Population and demography>Census counts>Mobility and migration
Content:
The Longitudinal Survey of Immigrants to Canada (LSIC), an immigration panel survey, and tax data information from the Longitudinal Immigration Database (IMDB) have been combined to provide an extended analytical file (LSIC-IMDB). Topics covered in the survey include language proficiency, housing, education, foreign credential recognition, employment, health, values and attitudes, the development and use of social networks, income, and perceptions of settlement in Canada. Latest additional socio-economic outcomes are then provided from tax filing information.
 
In addition to the IMDB-LSIC linkage keys, researchers do need to request and be approved for access to IMDB-Allcycles and LSIC. For any IMDB-LSIC related questions please contact your local Research Data Centre.
 
The extended file 
There exists a constant need for information on immigrants to Canada. As part of adapting to life in Canada, many immigrants face challenges such as finding suitable accommodation, learning or becoming more fluent in one or both of Canada's official languages, participating in the labour market or accessing education and training opportunities. The LSIC provides indicators of how immigrants are meeting these and other challenges. While settlement process may take many years, the LSIC is designed to examine the first four years, a time when newcomers establish economic, social and cultural ties to Canadian society. To this end, the objectives of the survey are two-fold: to study how new immigrants adjust to life in Canada over time; and, to provide information on the factors that can facilitate or hinder this adjustment. 
 
The linkage to IMDB tax data offers a unique opportunity to connect the respondents‚Äô social characteristics to long term socioeconomic outcomes without adding a new wage of interviews. With IMDB tax files updated yearly, LSIC respondents can be followed longitudinally without any sort of respondent burden. Additional detailed economic outcomes increase the analytical capacity of the survey.
 
This linkage is deterministic, it uses the immigrants‚Äô Serial number from admission file provided by Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC). Additionally, the IMDB brings together immigration from IRCC, taxation data from the Canada Revenue Agency (Annual Income Estimates for Census Families and Individuals ‚ÄìT1 Family files), and the date of death from Statistics Canada‚Äôs Amalgamated Mortality Database (AMDB). The benefits of analysis using the LSIC-IMDB include:  
Support for evidence based policy making;
Increase the use of administrative data sources for research, thereby reducing the cost of data collection and the burden on respondents for surveys;
Allow inferential statistical analysis on the confidential microdata and analytical work complex in nature or not suitable for other forms of data access.
 
The target population for the LSIC survey consists of immigrants who meet all of the following criteria: 
arrived in Canada between October 1, 2000 and September 30, 2001;
were age 15 years or older at the time of landing;
landed from abroad, must have applied through a Canadian Mission Abroad.
 
Refugees claiming asylum from within Canada are also excluded from the scope of the survey. To be linked to the IMDB, the respondent will have filed at least one tax return since 1982. This extended survey has a longitudinal design where data from tax are collected on a yearly basis, no additional sampling is done.

Title: Education and Labour Market Longitudinal Platform
Dataset Title (French): Plateforme longitudinaux entre l'√©ducation et le march√© du travail
Summary:
What is the ELMLP?
  • A Platform ‚Äì where keys are developed, to unlock access to more information about past cohorts of postsecondary students and registered apprentices, to better understand how their education and training affected their career prospects.
  • Securely linked datasets ‚Äì Linking datasets allows researchers to know more than what a single database or survey can provide. When administrative data are involved, the data can be mined for more meaningful information. The linkage process is in excellent hands and individuals cannot be identified, since personal identifiers are replaced with linkage keys and data are aggregated. New datasets will be linked to help answer the questions posed in the research as prioritized in the work plan.
  • Longitudinal data ‚Äì The data available within the platform is also linked longitudinally, allowing researchers to better understand the behaviours and outcomes of students and apprentices, including under-represented groups over time. For example: What was the family income of the student/apprentice before their studies/training? How did they navigate throughout their studies/training? Where did they end up after graduation?
  • Open Data ‚Äì All datasets and linkage keys prepared for the Platform will be made available to researchers through the Research Data Centres network across Canada. The costs associated with this access will be borne by the Government of Canada. In addition, a number of data tables will produced and disseminated annually, free of charge, on Statistics Canada‚Äôs website (CANSIM).


The platform centers around 3 administrative datasets: The RAIS (Registered Apprenticeship Information System), the PSIS (Post-Secondary Information System), and the T1 Family File (tax records). These datasets cover the following periods:
  • PSIS: 2009-latest available for all provinces, 2005-latest available for maritime provinces.
  • T1FF: 1992-latest available
  • RAIS: 2008-latest available.

A variety of supplementary files are part of the platform. A list of these files are maintained here. The most recent addition, not reflected in this update is the Ontario Ministry of Education grade 9-12 data.

Please note that additional documentation is available for this survey. Please contact your RDC analyst to request this documentation.
Summary French:

Cette plateforme de donn√©es s√©curis√©es permettra d‚Äôeffectuer un meilleur suivi et d‚Äôoffrir des renseignements importants sur le march√© du travail. En quoi consiste la Plateforme?
  • Une plateforme ‚Äì Il s‚Äôagit de l‚Äôendroit o√π des clefs sont cr√©√©es pour d√©verrouiller l‚Äôacc√®s √† de plus amples renseignements concernant les anciennes cohortes d‚Äô√©tudiants de niveau postsecondaire et d‚Äôapprentis inscrits, afin de mieux comprendre comment leur √©ducation et leur formation ont influenc√© leurs perspectives de carri√®re.
  • Des ensembles de donn√©es li√©s s√©curis√©s ‚Äì Le couplage des ensembles de donn√©es permet aux chercheurs d‚Äôen savoir plus que ce que peut offrir une simple base de donn√©es ou une enqu√™te. De nouveaux ensembles de donn√©es seront li√©s pour aider √† r√©pondre aux questions pos√©es dans la recherche selon l‚Äôordre de priorit√© √©tabli dans le plan de travail.
  • Des donn√©es longitudinales ‚Äì Les donn√©es disponibles au sein de la Plateforme sont √©galement li√©es longitudinalement, ce qui permet aux chercheurs de mieux comprendre les comportements et les r√©sultats des √©tudiants et des apprentis, y compris ceux des groupes sous-repr√©sent√©s, au fil du temps. Par exemple, quel √©tait le revenu familial de l‚Äô√©tudiant ou de l‚Äôapprenti avant ses √©tudes ou sa formation? Comment se sont-ils d√©brouill√©s tout au long de leurs √©tudes ou de leur formation? O√π ont-ils abouti une fois qu‚Äôils ont obtenu leur dipl√¥me?
  • Des donn√©es ouvertes ‚Äì Tous les ensembles de donn√©es et toutes les clefs d‚Äôappariement pr√©par√©s pour la Plateforme seront mis √† la disposition des chercheurs par l‚Äôinterm√©diaire du R√©seau canadien des Centres de donn√©es de recherche. Les co√ªts associ√©s √† cet acc√®s seront assum√©s par le gouvernement du Canada. De plus, un certain nombre de tableaux de donn√©es seront produits et diffus√©s chaque ann√©e, gratuitement, sur le site Web de Statistique Canada (CANSIM).
Quels donn√©es feront partie de la plateforme? La platforme commen√ßera avec 3 bases de donn√©es administratives: Le SIAI (Syst√®me d‚Äôinformation sur les apprentis inscrits), le SIEP (Syst√®me d‚Äôinformation sur les √©tudiants postsecondaires), et le FFT1 (fichier des famille T1). Les donn√©es seront actualis√©es aussit√¥t que possible et r√©montent comme suite:
  • SIEP: 2009-Plus r√©centes disponibles - toutes provinces; 2005-plus r√©centes disponibles - provinces marit√Æmes.
  • FFT1: 1992-Plus r√©centes disponibles

Title: Canadian Community Health Survey linked to the Longitudinal Immigration Database
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te sur la sant√© dans les collectivit√©s canadiennes et de la Base de donn√©es longitudinales sur l‚Äôimmigration
Summary: Statistics Canada and Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) are pleased to announce the release of a linked data set that brings together data from both organizations. These linked data provide information on the health, social and economic outcomes of immigrants in different immigration classes and categories. They will also allow researchers to study the health/social and economic outcomes of immigrants in the areas of newcomer settlement, resettlement and integration. As part of its record linkage activities, Statistics Canada linked the Canadian Community Health Survey (CCHS 2000-2014) with the Longitudinal Immigrant Database (IMDB 1980-2016). IRCC is collaborating with Statistics Canada to make the IMDB and the linked data available in the Research Data Centers. The linking of Statistics Canada health survey data with administrative data on immigrants creates a valuable dataset that can provide answers to important research questions that cannot be found in either survey or administrative data alone.

Ces donn√©es coupl√©es fournissent de l‚Äôinformation sur les r√©sultats sociaux, √©conomiques et en mati√®re de sant√© des immigrants dans diff√©rentes classes et cat√©gories d‚Äôimmigration. Elles aideront aussi les chercheurs √† √©tudier les r√©sultats sociaux, √©conomiques et en mati√®re de sant√© des immigrants dans les domaines de l‚Äô√©tablissement des nouveaux arrivants, de la r√©installation et de l‚Äôint√©gration. Dans le cadre de ses activit√©s de couplage d‚Äôenregistrements, Statistique Canada a coupl√© l‚ÄôEnqu√™te sur la sant√© dans les collectivit√©s canadiennes (ESCC 2000-2014) √† la Base de donn√©es longitudinales sur l‚Äôimmigration (BDIM 1980-2016). Le couplage de donn√©es d‚Äôenqu√™tes sur la sant√© de Statistique Canada √† des donn√©es administratives sur les immigrants que poss√®de IRCC permet d‚Äôobtenir des ensembles de donn√©es fort utiles qui peuvent fournir des r√©ponses √† des questions de recherche importantes auxquelles les donn√©es d‚Äôenqu√™te et les donn√©es administratives, √† elles seules, ne peuvent r√©pondre.
Subjects: Health>Lifestyle and social conditions|Health>Mental health and well-being|Population and demography>Census counts>Mobility and migration|Health>Prevention and detection of disease
Content: Statistics Canada and Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) are pleased to announce the release of a linked data set that brings together data from both organizations. These linked data provide information on the health, social and economic outcomes of immigrants in different immigration classes and categories. They will also allow researchers to study the health/social and economic outcomes of immigrants in the areas of newcomer settlement, resettlement and integration. As part of its record linkage activities, Statistics Canada linked the Canadian Community Health Survey (CCHS) with the Longitudinal Immigrant Database (IMDB). IRCC is collaborating with Statistics Canada to make the IMDB and the linked data available in the Research Data Centers. The linking of Statistics Canada health survey data with administrative data on immigrants creates a valuable dataset that can provide answers to important research questions that cannot be found in either survey or administrative data alone.

Title: Employment Insurance Status Vector
Dataset Title (French): Profil vectoriel de l‚Äôassurance-emploi
Summary:
The microdata from the Employment Insurance Program‚Äôs administrative records on EI beneficiaries are now available in the RDCs.The Employment Insurance Status Vector (EISV) data consist of individual-level, weekly records covering the period of January 1997 to August 2018. For each individual, there is a hierarchy of files, including one ‚Äúheader‚Äù file and multiple ‚Äútrailer‚Äù files. The header file contains policy-relevant information on the claims, such as the reason of separation, the previous occupation of the claimant, and the number of weeks of benefits received. The trailer files contain supplementary information on a weekly basis for those claims.

There are three trailer files, capturing relevant weekly information on:
  1. Disqualification or disentitlement;
  2. Benefits (i.e., information reported by an EI claimant on biweekly reports to Service Canada, and the outcome of these reports, regarding the payment of benefits, the reason for non-payment of benefits, and receipt of income from other sources, such as part-time work or training allowance); and
  3. Earnings (i.e., detailed work activity and earnings, as reported by an EI claimant to Service Canada on a biweekly basis).
In addition, EISV postal code file is available in a separate folder. Access is granted separately to EISV-postal code as specified by the MRC.
Summary French:
Il est maintenant possible d‚Äôacc√©der aux microdonn√©es sur les prestataires du r√©gime d‚Äôassurance-emploi (AE), tir√©es des dossiers administratifs du r√©gime.Le Profil vectoriel d'assurance-emploi (PVAE) renferme des enregistrements individuels hebdomadaires pour la p√©riode de janvier 1997 √† ao√ªt 2018. Une hi√©rarchie de fichiers, y compris un fichier ¬´ ma√Ætre ¬ª et des fichiers ¬´ compl√©mentaires ¬ª, est √©tablie pour chaque personne. Le fichier ma√Ætre contient des renseignements sur les r√©clamations, comme la raison de la cessation d‚Äôemploi, la profession ant√©rieure du demandeur et le nombre de semaines de prestations re√ßues. Les fichiers compl√©mentaires contiennent des renseignements suppl√©mentaires sur ces demandes.

Il existe trois fichiers compl√©mentaires qui contiennent des renseignements hebdomadaires pertinents sur les sujets suivants :
  1. l'exclusion ou l'inadmissibilit√©;
  2. les prestations (c.-√†-d. les renseignements fournis par les demandeurs d‚Äôassurance-emploi dans les rapports bihebdomadaires transmis √† Service Canada, et les r√©sultats de ces rapports; en ce qui concerne; le versement de prestations, les motifs de non-paiement de prestations, et la perception de revenus d‚Äôautres sources comme le travail √† temps partiel ou les allocations de formation); et
  3. les revenus (c.-√†-d. la description d√©taill√©e du travail effectu√© et des revenus, selon les renseignements fournis aux deux semaines √† Service Canada par les demandeurs d‚Äôassurance-emploi).
De plus, le fichier des codes postaux du PVAE est maintenant accessible sur le CDR dans un dossier s√©par√©. L‚Äôacc√®s est accord√© de fa√ßon distincte aux codes postaux du PVAE comme pr√©cis√© par le CRM. Veuillez communiquer avec votre CDR, pour plus de renseignements concernant l'acc√®s aux donn√©es du PVAE.Le r√©gime d‚Äôassurance-emploi offre un soutien du revenu aux travailleurs sans emploi pendant qu'ils cherchent du travail ou perfectionnent leurs comp√©tences. Il fournit √©galement des prestations sp√©ciales aux travailleurs qui s'absentent du travail en raison d'√©v√©nements pr√©cis de la vie (maladie, grossesse, soins √† un nouveau-n√©, √† un enfant nouvellement adopt√© ou √† un enfant gravement malade, soins √† un membre de la famille qui est gravement malade et qui risque de mourir). Les travailleurs re√ßoivent des prestations seulement s'ils ont cotis√© au r√©gime au cours de la derni√®re ann√©e et satisfont aux conditions d'admissibilit√©. Les travailleurs ind√©pendants peuvent participer au r√©gime d'assurance-emploi et recevoir des prestations sp√©ciales. Pour de plus amples renseignements sur ce programme, veuillez consulter le plus r√©cent Rapport de contr√¥le et d'√©valuation de l‚Äôassurance-emploi.

Title: Discharge Abstract Database - National Ambulatory Care Reporting System - Ontario Mental Health Reporting System linked to Canadian Vital Statistics Death Database
Dataset Title (French): Base de donn√©es sur les cong√©s des patients - Syst√®me national d‚Äôinformation sur les soins ambulatoires - Syst√®me d‚Äôinformation ontarien sur la sant√© mentale li√©e √† Base canadienne de donn√©es sur les d√©c√®s
Summary:
New Hospitalization data linked to death data is now available in Research Data Centres across Canada. As part of its record linkage activities, Statistics Canada has linked the patient records in the Discharge Abstract Database (DAD), the National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NACRS) and the Ontario Mental Health Reporting System (OMHRS), which are provided to Statistics Canada annually by the Canadian Institute for Health Information (CIHI), to the Canadian Vital Statistics Death Database. These linked data can be used to develop and validate health care indicators and perform survival and outcome analyses on acute hospital data.

The linking of Vital Statistic Death data with provincial administrative data held by CIHI creates a valuable dataset that can provide answers to important research questions that cannot be found in single administrative datasets alone. Statistics Canada has a long history of creating and using record linkages. Record linkage is an important and cost-effective statistical technique used to develop data products that support advanced research and provide insight on important social issues, such as health outcomes and disparities in subsectors of the Canadian population. The Discharge Abstract Database (DAD) (2000/2001 to 2020/2021), the National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NACRS) (2002/2003 to 2020/2021) and the Ontario Mental Health Reporting System (OMHRS) (2005/2006 to 2020/2021) linked to the Canadian Vital Statistics Death Database (CVSD) (January 1, 2000 to December 31, 2020) dataset is now accessible at Statistics Canada‚Äôs Research Data Centres across the country.
Summary French:
De nouvelles donn√©es sur les hospitalisations coupl√©es aux donn√©es sur les d√©c√®s sont d√©sormais accessibles dans les centres de donn√©es de recherche partout au Canada. Dans le cadre de ses activit√©s de couplage d‚Äôenregistrements, Statistique Canada a coupl√© des enregistrements de patients de la Base de donn√©es sur les cong√©s des patients (BDCP), du Syst√®me national d‚Äôinformation sur les soins ambulatoires (SNISA) et du Syst√®me d‚Äôinformation ontarien sur la sant√© mentale (SIOSM), que Statistique Canada re√ßoit chaque ann√©e de l‚ÄôInstitut canadien d‚Äôinformation sur la sant√© (ICIS), √† la Statistique de l‚Äô√©tat civil ‚Äì Base canadienne de donn√©es sur les d√©c√®s.

Ces donn√©es coupl√©es peuvent servir √† mettre au point et √† valider des indicateurs de soins de sant√©, de m√™me qu‚Äô√† effectuer des analyses de survie et des r√©sultats √† partir des donn√©es provenant des h√¥pitaux de soins de courte dur√©e. Le couplage de donn√©es de la statistique de l‚Äô√©tat civil sur les d√©c√®s avec des donn√©es administratives provinciales que poss√®de l‚ÄôICIS permet d‚Äôobtenir des ensembles de donn√©es fort utiles, capables d‚Äôapporter des r√©ponses √† des questions de recherche importantes auxquelles les ensembles de donn√©es administratives, √† eux seuls, ne peuvent r√©pondre.

Statistique Canada cr√©e et utilise depuis longtemps des couplages d‚Äôenregistrements. Le couplage d‚Äôenregistrements est une technique statistique importante et peu co√ªteuse qui est utilis√©e pour √©laborer des produits de donn√©es qui servent de fondement √† la recherche de pointe et permettent de mieux comprendre des questions sociales importantes, comme les r√©sultats en mati√®re de sant√© et les disparit√©s observ√©es dans des sous-segments de la population canadienne.

L‚Äôensemble de donn√©es Base de donn√©es sur les cong√©s des patients (BDCP) (de 2000-2001 √† 2020-2021), Syst√®me national d‚Äôinformation sur les soins ambulatoires (SNISA) (de 2002-2003 √† 2020-2021) et Syst√®me d‚Äôinformation ontarien sur la sant√© mentale (SIOSM) (de 2005-2006 √† 2020-2021) coupl√©s √† la Statistique de l‚Äô√©tat civil ‚Äì Base canadienne de donn√©es sur les d√©c√®s (BCDECD) (du 1er janvier 2000 au 31 d√©cembre 2020) est maintenant accessible dans les centres de donn√©es de recherche de Statistique Canada partout au pays
Subjects: Health>Mental health and well-being
Content: New Hospitalization data linked to death data is now available in Research Data Centres across Canada. As part of its record linkage activities, Statistics Canada has linked the patient records in the Discharge Abstract Database (DAD), the National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NACRS) and the Ontario Mental Health Reporting System (OMHRS), which are provided to Statistics Canada annually by the Canadian Institute for Health Information (CIHI), to the Canadian Vital Statistics Death Database. These linked data can be used to develop and validate health care indicators and perform survival and outcome analyses on acute hospital data. The linking of Vital Statistic Death data with provincial administrative data held by CIHI creates a valuable dataset that can provide answers to important research questions that cannot be found in single administrative datasets alone. Statistics Canada has a long history of creating and using record linkages. Record linkage is an important and cost-effective statistical technique used to develop data products that support advanced research and provide insight on important social issues, such as health outcomes and disparities in subsectors of the Canadian population. The Discharge Abstract Database (DAD) (2000/2001 to 2014/2015), the National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NACRS) (2002/2003 to 2014/2015) and the Ontario Mental Health Reporting System (OMHRS) (2005/2006 to 2014/2015) linked to the Canadian Vital Statistics Death Database (CVSD) (January 1, 2000 to December 31, 2012) dataset is now accessible at Statistics Canada‚Äôs Research Data Centres across the country.

Title: Employment Insurance Beneficiaries
Dataset Title (French): Donn√©es sur les prestataires d‚Äôassurance-emploi
Summary:
The Employment Insurance (EI) program provides temporary income support to unemployed workers while they look for employment or upgrade their skills. It also provides special benefits to workers who take time off from work in relation to specific life events (e.g., illness; pregnancy; and caring for a newborn, newly-adopted or critically-ill or injured child or adult). Workers receive EI benefits only if they have paid premiums in the past year and meet qualifying and entitlement conditions. Self-employed workers may participate in EI and receive special benefits.

The EIB data consist of person-level, weekly records covering the period of January 1997 to June 2018. It includes information for only one week per month, which coincides with the Labour Force Survey reference week. Each of these weekly records was produced from information available about 3.5 months following the reference period. Individual records cannot be longitudinally linked over time by person or business. Please refer to the Employment Insurance Status Vector data for longitudinally linkable beneficiary records.

Each record contains policy-relevant information on the claims, such as the previous occupation of the claimant, insurable hours and earnings, and the claim‚Äôs weekly benefit rate. Each record also contains information for the reference week including benefit type, earnings and number of continuous weeks on claim.

Les travailleurs re√ßoivent des prestations d‚Äôassurance-emploi seulement s‚Äôils ont cotis√© au r√©gime au cours de la derni√®re ann√©e et satisfont aux conditions d‚Äôadmissibilit√©. Les travailleurs ind√©pendants peuvent participer au r√©gime d‚Äôassurance-emploi et recevoir des prestations sp√©ciales.

Les donn√©es sur les PAE contiennent des enregistrements hebdomadaires au niveau de la personne, pour la p√©riode allant de janvier 1997 √† juin 2018. Elles comprennent des renseignements d‚Äôune seule semaine par mois, cette semaine co√Øncidant avec la semaine de r√©f√©rence de l‚ÄôEnqu√™te sur la population active. Chacun de ces enregistrements hebdomadaires a √©t√© produit √† partir de renseignements disponibles environ 3,5 mois apr√®s de la p√©riode de r√©f√©rence. Les enregistrements individuels ne peuvent pas √™tre coupl√©s longitudinalement dans le temps par personne ou entreprise. Veuillez consulter les donn√©es du Profil vectoriel de l‚Äôassurance-emploi pour acc√©der √† des enregistrements de prestataires qu‚Äôil est possible de coupler longitudinalement.

Chaque enregistrement renferme des renseignements pertinents pour l‚Äôanalyse de politiques √† propos des demandes, tels que l‚Äôemploi pr√©c√©dent du prestataire, les heures et la r√©mun√©ration assurables, ainsi que le taux hebdomadaire de prestations de la demande. Chaque enregistrement contient √©galement des renseignements pour la semaine de r√©f√©rence dont le type de prestations, la r√©mun√©ration et le nombre de semaines continues de la demande.

Title: Record of Employment
Dataset Title (French): Relev√©s d‚Äôemploi
Summary: The ROE data contains person-level information from ROE forms. The ROE form‚Äîwhether electronic or paper‚Äîis the form that employers complete for employees who stop working for various reasons, including retirements, quit, job loss. Employers may not issue a ROE in all cases. But for employees who experience an interruption of earnings and want to claim Employment Insurance (EI), the ROE is a mandatory document. Recently, more ROE forms are completed electronically, either through Secure Automated Transfer, or ROE web application. The remaining forms are completed using paper copies. The ROE data provides longitudinally linkable information on individuals' job separations over the period from 1987 to the most recent update, for policy analysis, research, and evaluation activities. Such activities foster the development and implementation of federal labour market and income related policies and programs in an effective manner, and consistent with national goals. The EI program provides temporary income support to unemployed workers while they look for employment or upgrade their skills. It also provides special benefits to workers who take time off from work in relation to specific life events (e.g., illness; pregnancy; and caring for a newborn, newly-adopted or critically-ill or injured child or adult). Workers receive EI benefits only if they have paid premiums in the past year and meet qualifying and entitlement conditions. Self-employed workers may participate in EI and receive special benefits. The ROE includes very limited information on EI claims. Please refer to the Employment Insurance Status Vector and the Employment Insurance Beneficiaries data for detailed information on beneficiary records.
Summary French:
Les donn√©es des RE contiennent des renseignements au niveau de la personne provenant des formulaires de RE. Le formulaire de RE, en format √©lectronique ou papier, est le formulaire que remplissent les employeurs pour les employ√©s qui ont cess√© leur emploi, notamment en raison d‚Äôune retraite, d‚Äôun d√©part volontaire ou d‚Äôune perte d‚Äôemploi. Les travailleurs re√ßoivent des prestations d‚Äôassurance-emploi seulement s‚Äôils ont cotis√© au r√©gime au cours de la derni√®re ann√©e et satisfont aux conditions d‚Äôadmissibilit√©. Pour de plus amples renseignements, veuillez consulter le plus r√©cent Rapport de contr√¥le et d‚Äô√©valuation de l‚Äôassurance-emploi. Les donn√©es des RE comprennent des renseignements tr√®s limit√©s sur les demandes d‚Äôassurance-emploi. Title: Canadian Vital Statistics Death Data - Discharge Abstract Database - National Ambulatory Care Reporting System
Dataset Title (French): Base de donn√©es sur les d√©c√®s de la Statistique de l‚Äô√©tat civil - Base de donn√©es sur les cong√©s des patients - Syst√®me national d‚Äôinformation sur les soins ambulatoires
Summary: As part of its data integration activities, Statistics Canada updated the linked data from the Canadian Vital Statistics Death Database (CVSD) to hospitalization information by adding more years and datasets. The data includes information from the CVSD from 2008 to 2017, and is linked to the Discharge Abstract Database (DAD) from 2004/05 to 2017/18, to the National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NACRS) from 2004/05 to 2017/18 and now to the Ontario Mental Health Reporting System (OMHRS) from 2006/07 to 2017/18. CIHI is collaborating with Statistics Canada to make the integrated data available in the Research Data Centers (RDC) and to support researchers using the file. The integration of death data with administrative data held by CIHI creates a valuable dataset that can provide answers to important research questions that cannot be found in single administrative datasets alone. Statistics Canada has a long history of creating and using record linkages to integrate datasets. Data integration is an important and cost-effective statistical technique used to develop data products that can be used to address important data gaps such as to broaden our understanding of health care service usage patterns during the period leading up to the end of life. For any CVSD_DAD_NACRS_OMHRS related questions please contact your local Research Data Centre.

Summary: Statistics Canada, in partnership with Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) and the Canadian Institute for Health Information (CIHI), is pleased to announce the release of a new integrated dataset. As part of its record data linkage activities, Statistics Canada has linked the Longitudinal Immigration Database (IMDB) with patient records in the Discharge Abstract Database (DAD). Title: Canada Student Loan Program
Dataset Title (French): Programme canadien de pr√™ts aux √©tudiants
Summary: This dataset provides recipient-level longitudinal information by loan year (August 1 to July 31) for the period of 2003-2004 to 2015-2016. It provides three files which track recipients through all phases of the loan or grant lifecycle: The Needs file provides data on the loan and grant application process of each person during a loan year. The Disbursements file covers loan and grant disbursements for each person and loan The Repayment file provides data on the repayment and repayment assistance status of each person. The CSLP data can be linked to the Post-secondary Information System (PSIS) records, up to 2009. Access is granted separately to CSLP and PSIS as specified by the MRC. Researchers must request access to each separate data product. The CSLP is part of Statistics Canada‚Äôs
Summary French:
Les microdonn√©es sur les b√©n√©ficiaires du Programme canadien de pr√™ts aux √©tudiants (PCPE) sont maintenant accessibles dans les centres de donn√©es de recherche partout au pays.
 
Le PCPE fait partie de Plateforme longitudinale entre l‚Äô√©ducation et le march√© du travail (PLEMT) de Statistique Canada.
 
Statistique Canada et Emploi et D√©veloppement social Canada (EDSC) sont heureux de vous annoncer que les microdonn√©es tir√©es des dossiers administratifs du PCPE sur les b√©n√©ficiaires de l‚Äôaide financi√®re aux √©tudiants sont maintenant accessibles.
 
Le PCPE offre une aide financi√®re (des bourses et des pr√™ts), remboursable et non remboursable, aux √©tudiants admissibles afin de leur permettre d‚Äôavoir acc√®s √† l‚Äô√©ducation postsecondaire et d‚Äôen assumer les frais. Le Programme offre √©galement une aide au remboursement aux emprunteurs qui ont de la difficult√© √† rembourser leurs pr√™ts √©tudiants. Toutes les provinces et tous les territoires participent au PCPE, √† l‚Äôexception du Qu√©bec, des Territoires du Nord-Ouest et du Nunavut, qui re√ßoivent des montants compensatoires du gouvernement du Canada afin de g√©rer leurs propres programmes d‚Äôaide financi√®re aux √©tudiants. En plus de l‚Äôaide financi√®re offerte par le gouvernement f√©d√©ral au moyen du PCPE, les provinces et les territoires proposent leurs propres programmes d‚Äôaide financi√®re aux √©tudiants. Les donn√©es du PCPE accessibles dans les centres de donn√©es de recherche tiennent uniquement compte de l‚Äôaide financi√®re offerte aux √©tudiants par le gouvernement f√©d√©ral.
   
Les donn√©es du PCPE fournissent des renseignements longitudinaux sur les b√©n√©ficiaires par ann√©e de pr√™t (du 1er ao√ªt au 31 juillet) pour la p√©riode allant de 2003-2004 √† 2015-2016. Le PCPE fournit trois fichiers aux centres de donn√©es de recherches qui permettent de suivre les b√©n√©ficiaires de l‚Äôaide financi√®re aux √©tudiants tout au long du cycle de vie du pr√™t ou de la bourse.
 
Le fichier des besoins fournit des donn√©es sur le processus de demande de pr√™t et de bourse de chaque personne au cours d‚Äôune ann√©e de pr√™t.
Le fichier des versements porte sur les versements de pr√™ts et de bourses pour chaque personne et chaque ann√©e de pr√™t. 
Le fichier des remboursements fournit des donn√©es sur l‚Äô√©tat du remboursement et de l‚Äôaide au remboursement de chaque personne.
 
Les donn√©es du PCPE peuvent √™tre coupl√©es aux dossiers du Syst√®me d‚Äôinformation sur les √©tudiants postsecondaires (SIEP). Seuls les dossiers pour les √©tudiants dans le SIEP depuis 2009 peuvent √™tre coupl√©s au PCPE. Un acc√®s distinct doit √™tre accord√© au PCPE et au SIEP, comme cela est pr√©cis√© dans le CRM. Les chercheurs doivent demander un acc√®s distinct √† chaque produit de donn√©es. Plateforme longitudinale entre l‚Äô√©ducation et le march√© du travail (PLEMT) de Statistique Canada.
Subjects: Education, training and learning>Financial resources invested in education
Content: This dataset provides recipient-level longitudinal information by loan year (August 1 to July 31) for the period of 2003-2004 to 2015-2016. It provides three files which track recipients through all phases of the loan or grant lifecycle: The Needs file provides data on the loan and grant application process of each person during a loan year. The Disbursements file covers loan and grant disbursements for each person and loan The Repayment file provides data on the repayment and repayment assistance status of each person. The CSLP data can be linked to the Post-secondary Information System (PSIS) records, up to 2009. Access is granted separately to CSLP and PSIS as specified by the MRC. Researchers must request access to each separate data product. The CSLP is part of Statistics Canada‚Äôs

Title: Business Research Microdata
Dataset Title (French): Microdonn√©es de recherche sur les entreprises
Summary: The goal of the Business Research Microdata (BRM), developed by the Economic Analysis Division at Statistics Canada, is to provide external researchers at Research Data Centres (RDC) a set of ‚Äòcore‚Äô firm level variables that are able to satisfy the economic questions their projects seek to answer. These include variables from the balance sheet, statements of income, employment slips, etc. of enterprises in Canada. In addition, EAD has created a number of derived variables for the BRM. These variables are based on economic theory and common usage, and helps to alleviate the burden of correct specification for external researchers. The BRM resources contain a list of variables in the BRM and a data dictionary.
Summary French: L‚Äôobjectif des Microdonn√©es de recherche sur les entreprises (MRE), √©labor√©es par la Division de l‚Äôanalyse √©conomique (DAE) de Statistique Canada, est de fournir aux chercheurs externes des centres de donn√©es de recherche (CDR) un ensemble de variables ¬´ de base ¬ª au niveau de l‚Äôentreprise, qui permet de r√©pondre aux questions √©conomiques faisant l‚Äôobjet de leurs projets de recherche. Il s‚Äôagit notamment de variables du bilan, de l‚Äô√©tat des r√©sultats, les feuillets d‚Äôemploi, etc. des entreprises au Canada. De plus, la DAE a cr√©√© un certain nombre de variables d√©riv√©es pour les MRE. Ces variables sont fond√©es sur la th√©orie √©conomique et l‚Äôusage courant et aident √† all√©ger le fardeau de la sp√©cification appropri√©e pour les chercheurs externes.
