Content: The goal of the Business Research Microdata (BRM), developed by the Economic Analysis Division at Statistics Canada, is to provide external researchers at Research Data Centres (RDC) a set of ‚Äòcore‚Äô firm level variables that are able to satisfy the economic questions their projects seek to answer. These include variables from the balance sheet, statements of income, employment slips, etc. of enterprises in Canada. In addition, EAD has created a number of derived variables for the BRM. These variables are based on economic theory and common usage, and helps to alleviate the burden of correct specification for external researchers. The BRM document provides an overview of the source files for the BRM, a user guide, a list of variables in the BRM, and detailed descriptions of each variable. The supplementary PDF file provides a condensed list of variables in the BRM.

Title: Survey on Early Learning and Child Care Arrangements
Dataset Title (French): L‚ÄôEnqu√™te sur les modes d'apprentissage et de garde des jeunes enfants
Summary:
Statistics Canada is gathering information from families who use child care as well as those who do not. The survey, which addresses child care in Canada for children younger than 6 years old, asks about the different types of early learning and child care arrangements that families use, difficulties some families may face when looking for care, as well as reasons for not using child care.

The Survey on Early Learning and Child Care Arrangements 2019 (SELCCA) has been linked to various administrative data sources:
  • 2017 T1 Family File (T1FF)
  • 2018 Canadian Child Benefit (CCB)
  • 2016 Census of Population ‚Äì Short-Form
  • Longitudinal Immigration Database ‚Äì 1980 to 2017 (IMDB)
  • Index of remoteness and accessibility
The sampling unit is the person knowledgeable about the child care arrangements for a child who lives in their household and is less than 6 years of age. SELCCA can produce provincial level estimates, as well as estimates for the territories. The objective of this linkage is to examine the characteristics of children and parents using (or not using) child care. The SELCCA is augmented with income, demographic and family structure variables from T1FF file and CCB files respectively and language variables from the 2016 short form Census. The date of immigration and immigrant flag for the children, CCB recipients and their spouses who linked to the IMDB will also be added to the SELCCA.
Summary French:
Statistique Canada recueille des renseignements aupr√®s des familles ayant recours √† des modes de garde ainsi que de celles n'y ayant pas recours. L'enqu√™te, qui examine les modes de garde au Canada pour les enfants de moins de six ans, porte sur les diff√©rents modes d'apprentissage et de garde des jeunes enfants auxquels ont recours les familles, les difficult√©s auxquelles certaines familles peuvent √™tre confront√©es lorsqu'elles cherchent des services de garde, ainsi que les raisons pour lesquelles certaines familles n'utilisent pas ces services. Les donn√©es de l‚ÄôEnqu√™te sur les modes d‚Äôapprentissage et de garde des jeunes enfants (EMAGJE) de 2019 ont √©t√© coupl√©es √† celles de diverses sources administratives :
  • Fichier des familles T1 (FFT1)
  • Fichier de l‚ÄôAllocation canadienne pour enfants (ACE);
  • Recensement de la population de 2016 ‚Äì questionnaire abr√©g√©;
  • Base de donn√©es longitudinales sur l‚Äôimmigration (BDIM);
  • Indice d'√©loignement et d'accessibilit√©.
L‚Äôunit√© d‚Äô√©chantillonnage est la personne bien inform√©e des modes de garde de l‚Äôenfant qui vit dans le m√©nage et qui est √¢g√© de moins de 6 ans. Les donn√©es de l‚ÄôEMAGJE peuvent permettre de produire des estimations √† l‚Äô√©chelle provinciale, ainsi que des estimations √† l‚Äô√©chelle territoriale. Les donn√©es de l‚ÄôEMAGJE sont compl√©t√©es par les variables sur le revenu, les caract√©ristiques d√©mographiques et la structure familiale du FFT1 et des fichiers de l‚ÄôACE respectivement, et par les variables linguistiques du questionnaire abr√©g√© du Recensement de 2016. La date d‚Äôimmigration et l‚Äôindicateur d‚Äôimmigrant pour les enfants, les b√©n√©ficiaires de l‚ÄôACE et leur conjoint ou conjointe pour lesquels il y a un couplage aux donn√©es de la BDIM seront √©galement ajout√©s aux donn√©es de l‚ÄôEMAGJE.
Subjects: Children and youth>Child care
Content: Statistics Canada is gathering information from families who use child care as well as those who do not. The survey, which addresses child care in Canada for children younger than 6 years old, asks about the different types of early learning and child care arrangements that families use, difficulties some families may face when looking for care, as well as reasons for not using child care. This survey is part of the Government of Canada's investment in early learning and child care. Information will be used to provide a current snapshot of the use of child care and of barriers to child care access. The results of this survey can be used to inform research, policies and programs aimed at improving the accessibility and affordability of high-quality early learning and child care in Canada. The Survey on Early Learning and Child Care Arrangements (SELCCA) - 2019 has been linked to various administrative sources: ¬∑ 2017 T1 Family File (T1FF) ¬∑ 2018 Canadian Child Benefit (CCB) ¬∑ 2016 Census of Population ‚Äì Short-Form ¬∑ Longitudinal Immigration Database ‚Äì 1980 to 2017 (IMDB) The Survey on Early Learning and Child Care Arrangements (SELCCA) is part of the Government of Canada's investment in early learning and child care. Information will be used to provide a current snapshot of the use of child care and of barriers to child care access. The sampling unit is the person knowledgeable about the child care arrangements for a child who lives in their household and is less than 6 years of age. SELCCA can produce provincial level estimates, as well as estimates for the territories. The objective of this linkage is to examine the characteristics of children and parents using (or not using) child care. The SELCCA is augmented with income, demographic and family structure variables from T1FF file and CCB files respectively and language variables from the 2016 short form Census. The date of immigration and immigrant flag for the children, CCB recipients and their spouses who linked to the IMDB will also be added to the SELCCA.

Title: Longitudinal Worker File
Dataset Title (French): Fichier de donn√©es longitudinales sur la main-d‚Äô≈ìuvre
Summary: The Longitudinal Worker File (LWF) is an administrative database designed to provide information on employment dynamics in Canada. From the linked administrative tax data sources, information on workers‚Äô demographic characteristics, the jobs they hold, the business enterprises in which they work, and the earnings they receive can be identified. This structure, coupled with information that allows workers‚Äô movements from employer to employer be identified, makes the LWF particularly well-suited to studying a variety of issues (e.g., labour turnover and mobility, earnings dynamics, and transitions to retirement). The LWF-RDC file is a version of the LWF 100% file that can be accessed by researchers at the Research Data Centres (RDCs). This LWF-RDC version 1.0 covers tax years between 1991 and 2016 with the following key features:  A 10% file extracted from the LWF 100% file. A generic firm ID is created to identify the same firm that individuals are associated with so that individual job mobility can be tracked but information cannot be aggregated at the firm-level. Industry information associated with each job record will be provided at aggregate level (2-digit NAICS level from 1991 onwards).
Summary French: Le FDLMO est une base de donn√©es administratives qui fournit de l‚Äôinformation sur la dynamique de l‚Äôemploi au Canada. √Ä partir de sources de donn√©es fiscales administratives coupl√©es, des renseignements sont obtenus sur les caract√©ristiques d√©mographiques des travailleurs, les emplois qu‚Äôils occupent, les entreprises pour lesquelles ils travaillent et les gains qu‚Äôils re√ßoivent. Gr√¢ce √† cette structure, associ√©e √† de l‚Äôinformation qui permet de rep√©rer les mouvements des travailleurs d‚Äôun employeur √† un autre, le FDLMO est particuli√®rement bien adapt√© √† l‚Äô√©tude de diverses questions (par exemple la mobilit√© et le roulement de la main-d‚Äô≈ìuvre, la dynamique de la r√©mun√©ration et les transitions menant √† la retraite).Le FDLMO-CDR est une version du FDLMO int√©gral qui est accessible aux chercheurs des centres de donn√©es de recherche (CDR). Cette version 1.0 du FDLMO-CDR traite des ann√©es d‚Äôimposition allant de 1991 √† 2016 et pr√©sente les caract√©ristiques principales suivantes : Un fichier de 10 % extrait du FDLMO int√©gral. Un identificateur g√©n√©rique des entreprises est cr√©√© pour identifier la m√™me entreprise √† laquelle sont associ√©es des personnes afin de suivre la mobilit√© professionnelle individuelle. Cependant, les donn√©es ne peuvent pas √™tre agr√©g√©es au niveau de l‚Äôentreprise. L‚Äôinformation sur l‚Äôindustrie associ√©e √† chaque enregistrement d‚Äôemploi sera fournie au niveau de l‚Äôagr√©gation (niveau du code du Syst√®me de classification des industries de l‚ÄôAm√©rique du Nord [SCIAN] √† deux chiffres √† partir de 1991).
Subjects: Income, pensions, spending and wealth
Content: The Longitudinal Worker File (LWF) is an administrative database designed to provide information on employment dynamics in Canada. From the linked administrative tax data sources, information on workers‚Äô demographic characteristics, the jobs they hold, the business enterprises in which they work, and the earnings they receive can be identified. This structure, coupled with information that allows workers‚Äô movements from employer to employer be identified, makes the LWF particularly well-suited to studying a variety of issues (e.g., labour turnover and mobility, earnings dynamics, and transitions to retirement). The LWF-RDC file is a version of the LWF 100% file that can be accessed by researchers at the Research Data Centres (RDCs). This LWF-RDC version 1.0 covers tax years between 1991 and 2016 with the following key features:  A 10% file extracted from the LWF 100% file. Title: Canada Disability Savings Program
Dataset Title (French): Les donn√©es sur le Programme canadien pour l‚Äô√©pargne-invalidit√©
Summary: Statistics Canada and Employment and Social Development Canada (ESDC) are pleased to announce the availability of microdata from the Canada Disability Savings Program (CDSP) administrative records on CDSP beneficiaries. The CDSP contains information on all beneficiaries and holders of Registered Disability Saving Plans (RDSPs) from 2008 to 2018. A RDSP helps save for the long-term financial security of a person with a disability. Each record is specific to the beneficiary, contract and year. The microdata includes information on: Disability Assistance Payment (DAP) or Lifetime Disability Assistance Payment (LDAP) which are payments made from a RDSP to the beneficiary or his/her estate. DAPs are single lump sum amounts. LDAPs are payments which, once started, are payable at least annually until the beneficiary's death or the plan is terminated.
Summary French: Statistique Canada et Emploi et D√©veloppement social Canada (EDSC) ont le plaisir d‚Äôannoncer que les microdonn√©es tir√©es des dossiers administratifs des b√©n√©ficiaires du PCEI sont accessibles.Les dossiers administratifs du PCEI contiennent des renseignements sur tous les b√©n√©ficiaires et titulaires de r√©gimes enregistr√©s d‚Äô√©pargne-invalidit√© (REEI) de 2008 √† 2018. Un REEI aide les personnes handicap√©es √† √©pargner pour assurer leur s√©curit√© financi√®re √† long terme. Chaque enregistrement est sp√©cifique au b√©n√©ficiaire, au contrat et √† l‚Äôann√©e. Les microdonn√©es contiennent des renseignements sur : les contributions que paie le titulaire ou le b√©n√©ficiaire dans un REEI; les subventions, qui sont un incitatif vers√© par le gouvernement du Canada dans un REEI, qui s‚Äôajoutent aux cotisations du titulaire ou du b√©n√©ficiaire ; les bons, qui sont vers√©s dans le REEI d‚Äôun b√©n√©ficiaire jug√© admissible et dont le revenu familial est inf√©rieur √† un seuil √©tabli ; les paiements d‚Äôaide √† l‚Äôinvalidit√© (PAI) ou les paiements viagers pour invalidit√© (PVI), qui sont des sommes retir√©es d‚Äôun REEI et vers√©es au b√©n√©ficiaire ou √† ses h√©ritiers. Les PAI sont des montants forfaitaires uniques. Les PVI sont des versements qui, une fois commenc√©s, sont payables au moins une fois par an jusqu‚Äôau d√©c√®s du b√©n√©ficiaire ou jusqu‚Äô√† la cessation du r√©gime.

Title: Vital Statistics - Stillbirth Database
Dataset Title (French): Statistique de l'√©tat civil - Base de donn√©es sur les mortinaissances
Summary: This is an administrative survey that collects demographic information annually from all provincial and territorial vital statistics registries on all stillbirths (fetal deaths) in Canada.
Summary French: Il s'agit d'une enqu√™te administrative con√ßue pour recueillir annuellement aupr√®s de tous les bureaux provinciaux et territoriaux de l'√©tat civil des renseignements d√©mographiques sur toutes les mortinaissances (morts foetales) survenues au Canada.
Subjects: Health|Population and demography
Content: This is an administrative survey that collects demographic information annually from all provincial and territorial vital statistics registries on all stillbirths (fetal deaths) in Canada. 2017 birth and stillbirth data for Yukon are not available. Due to improvements in methodology and timeliness, the duration of data collection has been shortened compared to previous years. As a result, there may have been fewer births and stillbirths captured by the time of the release. The 2017 data are therefore considered preliminary.

Title: Study on International Money Transfers
Dataset Title (French): √âtude sur les transferts de fonds internationaux
Summary:
The objective of this study is to collect information about international money transfers, from residents of Canada to their relatives or friends living outside Canada.

This study explores topics such as the various ways to send money, reasons for choosing one method over another, and the different uses of the money, as well as amounts transferred, fees and frequency of transferring money.

The results of this study will be used by Global Affairs Canada to help guide policies and programs with the goal of lowering the costs to send money outside Canada, and allow for safer, more reliable money transfers.
Summary French: L'objectif de cette √©tude est de recueillir des renseignements sur les transferts de fonds internationaux des r√©sidents du Canada √† des membres de la famille ou √† des amis habitant √† l'ext√©rieur du Canada. L'√©tude porte sur un √©ventail de sujets, dont les diff√©rents modes de transfert de fonds, les raisons de choisir un mode plut√¥t qu'un autre, le montant des fonds transf√©r√©s, les diff√©rentes utilisations pr√©vues des fonds, les frais associ√©s aux transferts, et la fr√©quence des transferts. Les r√©sultats de cette √©tude seront utilis√©s par Affaires mondiales Canada pour lui permettre d'orienter les politiques et les programmes en vue de r√©duire le co√ªt des transferts de fonds √† l'√©tranger, et d'accro√Ætre la s√©curit√© et la fiabilit√© des modes de transfert.
Subjects: Labour>Globalization and the labour market|Income, pensions, spending and wealth>Household, family and personal income|Children and youth>Immigrant children and youth|Immigration and ethnocultural diversity>Immigrants and non-permanent residents
Content:
The objective of this study is to collect information about international money transfers, from residents of Canada to their relatives or friends living outside Canada.

This study explores topics such as the various ways to send money, reasons for choosing one method over another, and the different uses of the money, as well as amounts transferred, fees and frequency of transferring money.

The results of this study will be used by Global Affairs Canada to help guide policies and programs with the goal of lowering the costs to send money outside Canada, and allow for safer, more reliable money transfers.

Title: Canadian Community Health Survey Linked to Vital Statistics - Discharge Abstracts - Ambulatory Care and Mental Health Records
Dataset Title (French): Base de donn√©es sur les d√©c√®s de la Statistique de l‚Äô√©tat civil - Base de donn√©es sur les cong√©s des patients - Syst√®me national d‚Äôinformation sur les soins ambulatoires - Syst√®me d‚Äôinformation ontarien sur la sant√© mentale - Enqu√™te sur la sant√© dans les collectivit√©s canadiennes
Summary:
Statistics Canada and the Canadian Institute for Health Information (CIHI) are pleased to announce the release of a linked data set that brings together data from both organizations. These linked data provide information that can be used for research on associations between behavioural, socio-economic and environmental factors, health outcomes and the use of hospital services. As part of its data integration activities, Statistics Canada has linked the Canadian Community Health Survey (CCHS) data from the Annual Component (2000-2017) and Focus Content Surveys (Mental Health 2002 and 2012, Nutrition 2004 and 2015, and Healthy Aging 2008/2009) with the Canadian Vital Statistics Death Database (CVSD) (2000-2017), the Discharge Abstract Database (DAD) (1999/00-2017/2018), the National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NACRS) (2002/03-2017/18), the Ontario Mental Health Reporting System (OMHRS) (2006/07-2017/18) and historical postal codes (2000-2016). CIHI is collaborating with Statistics Canada to make the linked data available in the Research Data Centers (RDC) and to support researchers using the file.

Please note that additional documentation is available for this survey. Please contact your RDC analyst to request this documentation.

Statistique Canada et¬†l‚ÄôInstitut canadien¬†d‚Äôinformation sur la sant√© (ICIS) sont heureux¬†d‚Äôannoncer la diffusion¬†d‚Äôun ensemble de donn√©es coupl√©es qui regroupe les donn√©es des deux organisations.¬†Ces donn√©es coupl√©es fournissent de¬†l‚Äôinformation qui peut √™tre utilis√©e √† des fins de recherche portant sur¬†l‚Äôassociation entre les facteurs comportementaux, socio√©conomiques et environnementaux de m√™me que les r√©sultats en mati√®re de sant√© et¬†l‚Äôutilisation des services hospitaliers. Dans le cadre de ses activit√©s¬†d‚Äôint√©gration de donn√©es, Statistique Canada a coupl√© les donn√©es de¬†l‚ÄôEnqu√™te sur la sant√© dans les collectivit√©s canadiennes (ESCC) de la composante annuelle (2000-2017) et des enqu√™tes √† contenu th√©matique (Sant√© mentale¬†2002 et 2012, Nutrition 2004 et 2015 et Vieillissement en sant√© 2008/2009) avec la Base canadienne de donn√©es sur les¬†d√©c√®s de la Statistique de¬†l‚Äô√©tat civil (BCDECD) (2000-2017), la Base de donn√©es sur les cong√©s des patients (BDCP) (1999/00-2017/2018), le Syst√®me national¬†d‚Äôinformation sur les soins ambulatoires (SNISA) (2002/03-2017/18), le Syst√®me¬†d‚Äôinformation ontarien sur la sant√© mentale (SIOSM) (2006/07-2017/18) et les codes postaux historiques (2000-2016).L‚ÄôICIS collabore avec Statistique Canada pour rendre les donn√©es coupl√©es accessibles dans les centres de donn√©es de recherche (CDR) et pour offrir un appui aux chercheurs qui utilisent le fichier.

Content:
Statistics Canada and the Canadian Institute for Health Information (CIHI) are pleased to announce the release of a linked data set that brings together data from both organizations. These linked data provide information that can be used for research on associations between behavioural, socio-economic and environmental factors, health outcomes and the use of hospital services.

 

As part of its data integration activities, Statistics Canada has linked the Canadian Community Health Survey (CCHS) data from the Annual Component (2000-2017) and Focus Content Surveys (Mental Health 2002 and 2012, Nutrition 2004 and 2015, and Healthy Aging 2008/2009) with the Canadian Vital Statistics Death Database (CVSD) (2000-2017), the Discharge Abstract Database (DAD) (1999/00-2017/2018), the National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NACRS) (2002/03-2017/18), the Ontario Mental Health Reporting System (OMHRS) (2006/07-2017/18) and historical postal codes (2000-2016). Title: Canadian Census Health & Environment Cohort linked to Discharge Abstract Data / National Ambulatory Care Reporting System
Dataset Title (French): Cohorte sant√© et environnement du recensement canadien coupl√©e √† la Base de donn√©es sur les cong√©s des patients / Syst√®me national d‚Äôinformation sur les soins ambulatoires
Summary:
The Canadian Census Health and Environment Cohort (CanCHEC) linked to DAD/NACRS is available in the RDC. Access is granted separately for each linkage. The Canadian Census Health and Environment Cohorts (CanCHEC) are population- based linked datasets that follow the non-institutional (household) population at time of census for different health outcomes such as mortality and cancer as well as annual postal codes.

The CanCHEC consists of a linkage between tax information, long-form census, and historic postal code data as well as mortality data and cancer registry data. The Discharge Abstract Database (DAD) is a national database for information on all separations from acute care institutions, including discharges, deaths, sign-outs and transfers, within a fiscal year (April 1 to March 31). Over time, the DAD has also been used to capture data on day surgery procedures, long-term care, rehabilitation and other types of care. Quebec does not submit data to the DAD. About 2.4 million day surgery abstracts are submitted to the Canadian Institute for Health Information (CIHI) annually; approximately 35% are sent to the DAD and 65% are sent to the National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NACRS). The National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NACRS) contains data for all hospital-based and community-based ambulatory care work Emergency departments Client visit data is collected at time of service in participating facilities.
Summary French:
La CERCan coupl√©e √† la base de donn√©es sur les cong√©s des patients ainsi que la syst√®me national d'information sur les soins ambulatoires est disponible dans le CDR. L'acc√®s est accord√© s√©par√©ment aux deux couplages.

La Cohorte sant√© et environnement du recensement canadien (CSERCan) est form√©e d‚Äôensembles de donn√©es coupl√©es bas√©s sur la population qui permettent de suivre, au moment du recensement, la population excluant les pensionnaires d‚Äô√©tablissements institutionnels (c.-√†-d. r√©sidant dans les m√©nages) au chapitre de diff√©rents r√©sultats en mati√®re de sant√©, comme la mortalit√© et le cancer ainsi que les codes postaux annuels.La Base de donn√©es sur les cong√©s des patients (BDCP) recueille des donn√©es administratives, cliniques et d√©mographiques sur les sorties des h√¥pitaux (y compris les d√©c√®s, les d√©parts volontaires et les transferts). Quelques provinces et territoires utilisent aussi la BDCP pour recueillir des donn√©es sur les chirurgies d‚Äôun jour. La BDCP contient des donn√©es d√©mographiques, administratives et cliniques sur toutes les sorties (√† l‚Äôexception des mortinaissances et des donneurs d√©c√©d√©s) provenant d‚Äô√©tablissements de soins de courte dur√©e pour patients hospitalis√©s dans l‚Äôensemble des provinces et territoires, √† l‚Äôexception du Qu√©bec.Le Syst√®me national d‚Äôinformation sur les soins ambulatoires (SNISA) comprend des donn√©es sur tous les soins ambulatoires en milieu hospitalier ou communautaire, y compris : la chirurgie d‚Äôun jour ; les cliniques communautaires et de consultation externe ; les services d‚Äôurgence. Les donn√©es sur les visites des clients sont recueillies lors de la prestation des services dans les √©tablissements participants.
Subjects: Indigenous peoples>Health and well-being|Health>Health care services
Content: The Canadian Census Health and Environment Cohort (CanCHEC) linked to DAD/NACRS is available in the RDC. Access is granted separately for each linkage. The Canadian Census Health and Environment Cohorts (CanCHEC) are population- based linked datasets that follow the non-institutional (household) population at time of census for different health outcomes such as mortality and cancer as well as annual postal codes. The CanCHEC consists of a linkage between tax information, long-form census, and historic postal code data as well as mortality data and cancer registry data. The Discharge Abstract Database (DAD) is a national database for information on all separations from acute care institutions, including discharges, deaths, sign-outs and transfers, within a fiscal year (April 1 to March 31). Over time, the DAD has also been used to capture data on day surgery procedures, long-term care, rehabilitation and other types of care. Quebec does not submit data to the DAD. About 2.4 million day surgery abstracts are submitted to the Canadian Institute for Health Information (CIHI) annually; approximately 35% are sent to the DAD and 65% are sent to the National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NACRS). The National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NACRS) contains data for all hospital-based and community-based ambulatory care work Emergency departments Client visit data is collected at time of service in participating facilities.

Summary: The B.C. Ministry of Education dataset provides student level information for students attending B.C.‚Äôs public and independent schools. The data includes information about student characteristics (gender, age, geographic location, etc.) and progress through the education system (graduation, Foundation Skills Assessment results, exam marks, etc.). The data is structured as one record per school year, student and school, such that most students will have one record (data row) per year. Students attending more than one school in a year have multiple records per year. Enrolment data is available from 1991 to present. Some supplementary data such as FSA scores are available in later years. B.C. K-12 data can be linked with other data within the Education and Labour Market Longitudinal Platform (ELMLP) such as: Postsecondary Student Information System (PSIS) and Registered Apprenticeship Information System (RAIS). These files must be added to the MRC. Please note that the Census 2016 must be added to the contract with BCK-12 linked to Census 2016 keys. Lastly, the B.C. Ministry of Education publishes reports and aggregate data on its website as well as through Open Data BC annually. Researchers are encouraged to visit these websites to confirm the values that are generated from this dataset and that they are structuring their queries correctly.

Title: Survey of Safety in Public and Private Spaces
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te sur la s√©curit√© dans les espaces publics et priv√©s
Summary: The purpose of this survey is to collect information on Canadians' experiences related to their safety in public and private spaces. Questions are asked about these personal experiences at home, in the workplace, in public spaces and online. All levels of government, academics and not-for-profit organizations have expressed interest in the SSPPS results in an effort to provide a more complete and inclusive picture of the realities of gender-based violence in Canada. To help end such violence, data from this survey will be used to inform the federal government's Strategy to Prevent and Address Gender-Based Violence. The data will assist with program and policy development decisions and support research in the field of gender-based violence. Additionally, some data will facilitate comparisons with international data sources.

Des questions sont pos√©es sur ces exp√©riences personnelles v√©cues √† la maison, dans le milieu de travail, dans des endroits publics et en ligne.Tous les ordres de gouvernement, les universitaires et les organismes sans but lucratif ont manifest√© de l'int√©r√™t pour les r√©sultats de l'ESEPP dans le but de fournir une image plus compl√®te et inclusive des r√©alit√©s de la violence fond√©e sur le sexe au Canada. Pour aider √† mettre fin √† cette violence, les donn√©es de cette enqu√™te serviront √† √©clairer le gouvernement f√©d√©ral dans sa Strat√©gie du Canada pour pr√©venir et contrer la violence fond√©e sur le sexe. Title: Travel Survey of Residents of Canada
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te sur les voyages des residents du Canada
Summary:
The TSRC is sponsored by Statistics Canada, Destination Canada, the provincial governments and municipal organizations of tourism. It measures the size of domestic travel in Canada from the demand side. The objectives of the survey are to provide information about the volume of trips and expenditures for Canadian residents by trip origin, destination, duration, type of accommodation used, trip reason, mode of travel, etc.; to provide information on travel incidence and to provide the socio-demographic profile of travellers and non-travellers. Estimates allow quarterly analysis at the national and provincial level (with varying degrees of precision) on:

- total volume of same-day and overnight trips taken by residents of Canada with destinations in Canada,

- same-day and overnight visits in Canada,

- main purpose of the trip/key activities on trip,

- spending on same-day and overnight trips taken in Canada by Canadian residents in total and by category of expenditure,

- modes of transportation (main/other) used on the trip,

- person-visits, household-visits, spending in total and by expense category for each location visited in Canada,

- person- and household-nights spent in each location visited in Canada, in total and by type of accommodation used,

- use of travel packages and associated spending and source of payment (household, government, private employer),

- demographics of adults that took or did not take trips, and

- travel party composition.
Summary French: L'EVRC est parrain√©e par Statistique Canada, Destination Canada, les gouvernements provinciaux et des organismes municipaux du tourisme. Elle mesure l'ampleur des voyages int√©rieurs au Canada, du point de vue de la demande. L'enqu√™te vise √† recueillir de l'information sur le volume de voyages et des d√©penses des r√©sidents du Canada selon l'origine du voyage, la destination, la dur√©e, le type d'h√©bergement utilis√©, le but du voyage, le moyen de transport, etc., √† recueillir de l'information sur l'incidence des voyages et fournir le profil sociod√©mographique des voyageurs et des non-voyageurs. Les estimations permettent d'effectuer des analyses sur une base trimestrielle √† l'√©chelle nationale et provinciale (√† divers degr√©s de pr√©cision) concernant les informations suivantes : - nombre total de voyages d'un m√™me jour et d'une nuit ou plus effectu√©s par les r√©sidents du Canada et dont la destination √©tait au Canada; - visites d'un m√™me jour et d'une nuit ou plus au Canada; - raison principale du voyage et activit√©s principales effectu√©es pendant le voyage; - d√©penses effectu√©es pour les voyages d'un m√™me jour et d'une nuit ou plus au Canada par les r√©sidents du Canada, au total et selon la cat√©gorie de d√©penses; - moyens de transport utilis√©s pendant le voyage (principal/autre); - visites-personnes, visites-m√©nages, d√©penses totales et par cat√©gorie de d√©penses pour chaque endroit visit√© au Canada; - nuit√©es-personnes et nuit√©es-m√©nages pass√©es √† chaque endroit visit√© au Canada, au total et selon le type d'h√©bergement utilis√©; - utilisation de forfaits de voyage et d√©penses qui y sont associ√©es et personne ou organisme ayant pay√© les co√ªts du voyage (m√©nage, gouvernement, employeur priv√©); - caract√©ristiques d√©mographiques des adultes qui ont effectu√© des voyages et ceux qui n'en n'ont pas effectu√©s; - composition du groupe des voyageurs.

Title: Canadian Perspectives Survey Series - COVID19
Dataset Title (French): S√©rie d'Enqu√™tes sur les Perspectives Canadiennes - COVID19
Summary:
The Canadian Perspectives Survey Series (CPSS) is a set of short, online surveys beginning in March 2020 that will be used to collect information on the knowledge and behaviours of residents of the 10 Canadian provinces. All surveys in the series will be asked of Statistics Canada‚Äôs probability panel. The probability panel for the CPSS is a new pilot project initiated in 2019. An important goal of the CPSS is to directly collect data from Canadians in a timely manner in order to inform policy makers and be responsive to emerging data needs. The CPSS is designed to assess the quality and viability of a more timely collection model using willing participants and web-only collection. CPSS is designed to produce data at a national level (excluding the territories).
  1. In 2020: From March 29 to April 3 2020, the first survey in the Canadian Perspecives Survey Series : Impacts of COVID-19. In order to implement this survey rapidly, it was conducted online only, among those who volunteered to participate in the Canadian Perspectives Survey Series (CPSS). This survey will be the first of the CPSS.
  2. From May 4 to May 10 2020, Canadian Perspectives Survey Series 2: Monitoring the Effects of COVID-19 (CPSS2). The CPSS2 covered a number of important topics including: the impacts of COVID-19 on food security and mental health of individuals, and on their social and employment circumstances.
  3. From June 15 to June 21, 2020, Canadian Perspectives Survey Series 3: Resuming economic and social activities during COVID-19 (CPSS3). This survey was the third wave of the CPSS. The CPSS3 covered Canadians' reactions and responses to the gradual reopening of economic and social activities during COVID-19.
  4. From July 20 to July 26 2020, Canadian Perspectives Survey Series 4: Information Sources Consulted During the Pandemic (CPSS4). This survey was the fourth wave of the CPSS. The CPSS4 covered a number of important topics including: the source and quality of COVID-19 information that Canadians are accessing, ongoing impacts of COVID-19 on the physical and mental health of individuals, and on their social and employment circumstances.
  5. From September 14 to September 20, 2020, Canadian Perspectives Survey Series 5: Technology use and cyber security during the pandemic (CPSS5). This survey was the fifth wave of the CPSS. The CPSS5 covered a number of important topics including technology use, cyber security practices and online spending during the pandemic.
  6. In 2021: From January 25 to January 31, Canadian Perspectives Survey Series 6: Substance Use and Stigma during the Pandemic.
Summary French:
La S√©rie d‚Äôenqu√™tes sur les perspectives canadiennes (SEPC) est un ensemble de courtes enqu√™tes en ligne men√©es √† compter de mars 2020 qui serviront √† recueillir, au cours de l‚Äôann√©e, des renseignements sur les connaissances et les comportements des r√©sidents des 10 provinces canadiennes. Les questions de toutes les enqu√™tes de la s√©rie seront pos√©es √† un panel probabiliste de Statistique Canada. L‚Äô√©chantillon probabiliste pour la SEPC est un nouveau projet pilote entrepris en 2019. Un but important de la SEPC est de recueillir, en temps utile, des donn√©es directement aupr√®s des Canadiens afin d‚Äô√©clairer les d√©cideurs politiques et de r√©pondre rapidement aux nouveaux besoins en donn√©es. La S√©rie d‚Äôenqu√™tes sur les perspectives canadiennes (SEPC) a √©t√© con√ßue pour √©valuer la qualit√© et la viabilit√© d‚Äôun mod√®le de collecte plus rapide reposant uniquement sur la participation volontaire et la collecte en ligne. La SEPC vise √† produire des donn√©es au niveau national (excluant les territoires).
  1. En 2020 : Du 29 mars au 3 avril, Statistique Canada a m√®n√© la premi√®re enqu√™te sur les r√©percussions de la COVID-19. Afin d'organiser la mise en place de cette enqu√™te rapidement, elle √©tait men√©e en ligne seulement aupr√®s des personnes qui se sont port√©es volontaires pour participer √† la S√©rie d'enqu√™tes sur les perspectives canadiennes (SEPC).
  2. Du 4 mai au 10 mai, la S√©rie d‚Äôenqu√™tes sur les perspectives canadiennes 2 : Suivi des effets de la COVID-19 (SEPC2). La SEPC2 a port√© sur un certain nombre de sujets importants, dont les r√©percussions de la COVID-19 sur la s√©curit√© alimentaire et la sant√© mentale des personnes ainsi que sur leur situation sociale et d'emploi.
  3. Du 15 au 21 juin, la S√©rie d‚Äôenqu√™tes sur les perspectives canadiennes 3 : Reprise des activit√©s √©conomiques et sociales pendant la COVID-19 (SEPC3). C‚Äôest la troisi√®me vague d‚Äôenqu√™te de la SEPC. La SEPC3 a abord√© les r√©actions et r√©ponses des Canadiens √† la r√©ouverture graduelle de l‚Äô√©conomie et des activit√©s sociales durant la pand√©mie de COVID-19.
  4. Du 20 juillet au 26 juillet, la S√©rie d‚Äôenqu√™tes sur les perspectives canadiennes 4 : Les sources d‚Äôinformation consult√©es pendant la pand√©mie (SEPC4). C‚Äôest la quatri√®me vague d‚Äôenqu√™te de la SEPC. La SEPC4 a port√© sur un certain nombre de sujets importants dont la source et de la qualit√© de l'information sur la COVID-19 que consulte la population canadienne. Il sera √©galement question de l'incidence continue de la pand√©mie sur la sant√© physique et mentale des personnes, ainsi que sur leur situation sociale et professionnelle.
  5. Du 14 septembre au 20 septembre, la S√©rie d‚Äôenqu√™tes sur les perspectives canadiennes 5 : Usage de la technologie et cybers√©curit√© pendant la pand√©mie (SEPC5). C‚Äôest la cinqui√®me vague d‚Äôenqu√™te de la SEPC. La SEPC5 a port√© sur un certain nombre de sujets importants, dont l'usage de la technologie, les pratiques de cybers√©curit√© et les achats en ligne au cours de la pand√©mie.
  6. En 2021: Du 25 janvier au 31 janvier, la S√©rie d'enqu√™tes sur les perspectives canadiennes 6:Consommation d‚Äôalcool ou de drogues et stigmatisation pendant la pand√©mie.

Title: Canadian Housing Survey
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te Canadienne sur le Logement
Summary:
The CHS provides information on how Canadians feel about their housing and how housing affects them. Information is collected on core housing need, dwelling characteristics and housing tenure, perceptions on economic hardship from housing costs, dwelling and neighbourhood satisfaction, perceptions on neighbourhood issues and safety, housing moves and intentions to move, volunteering, community engagement, life satisfaction, community satisfaction, dwelling adaptations to improve accessibility, self-assessed health, experience with homelessness, and socio-demographic characteristics. Under the umbrella of the 2018 Canadian Housing Survey (CHS), a suite of files is now available and can be accessed by researchers with approved projects.

These files are the outcome of a number of social inclusion related projects supported by the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation. They were conducted to enhance the CHS and support the National Housing Strategy. These new projects produced a Proximity Measures Database, indicators of neighbourhood income mixing (Income dispersion), a social inclusion index Detailed documentation describing the index will be available soon. In the interim, users should contact CISWS with any questions. , and spatial mobility data based on historical addresses. The Proximity Measures Database provides information on what access Canadians have, within a given distance of their dwelling, to services and amenities including transit, health services, schools and parks. The indicators of neighbourhood income mixing are designed to measure the diversity of income levels across neighbourhoods and multi-unit apartment buildings. The Social Inclusion Index measures how satisfied Canadian households are with their dwellings and neighbourhoods; how much they feel part of their community; as well as how safe and financially secure they feel. Historical data on the spatial mobility project can be used to study housing transitions.

This suite of files also includes income information from T4 tax Files, the T1 Family Files (T1FF), Historical addresses, Income dispersion, and the Administrative Personal Income Masterfile (APIM).
Summary French:
L'ECL fournit des renseignements sur la perception qu'ont les Canadiens de leur logement et sur la mani√®re dont le logement les affecte. Des renseignements sont recueillis sur les besoins imp√©rieux en mati√®re de logement, les caract√©ristiques du logement et le mode d'occupation du logement, les perceptions des difficult√©s √©conomiques associ√©es au co√ªt du logement, la satisfaction √† l'√©gard du quartier et du logement, les perceptions des probl√®mes li√©s au quartier et de la s√©curit√© du quartier, les d√©m√©nagements ou les intentions de d√©m√©nager, le b√©n√©volat, l'engagement communautaire, la satisfaction √† l'√©gard de la vie, la satisfaction √† l'√©gard de la communaut√©, les adaptations apport√©es au logement pour accro√Ætre l'accessibilit√©, la sant√© auto√©valu√©e, l'exp√©rience en mati√®re d'itin√©rance et les caract√©ristiques sociod√©mographiques. Une s√©rie de fichiers cr√©√©e dans le cadre de l‚ÄôEnqu√™te canadienne sur le logement (ECL) de 2018 est maintenant disponible, et les chercheurs dont les projets sont approuv√©s peuvent y acc√©der.

Les fichiers sont le r√©sultat d‚Äôun certain nombre de projets li√©s √† l‚Äôinclusion sociale appuy√©s par la Soci√©t√© canadienne d‚Äôhypoth√®ques et de logement. Ces nouveaux projets ont √©t√© men√©s afin d‚Äôam√©liorer l‚ÄôECL et de soutenir la Strat√©gie nationale sur le logement. Ils ont permis de produire la Base de donn√©es des mesures de proximit√©, des indicateurs de la diversit√© des revenus du quartier (dispersion des revenus), un indice de l‚Äôinclusion sociale11 De la documentation d√©taill√©e d√©crivant l‚Äôindice sera bient√¥t disponible. Entre-temps, les utilisateurs qui ont des questions doivent communiquer avec le CSRBS., et des donn√©es sur la mobilit√© spatiale fond√©es sur des adresses historiques. La Base de donn√©es des mesures de proximit√© fournit des renseignements sur l‚Äôacc√®s qu‚Äôont les Canadiens, √† une distance donn√©e de leur logement, √† des services et √† des commodit√©s, y compris les transports en commun, les services de sant√©, les √©coles et les parcs. Les indicateurs de la diversit√© des revenus du quartier visent √† mesurer la diversit√© des niveaux de revenu pour tous les quartiers et les grands immeubles d‚Äôappartements. L‚Äôindice de l‚Äôinclusion sociale mesure la satisfaction des m√©nages canadiens √† l‚Äô√©gard de leur logement et de leur quartier, leur sentiment d‚Äôinclusion dans leur communaut√©, ainsi que leur sentiment de s√©curit√© personnelle et financi√®re. Les donn√©es historiques sur le projet de mobilit√© spatiale peuvent servir √† √©tudier les transitions en mati√®re de logement.La s√©rie de fichiers comprend √©galement des renseignements sur le revenu de fichiers fiscaux T4, du Fichier des familles (FFT1), adresses historiques, dispersion des revenus, et du Fichier administratif principal du revenu personnel (FAPRP).L‚ÄôECL fournit des renseignements sur la perception qu‚Äôont les Canadiens de leur logement et sur la mani√®re dont le logement les touche.

Des renseignements sont recueillis sur les besoins imp√©rieux en mati√®re de logement, les caract√©ristiques du logement et le mode d‚Äôoccupation du logement, les perceptions des difficult√©s √©conomiques associ√©es au co√ªt du logement, la satisfaction √† l‚Äô√©gard du quartier et du logement, les perceptions des probl√®mes li√©s au quartier et de la s√©curit√© du quartier, les d√©m√©nagements ou les intentions de d√©m√©nager, le b√©n√©volat, l‚Äôengagement communautaire, la satisfaction √† l‚Äô√©gard de la vie, la satisfaction √† l‚Äô√©gard de la communaut√©, les adaptations apport√©es au logement pour accro√Ætre l‚Äôaccessibilit√©, la sant√© auto√©valu√©e, l‚Äôexp√©rience en mati√®re d‚Äôitin√©rance, et les caract√©ristiques sociod√©mographiques.
Subjects: Population and demography>Census counts>Families, households and marital status>Families|Families, households and marital status|Housing
Content:
The CHS provides information on how Canadians feel about their housing and how housing affects them. Information is collected on core housing need, dwelling characteristics and housing tenure, perceptions on economic hardship from housing costs, dwelling and neighbourhood satisfaction, perceptions on neighbourhood issues and safety, housing moves and intentions to move, volunteering, community engagement, life satisfaction, community satisfaction, dwelling adaptations to improve accessibility, self-assessed health, experience with homelessness, and socio-demographic characteristics. Under the umbrella of the 2018 Canadian Housing Survey (CHS), a suite of files is now available and can be accessed by researchers with approved projects.

These files are the outcome of a number of social inclusion related projects supported by the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation. They were conducted to enhance the CHS and support the National Housing Strategy. These new projects produced a Proximity Measures Database, indicators of neighbourhood income mixing (Income dispersion), a social inclusion index Detailed documentation describing the index will be available soon. In the interim, users should contact CISWS with any questions. , and spatial mobility data based on historical addresses. The Proximity Measures Database provides information on what access Canadians have, within a given distance of their dwelling, to services and amenities including transit, health services, schools and parks. The indicators of neighbourhood income mixing are designed to measure the diversity of income levels across neighbourhoods and multi-unit apartment buildings. The Social Inclusion Index measures how satisfied Canadian households are with their dwellings and neighbourhoods; how much they feel part of their community; as well as how safe and financially secure they feel. Historical data on the spatial mobility project can be used to study housing transitions.

This suite of files also includes income information from T4 tax Files, the T1 Family Files (T1FF) and the Administrative Personal Income Masterfile (APIM).

Title: Longitudinal Administrative Databank - Discharge Administrative Databank linkage
Dataset Title (French): Longitudinal Administrative Databank - Discharge Administrative Databank linkage
Summary: As part of its record data linkage activities, Statistics Canada has created a new linkage key that allows RDC users to link the Longitudinal Administrative Database (LAD) with patient records in the Discharge Abstract Database (DAD). The integration of LAD data which represents 20% of Canadian tax filers with provincial administrative data held by CIHI creates a valuable dataset that can provide answers to important research questions that cannot be found in single administrative datasets alone.

Title: Canadian Armed Forces Health Survey
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te sur la sant√© dans les Forces arm√©es canadiennes
Summary: Canadian Armed Forces Health Survey (CAFHS) is a cross-sectional survey that collects data in order to provide insight into the current health status of Canadian Armed Forces (CAF) members. The CAFHS is a continuation of a Department of National Defence (DND) survey called the Health and Lifestyle Information Survey (HLIS). The HLIS was a population-based health survey conducted every four to five years by DND-CAF. The HLIS 2013/14 was the fourth survey cycle conducted. Afterwards DND-CAF contracted Statistics Canada to develop and conduct the CAFHS.

Par la suite, le MDN-FAC a retenu les services de Statistique Canada pour √©laborer et r√©aliser l‚ÄôESFAC.

Title: Survey on Individual Safety in the Postsecondary Student Population
Dataset Title (French): Survey on Individual Safety in the Postsecondary Student Population
Summary: The Survey on Individual Safety was conducted by Statistics Canada on behalf of the Department of Wage and Gender Equality. The Royal Military college component was conducted on behalf of the Canadian Armed Forces (CAF). The purpose of the Survey on Individual Safety in the Postsecondary Student Population (SISPSP) is to collect information on the prevalence, nature and impact of inappropriate sexual behaviours, sexual assault and discrimination based on sex, sexual orientation, or gender identity in a school-related setting. Students‚Äô attitudes regarding information about policies, procedures and services provided by postsecondary schools will also be collected. The purpose of the Survey on Individual Safety in the Postsecondary Student Population ‚Äì Canadian Military Colleges (SISPSP-CMC) is to collect information on the prevalence, nature and impact of inappropriate sexual behaviours, sexual assault and discrimination based on sex, sexual orientation, or gender identity in a Royal Military College (RMC) related setting. Students‚Äô attitudes regarding information about policies, procedures and services provided by RMC will also be collected. Access is granted separately for SISPSP and SISPSP-CMC.

Elle permet √©galement de recueillir des renseignements sur les attitudes des √©tudiants √† l‚Äô√©gard de l‚Äôinformation sur les politiques, les proc√©dures et les services fournis par les CMR.Un acc√®s distinct est accord√© au fichier ESIPEP et au fichier ESIPEP-CMC.

Title: Canadian Survey on Disability linked to Census Housing Data
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te canadienne sur l'incapacit√© coupl√© aux donn√©es sur le logement du recensement
Summary: Custom data files were created by Statistics Canada in partnership with Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation (CMHC). These files involve customized housing-related data from the 2016 Census of Population for persons who were part of the 2017 Canadian Survey on Disability (CSD) population groups (involving both persons with disabilities and persons without disabilities). The files are intended to be used in conjunction with the complete set of 2017 CSD Analytical Data Files. The files are being made available to researchers through Research Data Centers (RDCs) across Canada. The CMHC data sets link the 2017 CSD records with selected housing-related data from the 2016 Census to provide 16 new variables of special interest to CMHC researchers. In order to facilitate more in-depth analysis of the rich existing CSD datasets, which already include almost 300 linked census variables, the CMHC files link 10 additional census variables and six new custom derived variables (DVs) created by regrouping or combining answers from one or more questions on the 2016 Census long-form questionnaire. Researchers do need to request and be approved for access to: CEN_REC_Housing_CSD_17 file; and CSD 2017

Title: Canada Emergency Response Benefit
Dataset Title (French): Prestation canadienne d'urgence
Summary:
Included in this initial release are data on the amounts received under the Canada Emergency Response Benefit (CERB) program. The dataset covers payments made for the weeks starting March 15 to September 20, 2020. The release of this data will allow for research and analysis on the participation in the program and the distribution of benefits according to different characteristics of the recipients. For more information on the emergency and recovery benefits, please consult the Emergency Benefits page. New analytical files featuring information on the Emergency and Recovery Benefits (ERB) recipients‚Äô records combined with administrative, census and survey data. The available microdata contains de-identified client-level administrative information such as the amount of benefits received and the number of weeks of receiving benefits from the following ERB programs:
  • Canada Emergency Response Benefit (CERB) ‚Äì March 2020 to September 2020
  • Canada Recovery Benefit (CRB) ‚Äì September 2020 to October 2021
  • Canada Recovery Sickness Benefit (CRSB) ‚Äì September 2020 to May 2022
  • Canada Recovery Caregiver Benefit (CRCB) ‚Äì September 2020 to May 2022
The following tax-derived and geographical variables are also available for the recipient and non-recipient population:
  • Income class;
  • NAICS industry code, employer size class;
  • Age, sex, disability status, marital status, presence of children; and
  • Geographical location
If required for approved analytical projects, subsequent linkage keys would allow mapping of the Emergency and Recovery Benefits records as described above to only one other type of data source at a time among the following:
  • Census: 2016 Census of Population Long Form, which collects information on the demographic, social and economic situation of people across Canada, and the dwellings they live in;
  • Canadian Survey on Disability: A national survey that collects information about the lived experiences of youth and adults whose everyday activities may be limited due to a long-term condition or health-related problem;
  • Canadian Income Survey: A survey that provides information on the income and income sources of Canadians, along with their individual and household characteristics;
  • Labour Force Survey: A monthly survey which measures the current state of the Canadian labour market and is used, among other things, to calculate the national, provincial, territorial and regional employment and unemployment rates;
  • Longitudinal Immigration Database: A database that provides detailed and reliable information on socioeconomic outcomes of immigrants after their admission, such as employment income and mobility
Summary French:
Les donn√©es sur les montants re√ßus dans le cadre du programme de la Prestation canadienne d‚Äôurgence (PCU) figurent dans cette diffusion initiale. L‚Äôensemble de donn√©es couvre les paiements vers√©s pendant les semaines allant du¬†15¬†mars au¬†20¬†septembre¬†2020. La diffusion de ces donn√©es permettra de mener des recherches et des analyses sur la participation au programme et la distribution des prestations selon les diff√©rentes caract√©ristiques des b√©n√©ficiaires. Pour obtenir plus de renseignements sur les prestations d‚Äôurgence et de relance √©conomique, veuillez consulter le site Canada.ca au lien suivant¬†:¬†https://www.canada.ca/fr/services/prestations/covid-19-prestations-urgence.html. Les futures versions de ce fichier pourraient comprendre des programmes suppl√©mentaires √† mesure que Statistique Canada aura acc√®s aux donn√©es. De nouveaux fichiers analytiques contenant des renseignements sur les dossiers des b√©n√©ficiaires des Prestations d‚Äôurgence et de la relance √©conomique, combin√©s aux donn√©es administratives, de recensement et d‚Äôenqu√™te. Les microdonn√©es diffus√©es contiennent des renseignements administratifs d√©personnalis√©s au niveau du client, comme le montant des prestations re√ßues et le nombre de semaines pendant lesquelles le client a re√ßu des prestations des programmes de Prestations d‚Äôurgence et de la relance √©conomique suivants :
  • Prestation canadienne d‚Äôurgence ‚Äî de mars 2020 √† septembre 2020
  • Prestation canadienne de la relance √©conomique ‚Äî de septembre 2020 √† octobre 2021
  • Prestation canadienne de maladie pour la relance √©conomique ‚Äî de septembre 2020 √† mai 2022
  • Prestation canadienne de la relance √©conomique pour les proches aidants ‚Äî de septembre 2020 √† mai 2022
Les variables fiscales et g√©ographiques suivantes sont √©galement disponibles pour les b√©n√©ficiaires et les non-b√©n√©ficiaires :

  • L‚Äô√¢ge, le sexe, la situation vis-√†-vis de l‚Äôincapacit√©, l‚Äô√©tat matrimonial, la pr√©sence d‚Äôenfants; et
  • L‚Äôemplacement g√©ographique.
Si n√©cessaire, pour les projets analytiques approuv√©s, des cl√©s de couplage subs√©quentes permettraient de mettre en correspondance les dossiers de prestations d‚Äôurgence et de relance d√©crits ci-dessus avec un seul autre type de source de donn√©es √† la fois, parmi les suivants :
  • Recensement : le questionnaire d√©taill√© du Recensement de la population de 2016, qui a recueilli des renseignements sur la situation d√©mographique, sociale et √©conomique des personnes qui vivent au Canada, ainsi que sur les logements dans lesquels elles habitent.
  • Enqu√™te canadienne sur l‚Äôincapacit√© : une enqu√™te nationale qui recueille des renseignements sur les exp√©riences des jeunes et des adultes, dont les activit√©s quotidiennes sont limit√©es en raison d‚Äôun √©tat ou d‚Äôun probl√®me de sant√© √† long terme.
  • Enqu√™te canadienne sur le revenu : une enqu√™te qui fournit des renseignements sur le revenu et les sources de revenu des Canadiens, de m√™me que sur leurs caract√©ristiques personnelles et celles de leur m√©nage.
  • Enqu√™te sur la population active : une enqu√™te mensuelle qui mesure l‚Äô√©tat actuel du march√© du travail canadien et qui est employ√©e, entre autres, pour calculer les taux d‚Äôemploi et de ch√¥mage √† l‚Äô√©chelle nationale, provinciale, territoriale et r√©gionale.
  • Base de donn√©es longitudinales sur les immigrants : une base de donn√©es qui fournit des renseignements d√©taill√©s et fiables sur la situation socio√©conomique des immigrants apr√®s leur admission, tels que le revenu d‚Äôemploi et la mobilit√©.

For more information on the emergency and recovery benefits, please consult Canada.ca at: https://www.canada.ca/en/services/benefits/covid19-emergency-benefits.html.
Future versions of this file may include additional programs as data become available to Statistics Canada.

Title: Linkage of Socioeconomic and Treatment Data to the Canadian Cancer Registry

Summary:
Statistics Canada has linked the patient records in the Canadian Cancer Registry (CCR) (1992-2015) with the Discharge Abstract Database (DAD) (1994 to 2015/2016), the National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NACRS) (2002/2003 to 2015/2016), the Canadian Vital Statistics Death Database (CVSD) (1992-2014), the Longitudinal Immigration Database (IMDB) (1982-2015), the T1 Family File (T1FF) (1992-2015) and the 2016 Census (long form). The linked data can be used to support research on the relationship between cancer diagnoses, surgical treatment(s), and socioeconomic factors as well as provide information that could help support policy and decision-making for the various stakeholders involved in the delivery of cancer care in Canada.

The linkage contains the following datasets and observes only patients with a Cancer diagnosis who survived to take the census in 2016 : CCR to Census 2016 (long form) concordance files Two set of concordance files are provided. One contains the CCR and Census identifiers only. The other contains the same set of identifiers as well as adjusted Census weights (both frequency weights and replicated weights). CCR to IMDB concordance file. CCR to T1FF (T1FF fields only) CCR to CVSD (CVSD fields only) CCR to DAD (DAD fields only) CCR to NACRS (NACRS fields only).

It is strongly advised that researchers contact their analyst to obtain documentation for this dataset to ensure it is suitable for their research.

This linkage was previously known as the CPAC linkage project.

Title: Canadian Survey on Disability linked to T1 Family File
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te canadienne sur l'incapacit√© - fichier des familles T1
Summary:
This file involves a customized selection of income data from the 2015-2017 T1 Family File (T1FF), T1 Personal Master File (T1PMF) and the 2017 Canadian Survey on Disability (CSD) population groups (involving both persons with disabilities and persons without disabilities). This file is intended to be used in conjunction with the complete set of 2017 CSD Analytical Data Files. The T1FF custom data file links the 2017 CSD records with selected income related data from the T1FF and T1PMF to provide 77 new variables of special interest to Finance Canada researchers. In order to facilitate more in-depth analysis of the rich existing CSD datasets, which already include almost 300 linked census variables.

A separate project created a customized selection of income data from the 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021 and 2022 T1 Family File (T1FF), and the 2022 Canadian Survey on Disability (CSD) population groups (involving both persons with disabilities and persons without disabilities). Title: Survey of Digital Technology and Internet Use

Summary: The Survey of Digital Technology and Internet Use (SDTIU) is designed to measure the impact of digital technologies on the operations of Canadian enterprises. The information gathered helps to better understand how enterprises use the Internet, including their online presence, involvement in e-commerce, use of specific information and communication technologies (ICTs) and interaction with federal government online services. The survey also examines skills and employment in ICT-related jobs. The data from this survey are used by government departments to develop policies and programs that help improve Canada's innovation system and strengthen the overall economy.

Title: Canadian Tobacco and Nicotine Survey

In 2019, the Canadian Alcohol and Drugs Survey (CADS) was conducted to collect data on alcohol and drug use independently from the Canadian Tobacco and Nicotine Survey (CTNS) which was conducted to primarily collect data on tobacco and nicotine.

Title: Canadian Health Measures Survey
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te canadienne sur les mesures de la sant√©
Summary:
The Canadian Health Measures Survey (CHMS) is an ongoing, national survey administered by Statistics Canada in partnership with Health Canada and the Public Health Agency of Canada.The survey collects important health information to create national baseline data on the extent of major health concerns. Launched in 2007, the CHMS collects information through household interviews and by means of direct physical measurements such as blood pressure, height, weight and physical fitness. In addition, the survey is collecting blood and urine samples as well as DNA sample from consenting participants.

Biobank Data results from analysis of the biosamples will be made available to researchers at Statistics Canada's Research Data Centres. Only aggregate statistical outputs conforming to the confidentiality provisions of the Statistics Act will be released.

Please note that additional documentation is available for this survey. Please contact your RDC analyst to request this documentation.

Biobanque Les donn√©es produites √† partir des analyses des √©chantillons biologiques seront mises √† la disposition des chercheurs dans les centres de donn√©es de recherche de Statistique Canada. Seuls des produits statistiques agr√©g√©s respectant les dispositions de la Loi sur la statistique en mati√®re de confidentialit√© seront diffus√©s

Notez que la documentation suppl√©mentaire est disponible pour cette enqu√™te. Veuillez contacter votre analyste du CDR pour demander cette documentation.

Title: Canadian Housing Statistics Program
Dataset Title (French): Programme de la statistique du logement canadien
Summary: Statistics Canada was mandated to create a residential property database: a comprehensive repository of data that covers numerous aspects of the housing sector. The database, under the responsibility of the Canadian Housing Statistics Program (CHSP), will ultimately include all residential properties in Canada and their owners. The CHSP residential property database was developed by combining data from multiple sources (e.g., property assessment rolls, land titles, Census of Population, etc.) and provides detailed information at the property and owner levels. The database, initialized in 2017, continues to be expanded with new geographies and variables and is expected to contain information for all properties in every census subdivision nationwide by December 2022

La base de donn√©es des propri√©t√©s r√©sidentielles du PSLC a √©t√© cr√©√©e √† partir de donn√©es tir√©es de sources multiples (p. ex. r√¥les d'√©valuation fonci√®re, titres fonciers, Recensement de la population, etc.), et elle fournit des renseignements d√©taill√©s sur les propri√©t√©s ainsi que sur leurs propri√©taires. La base de donn√©es, lanc√©e en 2017, continue de s'√©largir gr√¢ce √† l'ajout de nouvelles r√©gions et de nouvelles variables, et elle devrait contenir des renseignements sur toutes les propri√©t√©s de chaque subdivision de recensement √† l'√©chelle du pays d'ici d√©cembre 2022.

Title: British-Columbia Income Assistance - Income Tax Administrative Files
Dataset Title (French): Soutien au revenu de la Colombie Britannique - Fichier administratifs sur l'imposition des revenues
Summary: The British Columbia Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction, as part of research into basic income in the context of BC‚Äôs current income support system has supplied a dataset featuring monthly income support usage patterns for cases and persons who are members of the affected family units. A linkage between British Columbia‚Äôs Employment and Assistance data to various administrative files has been created that features select elements from the T1 Income Tax and Benefit return as well as summaries of the T4, T4E and T5007 slips issued over the period. This dataset, devoid of any personal identifiers, should permit the analysis of trajectories into and out of income support programs to further a better understanding and improvements to assistance policies or programs.

Title: Canadian Food Environment Database
Dataset Title (French): Base de donn√©es sur l'environnement alimentaire canadien
Summary: The Canadian Food Environment Dataset (Can-FED) is a geographic-based set of measures that represents the food environment of Canadian communities. The primary envisioned use of the Can-FED is research and analysis of the relationship between the local food environment, dietary intake and health outcomes. By using geography conversion tools such as the Postal Code Conversion File (PCCF+),(5)it is possible to link Can-FED measures to individual-level health data from national-level survey platforms (e.g., the Canadian Health Measures Survey and the Canadian Community Health Survey) or to investigator-led cohorts. A diversity of food categories was chosen to represent an inclusive set of different and overarching food outlet types, such as healthy food retailers (e.g., supermarkets, grocery stores), convenient food options (e.g., corner stores, fast-food outlets), and independent and specialty retailers (e.g., bakeries, fish markets, coffee shops), amongst other options.

Content: The Canadian Food Environment Dataset (Can-FED) is a geographic-based set of measures that represents the food environment of Canadian communities. The primary envisioned use of the Can-FED is research and analysis of the relationship between the local food environment, dietary intake and health outcomes. Title: Portrait of Canadian Society
Dataset Title (French): Portrait de la soci√©t√© Canadienne
Summary: The survey series Portrait of Canadian Society (PCS) is a new Statistics Canada initiative. It is a probabilistic web panel that involves asking the same group of participants to complete four brief online surveys over a one-year period. For now, this is an experimental project which is part of a larger effort to modernize our data collection methods and activities. The goal is to collect important data on Canadian society more efficiently, more rapidly and at a lower cost compared to traditional survey methods. We will be able to test this collection method and refine it over time. Each survey in the series is administered to a sub-sample of General Social Survey - Social Identity (GSS-SI) respondents who agreed to participate in additional surveys when completing the GSS-SI. Wave 1 - "Life During the Pandemic" explore Canadians‚Äô perceptions of various facets of life including home and work life, leisure and well-being. Wave 2 was titled "Experiences During the Pandemic", and Wave 3, "Impacts of Rising Prices".

Summary: The major objectives of the Canadian Alcohol and Drugs Survey are to: measure frequency of alcohol use, measure frequency of cannabis use, measure frequency of use of other drugs and measure potential harmful effects of alcohol, cannabis and other drugs. Up until 2017, Statistics Canada conducted the Canadian Tobacco, Alcohol and Drugs Survey (CTADS), which collected data on tobacco as well as alcohol and drugs. The Canadian Tobacco and Nicotine Survey (CTNS) has been conducted as a separate survey to collect data on tobacco and nicotine.

Title: Survey on Accessibility in Federal Sector Organizations¬†
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te sur l'accessibilit√© dans les organisations du secteur public
Summary: The SAFSO gathers information about barriers related to accessibility for Canadians aged 15 and older whose daily activities are limited due to a disability, long-term condition or health-related problem. Information from the SAFSO may be used by all levels of government, as well as associations for persons with disabilities and researchers working in the field of disability. Data may be used to plan and evaluate policies and programs for Canadians with disabilities to help enable their full participation in society. In particular, information on adults with disabilities is essential for the effective development and operation of the Legislated Employment Equity Program and to measure progress under the Accessible Canada Act. Data on disability are also used to fulfill Canada's international agreement relating to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The survey is sponsored by Employment and Social Development Canada (ESDC). The survey collects information on barriers experienced within the federal sector related to transportation, information and communication technologies (ICT), and communication.

Title: Mother Centric Linkages
Dataset Title (French): Liaisons centr√©s sur les m√®res
Summary: The recently established Social Data Linkage Environment (SDLE) provided a novel and effective tool to conduct a mother-centric linkage, leveraging the Derived Record Depository (DRD) that stored a collection of personal identifiers from tax records, vital statistics registration records (births and deaths), and immigration data and so forth. Through internal linkage in the SDLE, a cohort of mothers (Mothers File) was created using information from the Canadian Vital Statistics Birth Database (CVSB) and the Canadian Vital Statistics Stillbirth Database (CVSS). The Mothers File was then linked to data from the immigration, hospitalization. This integration added rich immigration and health services utilization information to the Mothers File such as immigration status, education at admission, income for immigrants, and hospital admission and discharge, etc. This data integration also provided the first comprehensive longitudinal database of Mothers and Infants in Canada, which significantly expands the analytical capacity.

Cette int√©gration a ajout√© de riches renseignements sur l‚Äôimmigration et l‚Äôutilisation des services de sant√© au fichier sur les m√®res, tels que le statut d‚Äôimmigration, le niveau de scolarit√© √† l‚Äôadmission, le revenu des immigrants, ainsi que les admissions √† l‚Äôh√¥pital et les cong√©s des patients, etc. Cette int√©gration de donn√©es a √©galement fourni la premi√®re base de donn√©es longitudinales compl√®te sur les m√®res et les nouveau-n√©s au Canada, ce qui accro√Æt de mani√®re significative la capacit√© analytique et ajoute des renseignements pertinents en mati√®re de sant√© p√©rinatale.

Title: Canadian Legal Problems Survey
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te canadienne sur les probl√®mes juridiques
Summary: The Canadian Legal Problems Survey (CLPS) collects information on serious disputes or problems, which may or may not require legal help, Canadians have encountered and the impacts on their lives. Topics covered in the survey include the identification of the types of serious problems experienced, the relationship between those problems, actions taken to resolve or try to resolve the problems, access to legal help, costs associated with the legal problems, the level of understanding of the legal implications of the problems, the evolution and status of the problems, the impacts of the problems on their life including health, family and work. The survey aims to gather information that will help governments better understand the characteristics and mechanisms involved in those situations, evaluate Canadian's access to legal help and costs associated with legal issues. The survey results will inform the development of tools and measures to support Canadians experiencing legal issues and will be used in the evaluation of federal contributions to civil legal aid. In addition, the information will be used to inform and develop programs to address Canadians' legal needs and problems, such as supporting community justice centres, enhancing legal literacy and other people-centred approaches to access to justice.

De plus, l'information servira √† orienter et √† √©laborer des programmes qui r√©pondront aux besoins juridiques des Canadiens et les aideront √† r√©soudre leurs probl√®mes juridiques, par exemple, par le soutien des centres juridiques communautaires, l'am√©lioration de la litt√©ratie juridique et l'adoption d'autres approches ax√©es sur la personne en mati√®re d'acc√®s √† la justice.

Title: Canadian Social Survey

Summary:
The Canadian Social Survey (CSS) will collect information on a variety of social topics such as health, well-being, impacts of COVID-19, activities, time-use, and emergency preparedness. The CSS will provide data at the national level (excluding the territories). This information may be used by all levels of government and various organizations, to inform the delivery of services and supports for Canadians during and after the pandemic, and to guide policy development on a range of social and economic issues. When working with multiple waves on the same topic ensure you are aware of changes made to the questionnaires between waves.

The topics for the CSS, by year, are:

  • Quality of Life, Health and Impacts of Rising Prices
  • Quality of life, renter experiences and trust
  • Quality of life, virtual health care and trust
  • Quality of life and energy use
2020-2022:
  • Covid 19 and well-being
  • Quality of life and cost of living
  • Well-being, activities and perception of time
  • Well-being and caregiving
  • Well-being and family relationships
  • Well-being, shared values and trust
  • Well-being, unpaid work and family time

Title: Hate Crime Policing Incident Profile
Dataset Title (French): Profils d'intervention polici√®res dans le cadre de crimes motiv√©s par la haine
Summary: The Hate Crime Policing Incident Profile (HCPIP) files are the first set of files produced for this Canadian-Sweden Research Collaboration on Organized Violent Threats. To develop the HCPIP files, which identify a cohort of individuals that were involved in police-reported hate crime incidents that occurred between 2011 and 2018, incidents from the Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) survey were flagged using the hate crime indicator. Unique person identifiers were then created to identify individuals involved in crimes and then all previous and subsequent police-reported incidents of those involved in hate crimes were included. Subsequently, using available postal code information mapped to standard dissemination area (DA) codes, the files were supplemented with the Canadian Index of Multiple Deprivation (CIMD).

Des identificateurs uniques de chaque affaire ont √©t√© √©tablis afin de relier l‚Äôaffaire aux enregistrements de l‚Äôauteur pr√©sum√©. De plus, des donn√©es suppl√©mentaires sur les profils d‚Äôinterventions polici√®res ont √©t√© inclus afin d‚Äôidentifier toutes les affaires ant√©rieures et subs√©quentes d√©clar√©es par la police des personnes impliqu√©es dans des crimes motiv√©s par la haine.
