Title: Terrorism and Other Related Criminal Activities
Dataset Title (French): Terrorisme et les autres activit√©s criminelles connexes
Summary:
The Terrorism and Other Related Criminal Activities (TORCA) files identify a cohort of individuals that were involved in police-reported terrorism and other related criminal activities between 2011 and 2018, as well as their involvement in previous and subsequent police-reported incidents. The files include data from the Uniform Crime Reporting Survey (UCR), the Integrated Criminal Courts Survey (ICCS), and the Integrated Correctional Services Survey (ICSS)/Canadian Correctional Services Survey (CCSS). These files are supplemented with the Canadian Index of Multiple Deprivation (CIMD).
The TORCA files are the second set of files produced for the Canadian-Sweden Research Collaboration on Organized Violent Threats. In collaboration with Defence Research and Development Canada (DRDC), Statistics Canada developed these data files to enhance our understanding of the underlying mechanisms leading to violence, and ultimately contribute to strengthening societal resilience against organized violent threats. This is part of a broader collaboration between Canada and Sweden that aims to address requirements for data resources and knowledge sharing between the two countries to develop a better understanding of the evolution of organized violence of different types. Canadian partners participating in the project include Public Safety Canada, Statistics Canada, and the Canadian Network for Research on Terrorism, Security and Society (TSAS). Data files on hate crime were previously produced and files on organized crime will follow.
Summary French:
Les fichiers de donn√©es sur le Terrorisme et les autres activit√©s criminelles connexes (TAACC) identifient une cohorte de personnes impliqu√©es dans terrorisme et d‚Äôautres activit√©s criminelles connexes  d√©clar√©es par la police entre les ann√©es 2011 et 2018, ainsi que leurs affaires criminelles ant√©rieures et subs√©quentes d√©clar√©es par la police. Les fichiers comprennent des donn√©es provenant du Programme de d√©claration uniforme de la criminalit√© (DUC), de l‚ÄôEnqu√™te int√©gr√©e sur les tribunaux de juridiction criminelle (EITJC) et de l‚ÄôEnqu√™te int√©gr√©e sur les services correctionnels/l‚ÄôEnqu√™te sur les services correctionnels canadiens (ESCC). L'Indice canadien de d√©favorisation multiple (ICDM) a aussi √©t√© ajout√© aux fichiers.
Les fichiers de donn√©es sur le TAACC sont le deuxi√®me ensemble de fichiers cr√©√©s pour l‚ÄôInitiative de recherche sur les menaces violentes organis√©es men√©e par le Canada et la Su√®de. En collaboration avec Recherche et d√©veloppement pour la d√©fense Canada (RDDC), Statistique Canada a cr√©√© ces fichiers de donn√©es afin d‚Äôam√©liorer notre compr√©hension des m√©canismes sous-jacents menant √† la violence, et de contribuer au renforcement de la r√©silience de la soci√©t√© face aux menaces violentes organis√©es. Ceci est dans le cadre d‚Äôune collaboration plus large entre le Canada et la Su√®de qui vise √† r√©pondre aux besoins en mati√®re de ressources de donn√©es et de partage des connaissances entre les deux pays, afin d‚Äôam√©liorer la compr√©hension des diff√©rentes formes de violence organis√©e. Parmi les partenaires canadiens qui participent au projet figurent S√©curit√© publique Canada, Statistique Canada et le R√©seau canadien de recherche sur le terrorisme, la s√©curit√© et la soci√©t√©. Des fichiers de donn√©es sur le crime motiv√© par la haine ont d√©j√† √©t√© cr√©√©s et des fichiers sur le crime organis√© suivront.
Subjects: Crime and justice>Crimes and offences
Content:

The TORCA files are the second set of files produced for the Canadian-Sweden Research Collaboration on Organized Violent Threats. Title: Impact of Preterm Birth on Socioeconomic and Educational Outcomes of Children and Families
Dataset Title (French): Impact des naissances pr√©matur√©es sur les r√©sultats socio-√©conomiques et √©ducationnels des enfants et des familles
Summary: The purpose of this data integration project is to quantify individual- and family-level, socioeconomic impact of preterm birth, in both the short- and long-term survivors and compare their outcomes to those of infants born at term. This project will also create a retrospective cohort of families of preterm infants and compare their outcomes to those of families of infants born at term. Four cohorts were produced for this project: long-term follow-up of children (LTC) born between 1983 and 1996, long-term follow-up of mothers (LTM) of children born between 1983 and 1996; short-term follow-up of children (STC) born between 2006 and 2015; and short-term follow-up of mothers (STM) of children born between 2006 and 2015. Subsequently, each cohort was linked to one or more of the following administrative and/or survey data: the T1 Family file (T1FF); the Canadian Vital Statistics ‚Äì Deaths Database (CVSD); the Discharge Abstract Database (DAD); the Employment Insurance Status Vector (EISV); the Postsecondary Student Information System (PSIS); and the 2006 Census of Population. This project will provide valuable information to both policymakers and clinicians. The linked data can be used to help inter alia: Elucidate areas of focus or improvement for future interventions involving preterm birth children and families; and Provide comprehensive, quantifiable estimates of the short- and long-term socioeconomic impact of preterm birth on both child and family
Summary French: L‚Äôobjectif de ce projet d‚Äôint√©gration de donn√©es est de quantifier l‚Äôimpact socio-√©conomique √† court et √† long terme des naissances pr√©matur√©es pour les survivants aux niveaux individuel, et familial et de les comparer √† ceux des enfants n√©s √† terme. Dans le cadre de ce projet, quatre cohortes ont √©t√© cr√©√©es. Il s‚Äôagit de la cohorte de suivi √† long terme des enfants n√©s entre 1983 et 1996, de la cohorte de suivi √† long terme des m√®res des enfants n√©s entre 1983 et 1996 ; de la cohorte de suivi √† court terme des enfants n√©s entre 2006 et 2015, et de la cohorte de suivi √† court terme des m√®res des enfants n√©s entre 2006 et 2015. Par la suite, chaque cohorte a √©t√© coupl√©e √† une ou plusieurs donn√©es administratives et/ou enqu√™tes suivantes : le fichier des familles T1 (FFT1), la Base canadienne de donn√©es sur les d√©c√®s de la Statistique de l‚Äô√©tat civil (BCDECD), la Base de donn√©es sur les cong√©s des patients (BDCP), le Profil vectoriel de l‚Äôassurance-emploi (PVAE), le Syst√®me d‚Äôinformation sur les √©tudiants postsecondaires (SIEP), et le recensement de la population de 2006. Le projet fournira de pr√©cieuses informations aux d√©cideurs politiques et aux cliniciens. Les donn√©es coupl√©es peuvent √™tre utilis√©es entre autres choses pour aider √† : √âlucider des domaines d‚Äôint√©r√™t ou des domaines m√©ritant des am√©liorations pour des interventions futures impliquant des naissances pr√©matur√©es et leurs familles, et Fournir des estimations compl√®tes et quantifiables de l‚Äôimpact socio-√©conomique √† court et √† long terme des naissances pr√©matur√©es √† la fois sur les enfants et les familles. Statistique Canada dispose d‚Äôune longue exp√©rience pour cr√©er, utiliser et rendre accessible des couplages d‚Äôenregistrements. Le couplage d‚Äôenregistrements est une technique statistique essentielle et rentable utilis√©e pour √©laborer des produits de donn√©es qui servent de fondement √† la recherche de pointe et permettent de mieux comprendre d‚Äôimportantes questions sociales, comme les r√©sultats en mati√®re de sant√© et les disparit√©s observ√©es dans des sous-segments de la population canadienne.

Title: Impacts of COVID-19 on Canadians: Data Collection Series
Dataset Title (French): R√©percussions de la COVID-19 sur les Canadiens : s√©rie de collecte de donn√©es
Summary: Starting April 3, 2020, Statistics Canada will conduct a collection series on the Impacts of the COVID-19 on Canadians. The COVID-19 pandemic is currently disrupting the lives and habits of all Canadians. It is therefore necessary to quickly gather information to help understand its impacts on the physical and mental health of individuals, as well as on their social and employment circumstances. The collection series collects data on the current economic and social situation, as well as on people's physical and mental health, to effectively assess the needs of communities and implement suitable support measures during and after the pandemic.

La s√©rie de collecte permet de recueillir des donn√©es sur la situation √©conomique et sociale, ainsi que sur la sant√© physique et mentale des individus, pour bien comprendre les besoins des collectivit√©s et pouvoir mettre en place des mesures de soutien appropri√©es pendant et apr√®s la pand√©mie.

Title: Survey of Household Spending - Cancer Cost linkage
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te sur les d√©penses des m√©nages couts du cancer couplage
Summary:
This data integration project brings together data from the Survey of Household Spending (SHS), the Canadian Cancer registry (CCR), the Discharge Abstract Database (DAD), the National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NACRS), the Ontario Mental Health Reporting System (OMHRS), the Canadian Vital Statistics ‚Äì Death Database (CVSD), and the T1 Family (T1FF).

 

The purpose of this research project is to leverage existing data in Canada to better understand the full scope and magnitude of the economic burden of out-of-pocket costs paid by cancer patients and survivors for medical and non-medical care and how it differs between jurisdictions, cancer type and relevant patient sub-populations. The overarching aim of this project is to provide the required tools to conduct research that may help identify policy and practice options to mitigate the financial barriers to cancer treatments and care that exist for patients and their families.
Summary French:
Ce projet d‚Äôint√©gration de donn√©es rassemble les donn√©es de l‚ÄôEnqu√™te sur les d√©penses des m√©nages (EDM) avec le Registre canadien du cancer (RCC), la Base de donn√©es sur les cong√©s des patients (BDCP), le Syst√®me national d‚Äôinformation sur les soins ambulatoires (SNISA), le Syst√®me d‚Äôinformation ontarien sur la sant√© mentale (SIOSM), la Base canadienne de donn√©es de l‚Äô√©tat civil ‚Äì D√©c√®s (BCDECD) et le Fichier des familles T1 et le Fichier des familles (FFT1).

 

Le but du projet est de mettre √† profit les donn√©es actuellement disponibles au Canada afin de mieux comprendre l‚Äôampleur et la port√©e du fardeau √©conomique des co√ªts directs assum√©s par les patients et les survivants du cancer pour des soins m√©dicaux et non m√©dicaux et sa variation d‚Äôune province et d‚Äôun territoire √† l‚Äôautre, selon le type de cancer et les sous-populations pertinentes de patients. L‚Äôobjectif primordial du couplage est de fournir les outils n√©cessaires pour mener des recherches visant √† relever des options politiques et pratiques afin d‚Äôatt√©nuer les obstacles financiers aux traitements contre le cancer et aux soins connexes auxquels sont confront√©s les patients et leur famille.

This data integration project brings together data from the Survey of Household Spending (SHS), the Canadian Cancer registry (CCR), the Discharge Abstract Database (DAD), the National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NACRS), the Ontario Mental Health Reporting System (OMHRS), the Canadian Vital Statistics ‚Äì Death Database (CVSD), and the T1 Family (T1FF).

 

The purpose of this research project is to leverage existing data in Canada to better understand the full scope and magnitude of the economic burden of out-of-pocket costs paid by cancer patients and survivors for medical and non-medical care and how it differs between jurisdictions, cancer type and relevant patient sub-populations. Title: Staffing and Non-Partisanship Survey
Dataset Title (French): Sondage sur la dotation et l'impartialit√© politique
Summary: The Staffing and Non-partisanship Survey is conducted every two years for the Public Service Commission of Canada. The survey targets all departments and agencies under the Public Service Employment Act (PSEA), with no minimum number of employees required. The SNPS gathers information from employees, managers or supervisors and staffing advisors, on key aspects of the staffing system (e.g., merit), including the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. As in previous years, the survey also gathers critical information on employees' understanding of their rights and responsibilities regarding political activities and non-partisanship.

Le SDIP recueille des renseignements aupr√®s de l'ensemble des employ√©s, de gestionnaires ou superviseurs et de conseillers en dotation des organisations, au sujet des principaux aspects du syst√®me de dotation (p. ex. le m√©rite), y compris les r√©percussions de la pand√©mie de COVID-19. Tout comme lors des cycles pr√©c√©dents, le sondage recueille √©galement des renseignements essentiels sur la compr√©hension des fonctionnaires, de leurs droits et responsabilit√©s √† l'√©gard des activit√©s politiques et de l'impartialit√© politique.

Title: Census of Agriculture
Dataset Title (French): Recensement de l'Agriculture
Summary: The data collected by the Census of Agriculture are used to produce statistics on the full spectrum of the agriculture industry. The information is also used by Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada and provincial governments to develop, administer and evaluate agricultural policies, and by universities and agri-businesses for research and planning. The census takes place every five years as decreed by the Statistics Act. It provides a historical perspective on Canadian agriculture and on trends in the industry over the years. This data release includes non-confidential documentation that can be provided to researchers outside an RDC. Please contact your local RDC Analyst if you would like a copy.

Les donn√©es recueillies dans le cadre du Recensement de l'agriculture sont utilis√©es pour produire des statistiques sur l'ensemble de l'industrie agricole. The information is also used by Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada and provincial governments to develop, administer and evaluate agricultural policies, and by universities and agri-businesses for research and planning. This data release includes non-confidential documentation that can be provided to researchers outside an RDC. Please contact your local RDC Analyst if you would like a copy.

Content: The 2021 Canadian Survey of Cyber Security and Cybercrime is conducted on behalf of Public Safety Canada. Title: Canadian COVID-19 Antibody and Health Survey
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te canadienne sur la sant√© et les anticorps contre la COVID-19
Summary:
The Canadian COVID-19 Antibody and Health Survey (CCAHS), collected key information relevant to the COVID-19 pandemic to learn as much as possible about the virus, how it affects overall health, how it spreads, and whether Canadians are developing antibodies against it. The Canadian COVID-19 Antibody and Health Survey (CCAHS) collected information in two parts. The first part is an electronic questionnaire about general health and exposure to COVID-19. The second part is two self-administered sample collections; an at-home finger-prick sample collection called a dried blood spot (DBS) sample, which was used to measure the presence of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, from vaccination or prior infection. The second at-home collection was a saliva sample which was used to determine if there was a recent or current SARS-CoV-2 infection at the time of sampling, by testing for viral material in the sample using a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test. Participants were asked to complete both sample collections as soon as possible after the questionnaire. The data can be used to:
  • Estimate how many Canadians test positive for antibodies against COVID-19. By using each participant's DBS samples combined with their survey responses, we can determine how many Canadians have antibodies against COVID-19 due to infection, vaccination or both.
  • Provide a platform to explore emerging public health issues;
  • Assist in the development of programs and services to respond to the needs of the current pandemic.
  • Identify the estimated prevalence of infection on any given day during May to August 2022 in Canada.
In 2023, a follow-up to the Canadian COVID-19 Antibody and Health Survey (CCAHS - Follow-up Questionnaire, 2023) collected new and updated information about health. The questions touched on changes in vaccination status, reinfection with the virus that causes COVID-19, symptoms of COVID-19 and impact on daily life, health conditions and the use of health care services.
Summary French:
L'Enqu√™te canadienne sur la sant√© et les anticorps contre la COVID-19 (ECSAC) a permis de recueillir des renseignements importants li√©s √† la pand√©mie de COVID-19 pour en apprendre le plus possible √† propos du virus, de ses effets sur la sant√© en g√©n√©ral, de sa propagation et de la production potentielle d'anticorps au sein de la population canadienne. L'Enqu√™te canadienne sur la sant√© et les anticorps contre la COVID-19 (ECSAC) a recueilli des informations en deux parties. La premi√®re partie est un questionnaire √©lectronique sur l'√©tat de sant√© g√©n√©ral et l'exposition √† la COVID-19. La deuxi√®me partie est constitu√©e de deux √©chantillons auto-administr√©s ; un √©chantillon de gouttes de sang s√©ch√© (GSS) pr√©lev√© √† domicile par piq√ªre au doigt servant √† mesurer la pr√©sence d'anticorps contre le SRAS-CoV-2, le virus qui cause la COVID-19, que ce soit par vaccination ou une infection ant√©rieure. Le deuxi√®me pr√©l√®vement √† domicile √©tait un √©chantillon de salive servant √† analyser la pr√©sence de mati√®res virales pour d√©terminer si les participants ont une infection au SRAS-CoV-2 au moment des pr√©l√®vements ou s'ils en ont eu une r√©cemment. On a demand√© aux participants d'effectuer les pr√©l√®vements de sang et de salive d√®s que possible apr√®s avoir rempli le questionnaire. Les donn√©es peuvent √™tre utilis√©es pour :
  • Estimer le nombre de Canadiens qui obtiennent un r√©sultat positif au test de d√©pistage des anticorps contre la COVID-19. En utilisant les √©chantillons de GSS de chaque participant et leurs r√©ponses √† l'enqu√™te, nous pouvons d√©terminer le nombre de Canadiens qui ont des anticorps contre la COVID-19 suite √† une infection, une vaccination ou les deux.
  • Fournir une plateforme pour examiner les probl√®mes de sant√© publique √©mergents;
  • Aider √† l'√©laboration de programmes et de services pour r√©pondre aux besoins li√©s √† la pand√©mie actuelle;
  • D√©terminer la pr√©valence estim√©e d'infections au Canada, peu importe le moment, de mai √† ao√ªt 2022;
    • En 2023, le suivi √† l'Enqu√™te canadienne sur la sant√© et les anticorps contre la COVID-19 (ECSAC - Questionnaire de suivi, 2023) a recueilli des renseignements nouveaux et √† jour √† propos de la sant√©. Les questions portaient sur les changements dans votre statut vaccinal, la r√©infection au virus qui cause la COVID-19, les sympt√¥mes de la COVID-19 et ses r√©percussions sur la vie quotidienne, les probl√®mes de sant√© et l'utilisation des services de soins de sant√©.
Subjects: Health>Diseases and physical health conditions|Health>Lifestyle and social conditions
Content:

The second part is two self-administered sample collections; an at-home finger-prick sample collection called a dried blood spot (DBS) sample, which was used to measure the presence of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, from vaccination or prior infection. The data can be used to:

Title: Criminal Organization and Street Gang Offences
Dataset Title (French): Infractions d'organisation criminelle et de gang de rue
Summary: The Criminal Organization and Street Gang Offences (COSGO) files identify a cohort of individuals that were involved in police-reported criminal organization/street gang offences between 2016 and 2021, as well as their involvement in previous and subsequent police-reported incidents. The files include data from the Uniform Crime Reporting Survey (UCR), the Integrated Criminal Courts Survey (ICCS), and the Integrated Correctional Services Survey (ICSS)/Canadian Correctional Services Survey (CCSS). These files are supplemented with the Canadian Index of Multiple Deprivation (CIMD). The COSGO files are the third and final set of files produced for the Canadian-Sweden Research Collaboration on Organized Violent Threats. In collaboration with Defence Research and Development Canada (DRDC), Statistics Canada developed these data files to enhance our understanding of the underlying mechanisms leading to violence, and ultimately contribute to strengthening societal resilience against organized violent threats. This is part of a broader collaboration between Canada and Sweden that aims to address requirements for data resources and knowledge sharing between the two countries to develop a better understanding of the evolution of organized violence of different types. Canadian partners participating in the project include Public Safety Canada, Statistics Canada, and the Canadian Network for Research on Terrorism, Security and Society (TSAS). Data files on hate crime as well as terrorism and other related criminal activities were previously produced.
Summary French: Les fichiers de donn√©es sur les Infractions d‚Äôorganisation criminelle et de gang de rue (IOCGR) identifient une cohorte de personnes impliqu√©es dans des infractions d‚Äôorganisation criminelle/de gang de rue d√©clar√©es par la police entre les ann√©es 2016 et 2019, ainsi que leurs affaires criminelles ant√©rieures et subs√©quentes d√©clar√©es par la police. Les fichiers comprennent des donn√©es provenant du Programme de d√©claration uniforme de la criminalit√© (DUC), de l‚ÄôEnqu√™te int√©gr√©e sur les tribunaux de juridiction criminelle (EITJC) et de l‚ÄôEnqu√™te int√©gr√©e sur les services correctionnels/l‚ÄôEnqu√™te sur les services correctionnels canadiens (ESCC). L'Indice canadien de d√©favorisation multiple (ICDM) a aussi √©t√© ajout√© aux fichiers. Les fichiers de donn√©es sur l‚ÄôIOCGR sont le troisi√®me et dernier ensemble de fichiers cr√©√©s pour l‚ÄôInitiative de recherche sur les menaces violentes organis√©es men√©e par le Canada et la Su√®de. En collaboration avec Recherche et d√©veloppement pour la d√©fense Canada (RDDC), Statistique Canada a cr√©√© ces fichiers de donn√©es afin d‚Äôam√©liorer notre compr√©hension des m√©canismes sous-jacents menant √† la violence, et de contribuer au renforcement de la r√©silience de la soci√©t√© face aux menaces violentes organis√©es. Ceci est dans le cadre d‚Äôune collaboration plus large entre le Canada et la Su√®de qui vise √† r√©pondre aux besoins en mati√®re de ressources de donn√©es et de partage des connaissances entre les deux pays, afin d‚Äôam√©liorer la compr√©hension des diff√©rentes formes de violence organis√©e. Parmi les partenaires canadiens qui participent au projet figurent S√©curit√© publique Canada, Statistique Canada et le R√©seau canadien de recherche sur le terrorisme, la s√©curit√© et la soci√©t√©. Des fichiers de donn√©es sur le crime motiv√© par la haine ainsi que sur le terrorisme et les autres activit√©s criminelles connexes ont d√©j√† √©t√© cr√©√©s.

These files are supplemented with the Canadian Index of Multiple Deprivation (CIMD). The COSGO files are the third and final set of files produced for the Canadian-Sweden Research Collaboration on Organized Violent Threats. Title: Survey of Employees under Federal Jurisdiction

Summary: This survey collects information from a sample of employees working for businesses under federal jurisdiction, including regular, seasonal, term, and casual or on-call employees. Title: Nursing and Residential Care Facility Survey
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te sur les √©tablissements de soins infirmiers et de soins pour b√©n√©ficiaires internes
Summary: Questions will be asked about the facility, its revenues and expenses, personnel and hours worked, the type of services offered on-site, the number of beds and the number of residents by their age and gender. Questions related to the COVID-19 pandemic will cover infection prevention and control, changes made to the facility, the confirmed number of COVID-19 cases, and the proportion of residents and employees fully vaccinated against COVID-19. Data collected from businesses are aggregated with information from other sources to produce official estimates of national and provincial economic production for this industry. This survey data will be used to standardize national, provincial, and regional statistics on nursing and residential care facilities in Canada. This will allow governments and researchers to examine the correlation between facility operations and personnel, health outcomes of residents, and system-level performance during pandemics or other emergencies.

Title: Business Employee Analytical Microdata
Dataset Title (French): Microdonn√©es analytiques sur les entreprises et les employ√©s
Summary:
The BEAM is a set of linkable microdata files extracted from Statistics Canada‚Äôs tax and administrative data. The BEAM contains information on all individual tax filers and all paid employees who were issued a T4 slip. All corporations that filed a T2 corporation tax return and all unincorporated businesses with a valid Business Number are also included in the BEAM. Names and addresses of both individuals and businesses have been removed and replaced with anonymized identifiers.

The BEAM provides rich information on individuals and on the characteristics and performance of businesses. For example, for individual employees, The BEAM includes information on demographic, income, job mobility, and immigration status. For businesses, the BEAM includes information on the characteristics and performance of businesses such as income, expenses, assets, liabilities, payroll and employment as well as ownership and workforce compositions.

Les noms et les adresses des particuliers et des entreprises ont √©t√© retir√©s et remplac√©s par des identifiants anonymes.

Title: Pilot Study on Everyday Well-being

Title: Farm Management Survey
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te sur la gestion des fermes
Summary:
The Farm Management Survey (FMS), conducted every five years, is a collaborative project between Statistics Canada and Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada.

The FMS contributes to Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada's work on measuring selected management practices in the agriculture sector. The information generated from this survey informs federal and provincial policy decisions in the sector.

FMS data were collected using a sample of 18,000 farms selected to be representative of 81% of Canadian production of dairy cows; beef; poultry; pork; field crops; forage crops; and fruit, vegetable, berry and nut crops. Small farms were automatically excluded, and large ones were considered "must take" because of their national influence on farm practices.

The survey aims to produce estimates for seven farm types at both the provincial and ecological region levels. Each respondent filled out the questionnaire for only one of these commodities based on the significance of their production nationally and within their region. Data from the Census of Agriculture were used to identify the importance of each farm's production.
Summary French:
L'Enqu√™te sur la gestion des fermes (EGF), men√©e tous les cinq ans, est un projet collaboratif entre Statistique Canada et Agriculture et Agroalimentaire Canada.

L'EGF contribue au travail d'Agriculture et Agroalimentaire Canada concernant l'adoption de certaines pratiques de gestion dans le secteur agricole. Les renseignements provenant de cette enqu√™te permettent d'orienter la prise de d√©cisions relatives aux politiques f√©d√©rales et provinciales dans ce secteur.

Les donn√©es de l'EGF ont √©t√© recueillies √† partir d'un √©chantillon de 18 000 exploitations agricoles s√©lectionn√©es pour qu'elles repr√©sentent 81 % de la production canadienne de vaches laiti√®res, de bovins de boucherie, de volaille, de porcs, de grandes cultures, de cultures fourrag√®res et de cultures de fruits, de l√©gumes, de baies et de noix. Les petites exploitations ont √©t√© automatiquement exclues, alors que de grandes exploitations ont √©t√© consid√©r√©es √† tirage obligatoire en raison de leur influence nationale sur les pratiques agricoles.

Cette enqu√™te vise √† produire des estimations pour sept types d'exploitations agricoles √† l'√©chelle provinciale et de la r√©gion √©cologique. Chaque r√©pondant a rempli le questionnaire pour une seule de ces commodit√©s en se basant sur la significativit√© de leur production au niveau national et √† l'int√©rieur de leur r√©gion. Les donn√©es provenant du Recensement de l'agriculture ont √©t√© utilis√©es afin d'identifier l'importance de la production de chaque ferme.
Subjects: Environment>Environmental protection|Agriculture and food>Land use
Content:
The Farm Management Survey (FMS), conducted every five years, is a collaborative project between Statistics Canada and Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada.

The FMS contributes to Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada's work on measuring selected management practices in the agriculture sector. The information generated from this survey informs federal and provincial policy decisions in the sector.

FMS data were collected using a sample of 18,000 farms selected to be representative of 81% of Canadian production of dairy cows; beef; poultry; pork; field crops; forage crops; and fruit, vegetable, berry and nut crops. Small farms were automatically excluded, and large ones were considered "must take" because of their national influence on farm practices.

The survey aims to produce estimates for seven farm types at both the provincial and ecological region levels. Each respondent filled out the questionnaire for only one of these commodities based on the significance of their production nationally and within their region. Data from the Census of Agriculture were used to identify the importance of each farm's production.

Title: Survey Series on People and their Communities
Dataset Title (French): S√©rie d'enqu√™tes sur les gens et leurs communaut√©s
Summary:
The Survey Series on People and their Communities (SSPC) involves creating a panel of people who agree to complete four short online surveys over a period of one year. This is the third time that Statistics Canada is conducting this type of survey.
The SSPC is a survey series of four social surveys in 2022 and 2023. This project falls under the umbrella of the Disaggregated Data Action Plan (DDAP). DDAP will produce detailed statistical information to highlight the lived experiences of specific population groups, such as women, Indigenous peoples, racialized groups and people living with disabilities. It will also shed light on intersections such as those between racialized identity and sexual orientation, or between age and gender. Questionnaire content will cover a variety of social topics. Using the 2021 Census survey frame, the sample for the SSPC includes an oversampling of immigrants, and Canadians self-declaring as being part of racialized groups. By doing this, differences and commonalities in the experiences of racialized groups and immigrants will be revealed. The SSPC was specifically designed to provide estimates within individual racialized groups and immigration status categories.

La SEGC est une s√©rie de quatre enqu√™tes sociales qui seront men√©es en 2022 et en 2023. Ce projet s'inscrit dans le cadre du Plan d'action sur les donn√©es d√©sagr√©g√©es (PADD). La SEGC a √©t√© sp√©cialement con√ßue pour fournir des estimations √† l'int√©rieur des groupes racis√©s et des cat√©gories de statut d'immigrant pris isol√©ment.

Title: National Travel Survey
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te nationale sur les voyages
Summary:
The National Travel Survey was developed to fully replace the Travel Survey of Residents of Canada (record number 3810) and replace the Canadian resident component of the International Travel Survey (record number 3152). The National Travel Survey collects information about the domestic and international travel of Canadian residents.

The National Travel Survey, sponsored by Statistics Canada, aims to measure the characteristics and the economic impact of the tourism activities of Canadian residents. The objectives of the survey are to provide information about the number of trips and expenditures by Canadian residents by trip origin, destination, duration, type of accommodation used, trip reason, mode of travel, etc.; to provide information on travel incidence and to provide the socio-demographic profile of travellers and non-travellers. From a macroeconomic point of view, the NTS measures the domestic and international tourism demand by Canadian residents.

Title: Survey of Commercial and Institutional Energy Use
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te sur l'utilisation commerciale et institutionnelle d'√©nergie
Summary:
The purpose of this survey, sponsored by Natural Resources Canada (NRCan), is to collect statistical information on the energy demand and consumption patterns of commercial and institutional buildings across Canada. The survey collects data on the types and quantities of energy being used (such as electricity and natural gas) and building characteristics to better understand energy consumption.

Clear, credible information is the foundation on which to build the case for investments in energy efficiency. Understanding how much energy a building uses and for what reason is a necessary first step to designing effective measures to reduce energy use and track the effectiveness of those measures over time.

Aggregated data from this survey will be used by governments, utilities, industry associations, building managers and business owners to
‚Ä¢ develop programs and policies to improve the energy efficiency of commercial and institutional buildings and support Canada's climate change objectives
‚Ä¢ support programs such as ENERGY STAR¬Æ Portfolio Manager¬Æ to encourage energy efficiency practices and enable owners to track and compare their building's energy use against that of similar buildings.

L'enqu√™te permet de recueillir des donn√©es sur les types et les quantit√©s d'√©nergie utilis√©s (√©lectricit√©, gaz naturel, etc.) et les caract√©ristiques des immeubles pour mieux comprendre la consommation d'√©nergie.

- √©laborer des programmes et des politiques qui am√©lioreront l'efficacit√© √©nerg√©tique des immeubles commerciaux et institutionnels et qui appuieront les objectifs du Canada en ce qui concerne les changements climatiques;
- soutenir des programmes tels que ¬´ ENERGY STAR¬Æ Portfolio Manager¬Æ ¬ª afin d'encourager les pratiques d'efficacit√© √©nerg√©tique et de permettre aux propri√©taires de surveiller la consommation d'√©nergie de leur immeuble et de la comparer √† celle d'immeubles semblables.

Title: Farm Management Survey Linked to Census of Agriculture
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te fur la gestion des exploitations agricoles coupl√©e au recensement de l'agriculture
Summary:
Microdata linkage files between the Census of Agriculture (CEAG) and the Farm Management Survey (FMS) have been produced. CEAG variables cover many topics such as the number of farms and farm operators, farm area, farm size, farm type, land use, crop areas, land management practices, livestock inventories, business operating arrangements, farm operating revenues, farm operating expenses, farm capital, and farm machinery.
Like the CEAG, the FMS is collected every 5 years and measures management practices on Canadian farms. While some of the content for FMS and CEAG can overlap (animal and crop inventory, use of new technologies, innovation on farms, etc.), FMS tends to cover fewer subjects, but in greater detail. The FMS focuses on both livestock and crop operations; specifically the production of dairy, beef, poultry, pig, field crops, forage crops and vegetable, fruit, berry and nut crops. This survey is conducted in conjunction with Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada, to ensure that agriculture programs reflect the changing way resources are being managed on today's farms. Some of the subjects covered by this survey include agriculture and food, environment, environmental protection, and land use and environmental practices.
Summary French:
Des fichiers de couplage de microdonn√©es entre le recensement de l'agriculture (REAG) et l'enqu√™te sur la gestion des exploitations agricoles (EGF) ont √©t√© produits. Les variables du REAG couvrent de nombreux sujets tels que le nombre d'exploitations et d'exploitants agricoles, la superficie des exploitations, leur taille, le type d'exploitation, l'utilisation des terres, les surfaces cultiv√©es, les pratiques de gestion des terres, les stocks de b√©tail, les accords d'exploitation commerciale, les revenus d'exploitation des exploitations, les d√©penses d'exploitation des exploitations, le capital des exploitations et les machines agricoles.
Tout comme le REAG, la collecte de l'EGF a lieu tous les 5 ans et mesure les pratiques de gestion dans les fermes canadiennes. Il y a du recoupement entre le contenu de l‚ÄôEGF et de celui du REAG (inventaire des animaux et des cultures, utilisation des nouvelles technologies, innovation dans les exploitations agricoles), o√π l‚ÄôEGF couvre moins de sujets, mais plus en d√©tail. Cette enqu√™te s'int√©resse aux fermes de b√©tail et de cultures, notamment sur les productions laiti√®res, bovines, volaille, porcs, de grandes cultures, fourrag√®res et cultures de l√©gumes, de fruits, de baies et de noix. Cette enqu√™te est men√©e conjointement avec Agriculture et Agroalimentaire Canada pour garantir que les programmes agricoles repr√©sentent les nouvelles fa√ßons de g√©rer les ressources dans les fermes. Quelques-uns des sujets inclus dans cette enqu√™te sont agriculture et alimentation, environnement, protection de l‚Äôenvironnement, et utilisation de terres et pratiques environnementales.

Summary: The Mental Health and Access to Care Survey (MHACS) collects information about the mental health status of Canadians, as well as their access to and need for services and supports, whether formal or informal. Title: Survey of Innovation and Business Strategy
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te sur l'innovation et les strat√©gies d'entreprise
Summary:
The Survey of Innovation and Business Strategy (SIBS) is a cross-economy survey of business enterprises and industrial non-profit organizations in Canada.

The concepts and definitions employed in the collection and dissemination of innovation data are provided in the Oslo Manual: Guidelines for Collecting and Interpreting Innovation Data, 4th Edition (Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, [OECD and Eurostat, 2018]). According to the manual:

"An innovation is a new or improved product or process (or combination thereof) that differs significantly from the unit's previous products or processes and that has been made available to potential users (product) or brought into use by the unit (process)."

The SIBS collects complementary qualitative business information, including market characteristics, use of advanced technologies, business strategy, business practices and participation in global value chains. The survey also collects quantitative information on total sales, innovation expenditures, purchase of goods and services and personnel, supplemented by percentage distributions by specified subgroups.
Summary French: L'Enqu√™te sur l'innovation et les strat√©gies d'entreprise (EISE) touche l'ensemble de l'√©conomie et elle est men√©e aupr√®s d'entreprises et d'organismes industriels sans but lucratif au Canada. Les concepts et les d√©finitions utilis√©s pour recueillir et diffuser les donn√©es sur l'innovation sont pr√©sent√©s dans le Manuel d'Oslo : Principes directeurs pour le recueil et l'interpr√©tation des donn√©es sur l'innovation, 4e √©dition (Organisation de coop√©ration et de d√©veloppement √©conomiques [OCDE et Eurostat, 2018]). Selon le Manuel : ¬´ Une innovation d√©signe un produit ou un processus (ou une combinaison des deux) nouveau ou am√©lior√© qui diff√®re sensiblement des produits ou processus pr√©c√©dents d'une unit√© et a √©t√© mis √† la disposition d'utilisateurs potentiels (produit) ou mis en oeuvre par l'unit√© (processus). ¬ª L'EISE recueille des renseignements commerciaux qualitatifs compl√©mentaires, y compris les caract√©ristiques du march√©, l'utilisation de technologies de pointe, les strat√©gies d'entreprise, les pratiques commerciales et la participation aux cha√Ænes de valeur mondiales. L'enqu√™te recueille √©galement des renseignements quantitatifs sur les ventes totales, les d√©penses en innovation, l'achat de biens et de services, et le personnel, auxquels s'ajoutent des r√©partitions en pourcentage par sous groupe pr√©cis.

The concepts and definitions employed in the collection and dissemination of innovation data are provided in the Oslo Manual: Guidelines for Collecting and Interpreting Innovation Data, 4th Edition (Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, [OECD and Eurostat, 2018]). Title: Canadian Partnership Against Cancer - All Years Linkage
Dataset Title (French): Partenariat Canadien Contre le Cancer - toutes ann√©es
Summary:
The purpose of this microdata linkage project is to create linked data that will allow researchers to examine the short and long term income of adult cancer survivors from across Canada. The specific aims of this project are the following: to describe patterns of income for a cohort of cancer survivors over time, as measured by net household and net individual income from the T1 Family File (T1FF) and on the Longitudinal Administrative Databank (LAD) for a cohort of controls; to estimate the effect of clinical factors (e.g., data of diagnosis, age at diagnosis, and tumour type) and sociodemographic factors (e.g., immigration status, income, urban/rural indicator, province/territory and health region) on household and individuals; and to examine differences in the impact of cancer on income for: women and men; different age at diagnosis groups; different provinces/territories, health regions and urban/rural locations.

A cohort of cancer survivors who had a cancer diagnosis between January 1, 2000 and December 31, 2017 was constructed using the Canadian Cancer Registry (CCR) linked to the T1FF (1992 to 2017) and to the Vital Statistics ‚Äì Death Database (CVSD) (2000 to 2017). A cohort of controls formed by those who did not have a cancer diagnosis during the same period was also created using the LAD (1992 to 2017) records that were not linked to the CCR; these LAD records were also linked to the CVSD.

This data release includes non-confidential documentation that can be provided to researchers outside an RDC. Please contact your local RDC Analyst if you would like a copy.
Summary French:

The Survey on Early Learning and Child Care Arrangements - Children with Long-term Conditions and Disabilities gathers information from parents and guardians on early learning and child care arrangements for children aged 0 to 5 who may have one or more long-term condition or disability.

Title: Annual Survey of Manufacturing and Logging Industries
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te annuelle sur les industries manufacturi√®res et de l'exploitation foresti√®re
Summary:
The Annual Survey of Manufacturing and Logging Industries (ASML) is a survey of the manufacturing and logging industries in Canada. It is intended to cover all establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing and logging activities as well as some sales offices and warehouses which support these establishments.

The details collected include principal industrial statistics (such as revenue, salaries and wages, cost of materials and supplies used, cost of energy and water utility, inventories, etc.), as well as information about the commodities produced and consumed. Data collected from businesses will be aggregated with information from other sources to produce official estimates of national and provincial economic production for these industries.

Data collected by the ASML are important because they help measure the production of Canada's industrial and primary resource sectors, as well as provide an indication of the well-being of each industry covered by the survey and its contribution to the Canadian economy. Within Statistics Canada, the data are used by the Canadian System of National Accounts, the Monthly Survey of Manufacturing (record number 2101) and Prices programs. The data are also used by the business community, trade associations and federal and provincial departments, as well as international organizations and associations, to profile the manufacturing and logging industries, undertake market studies, forecast demand and develop trade and tariff policies.

L'Enqu√™te annuelle sur les industries manufacturi√®res et de l'exploitation foresti√®re (EAMEF) est une enqu√™te des secteurs de la fabrication et de l'exploitation foresti√®re au Canada. Elle est destin√©e √† couvrir tous les √©tablissements dont l'activit√© principale est la fabrication ou l'exploitation foresti√®re ainsi que certains bureaux de vente et entrep√¥ts se rattachant √† ces √©tablissements.

Les donn√©es recueillies par l'EAMEF sont importantes, car elles aident √† mesurer la production des secteurs de la fabrication et des ressources primaires au Canada, en plus de fournir un indice sur la vitalit√© de chaque industrie faisant l'objet de l'enqu√™te et de sa contribution √† l'√©conomie canadienne. Au sein de Statistique Canada, les donn√©es sont utilis√©es par le Syst√®me de comptabilit√© nationale du Canada, l'Enqu√™te mensuelle sur les industries manufacturi√®res (num√©ro d'enregistrement 2101) et les programmes de la Division des prix. Les donn√©es sont √©galement utilis√©es par le monde des affaires, les associations commerciales, les minist√®res f√©d√©raux et provinciaux, ainsi que les organisations et associations internationales dans le but de tracer un profil des secteurs de la fabrication et de l'exploitation foresti√®re, d'entreprendre des √©tudes de march√©, de pr√©voir la demande et de mettre sur pied des politiques en mati√®re de droit tarifaire et de commerce.

Title: Children with Incarcerated Parents

Summary: The main objective of the CHIRP (Children with Incarcerated Parents) Study is to identify children who experience parental incarceration, using data from the Canadian Correctional Services Survey (CCSS) 2015-2022, the Canadian Vital Statistics database 1997-2022 and the Discharge Abstract Database 1997-2022. Through this data linkage, an estimate of the actual number of children experiencing parental incarceration can be determined, as well as he health status and outcomes of this population relative to general population. This project will address data gaps regarding the lack of population-level data on the number of children who experience parental incarceration. The findings of this project could be used to increase the visibility of this population in national and provincial policies, and ultimately to inform the design and delivery of initiatives to better support children who experience parental incarceration.

Title: Consumer Price Index
Dataset Title (French): Indice des prix √† la consommation
Summary:
The Consumer Price Index (CPI) represents changes in prices as experienced by Canadian consumers. It measures price change by comparing, through time, the cost of a fixed basket of goods and services. Since the basket contains goods and services of unchanging or equivalent quantity and quality, the index reflects only pure price change.

The CPI is widely used as an indicator of the change in the general level of consumer prices or the rate of inflation. Since the purchasing power of money is affected by changes in prices, the CPI is useful to all Canadians. Consumers can compare movements in the CPI to changes in their personal income to monitor and evaluate changes in their financial situation.
Summary French:
L'Indice des prix √† la consommation (IPC) repr√©sente les changements de prix que subissent les consommateurs canadiens. Il mesure la variation des prix en comparant, au fil du temps, le co√ªt d'un panier fixe de biens et de services. Puisque le panier comprend des biens et services d'une quantit√© et d'une qualit√© constante ou √©quivalente, l'indice refl√®te uniquement la fluctuation pure des prix.

L'IPC est couramment utilis√© comme indicateur de la variation du niveau g√©n√©ral des prix √† la consommation ou du taux d'inflation. Comme la variation des prix a un effet sur le pouvoir d'achat du dollar, l'IPC est utile pour tous les Canadiens. Les consommateurs peuvent comparer la fluctuation de l'IPC √† la variation de leur revenu personnel et ainsi suivre et √©valuer l'√©volution de leur situation financi√®re.

Title: Industrial Product Price Index
Dataset Title (French): Indice des prix des produits industriels
Summary: The Industrial Product Price Index (IPPI) measures price changes for major commodities sold by manufacturers operating in Canada. The prices collected are for goods sold at the factory gate. As a result, the prices covered by the IPPI refer not to what a purchaser pays, but to what the producer receives. They exclude all indirect taxes, such as sales taxes and tariffs as this money does not go to the factors of production (i.e. labour, capital, or profit). They also exclude any transportation service performed by a common carrier beyond the factory gate and any distribution services performed by the retail or wholesale trade industries.
Summary French: L'Indice des prix des produits industriels (IPPI) mesure la variation des prix des principaux produits vendus par les fabricants op√©rant au Canada. Les prix recueillis sont ceux des marchandises vendues √† la sortie de l'usine. Par cons√©quent, les prix vis√©s par l'IPPI repr√©sentent non pas ce que l'acheteur paie, mais ce que le producteur re√ßoit. Ils excluent toutes les taxes indirectes, comme les taxes de vente et les tarifs douaniers, qui n'entrent pas dans les facteurs de production (main d'oeuvre, capital, b√©n√©fice). Ils excluent √©galement les co√ªts de tout service de transport rendu par un transporteur public au-del√† de l'usine et de tout service de distribution assur√© par les entreprises des secteurs du commerce de gros ou de d√©tail.
Subjects: Prices and price indexes>Producer price indexes
Content: The Industrial Product Price Index (IPPI) measures price changes for major commodities sold by manufacturers operating in Canada. The prices collected are for goods sold at the factory gate. As a result, the prices covered by the IPPI refer not to what a purchaser pays, but to what the producer receives. They exclude all indirect taxes, such as sales taxes and tariffs as this money does not go to the factors of production (i.e. labour, capital, or profit). They also exclude any transportation service performed by a common carrier beyond the factory gate and any distribution services performed by the retail or wholesale trade industries.

Title: Criminal Justice Relational Database
Dataset Title (French): Base de donn√©es relationnelle sur la justice p√©nale
Summary:
The¬†Criminal Justice Relational Database (CJRD)¬†was created to allow multivariate analyses on the demographic and socioeconomic factors associated with (repeated) criminal justice system involvement in Canada. It consists of anonymized, integrated criminal justice data, as well as other integrated social data sources (e.g., economic, health, and education data).

Concordance files:
  • IDAD, NACRS, OMHRS - 2020/2022
  • PSIS, RAIS - 2020/2021
  • Census - 2006, 2016, NHS ‚Äì 2011
  • T1FF 2021
  • Canadian Vital Statistics Deaths (CVSD) Database


The CJRD consists of three types of files: Core Datasets, Supplementary Datasets, and Concordance Key Files.

Core Datasets constitute the base of the CJRD. They are longitudinal, administrative criminal justice system surveys and are updated annually. Core Datasets currently include the Integrated Criminal Court Survey (ICCS) from 2005/2006 to 2020/2021 and the Canadian Correctional Services Survey (CCSS) from 2015/2016 to 2021/2022. The ICCS includes information on appearances, charges, and cases in youth courts and adult criminal courts from all provinces and territories across Canada. The CCSS collects data from correctional services across Canada, including characteristics of persons being supervised and their legal hold statuses. The CCSS Core Dataset includes data on adult correctional records from five provincial correctional programs: Nova Scotia, Ontario, Saskatchewan, Alberta, and British Columbia.

Supplementary Datasets are special extracts from non-criminal justice datasets that are not already available in the RDCs in their full form. They contain only records that linked to one of the Core Datasets and may be updated annually or less frequently. Supplementary Datasets include special extracts from the T1 Family file (T1FF) from 2002 to 2021, the National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NACRS) from 2005/2006 to 2020/2021, the Discharge Abstract Database (DAD) from 2005/2006 to 2020/2021, the Ontario Mental Health Reporting System (OMHRS) from 2006/2007 to 2020/2021, and the Longitudinal Immigration Database (IMDB) from 1980 to 2022. The T1FF Supplementary Dataset includes select variables on income, employment, and family composition. The NACRS, DAD, and OMHRS Supplementary Datasets include all releasable variables collected by those administrative surveys, including information on the use of medical emergency rooms and ambulatory services, discharges from acute inpatient institutions, and visits to select psychiatric institutions. The IMDB Supplementary Dataset includes only the landing date and the first permit effective date for permanent and non-permanent residents, respectively.

Concordance Key Files allow the Core Datasets to be integrated with non-criminal justice datasets that are already published in the RDCs in their full form. Each Concordance Key File contains only the record identifiers required to merge one of the Core Datasets with one additional target dataset. Concordance Key Files are provided to allow the Core Datasets to be integrated with the Canadian Vital Statistics -Deaths (2005 to 2020), the Postsecondary Student Information System (2008/2009 to 2020/2021), the Registered Apprenticeship Information System (2008 to 2021), the 2006 Census of Population Long-Form, the 2011 National Household Survey, and the 2016 Census of Population Long-Form.
Summary French:
La¬†Base de donn√©es relationnelle sur la justice p√©nale (BDRJP)¬†a √©t√© cr√©√©e pour permettre des analyses multivari√©es des facteurs d√©mographiques et socio√©conomiques associ√©s aux interactions (r√©p√©t√©es) avec le syst√®me de justice p√©nale au Canada. Elle contient des donn√©es sur la justice p√©nale anonymis√©es et int√©gr√©es, ainsi que d‚Äôautres sources de donn√©es sociales int√©gr√©es (p.¬†ex. donn√©es sur l‚Äô√©conomie, la sant√© et l‚Äô√©ducation). La BDRJP a produit de nouveaux fichiers de concordance :

Fichiers de concordance:
  • BDCP, SNISA, SIOSM - 2020/2022
  • SIEP, SIAI - 2020/2021
  • Recensement - 2006, 2016, ENM ‚Äì 2011
  • FFT1 2021
  • Base canadienne de donn√©es de l‚Äô√©tat civil ‚Äì D√©c√®s (BCDECD)


La BDRJP se compose de trois types de fichiers : ensembles de donn√©es de base, ensembles de donn√©es suppl√©mentaires et fichiers de cl√© de concordance.

Les ensembles de donn√©es de base constituent la fondation de la BDRJP. Ils sont compos√©s d‚Äôenqu√™tes longitudinales sur le syst√®me de justice p√©nale administrative et sont mis √† jour annuellement. Les ensembles de donn√©es de base comprennent actuellement l‚ÄôEnqu√™te int√©gr√©e sur les tribunaux de juridiction criminelle (EITJC) de 2005-2006 √† 2020-2021 et l‚ÄôEnqu√™te sur les services correctionnels canadiens (ESCC) de 2015-2016 √† 2021-2022. L‚ÄôEITJC comprend des renseignements sur les comparutions, les accusations et les causes port√©es devant les tribunaux de la jeunesse et les tribunaux de juridiction criminelle pour adultes dans toutes les provinces et tous les territoires du Canada. L‚ÄôESCC recueille des renseignements aupr√®s des services correctionnels au Canada, y compris les caract√©ristiques des personnes plac√©es sous surveillance et leur statut judiciaire. L‚Äôensemble de donn√©es de base de l‚ÄôESCC comprend des donn√©es sur les enregistrements des cinq services correctionnels pour adultes : la Nouvelle-√âcosse, l‚ÄôOntario, la Saskatchewan, l‚ÄôAlberta, et la Colombie-Britannique.

Les ensembles de donn√©es suppl√©mentaires sont des extraits sp√©ciaux des ensembles de donn√©es non judiciaires qui ne sont pas encore accessibles dans les CDR dans leur forme compl√®te. Ils ne contiennent que les enregistrements coupl√©s √† l‚Äôun des ensembles de donn√©es de base et peuvent √™tre mis √† jour annuellement ou moins fr√©quemment. Les ensembles de donn√©es suppl√©mentaires comprennent des extraits sp√©ciaux du Fichier des familles T1 (T1FF) de 2002 √† 2021, le Syst√®me national d‚Äôinformation sur les soins ambulatoires (SNISA) de 2005-2006 √† 2020-2021, la Base de donn√©es sur les cong√©s des patients (BDCP) de 2005-2006 √† 2020-2021, le Syst√®me d‚Äôinformation ontarien sur la sant√© mentale (SIOSM) de 2006-2007 √† 2020-2021, et la Base de donn√©es longitudinales sur les immigrants (BDIM) de 1980 √† 2022. L‚Äôensemble de donn√©es suppl√©mentaires T1FF comprend des variables s√©lectionn√©es sur le revenu, l'emploi et la composition de la famille. Les ensembles de donn√©es suppl√©mentaires SNISA, BDCP, et SIOSM comprennent toutes les variables publiables collect√©es dans le cadre de ces enqu√™tes administratives, y compris des renseignements sur l‚Äôutilisation des salles d‚Äôurgence m√©dicales et des services ambulatoires, les d√©charges des √©tablissements de soins intensifs en √©tablissement, et les visites dans certains √©tablissements psychiatriques. L‚Äôensemble de donn√©es suppl√©mentaires BDIM contient uniquement les dates d‚Äôentr√©e en vigueur de l‚Äôarriv√©e et du premier permis pour les r√©sidents permanents et non permanents, respectivement.

Les fichiers cl√©s de concordance permettent d‚Äôint√©grer les ensembles de donn√©es de base aux ensembles de donn√©es non judiciaires qui sont d√©j√† publi√©s dans les CDR sous leur forme compl√®te. Chaque fichier cl√© de concordance contient uniquement les identificateurs des enregistrements requis pour fusionner un des ensembles de donn√©es de base avec un autre ensemble de donn√©es cible. Des fichiers cl√©s de concordance sont fournis pour permettre l'int√©gration des ensembles de donn√©es de base avec la Base canadienne de donn√©es de l‚Äô√©tat civil ‚Äì D√©c√®s (2005 √† 2020), les Donn√©es du Syst√®me d‚Äôinformation sur les √©tudiants postsecondaires (2008-2009 √† 2020-2021), le Syst√®me d‚Äôinformation sur les apprentis inscrits (2008 √† 2021), le Questionnaire d√©taill√© du Recensement de la population de 2006, l‚ÄôEnqu√™te nationale aupr√®s des m√©nages de 2011, et le Questionnaire d√©taill√© du Recensement de la population de 2016.
Subjects: Crime and justice>Correctional services|Crime and justice>Courts
Content:
The¬†Criminal Justice Relational Database (CJRD)¬†was created to allow multivariate analyses on the demographic and socioeconomic factors associated with (repeated) criminal justice system involvement in Canada. It consists of anonymized, integrated criminal justice data, as well as other integrated social data sources (e.g., economic, health, and education data). Concordance files[1]:

¬∑       CJRD linked to hospitalization data

ICCS ‚Äì 2020/2021 and CCSS 2021/2022 ‚Äì DAD, NACRS, OMHRS - 2020/2022
¬∑       CJRD linked to education data

ICCS ‚Äì 2020/2021 and CCSS 2021/2022 ‚Äì PSIS, RAIS - 2020/2021
¬∑       CJRD linked to Census data

ICCS ‚Äì 2020/2021 and CCSS 2021/2022  - Census - 2006, 2016, NHS ‚Äì 2011
CJRD linked to tax data
ICCS ‚Äì 2020/2021 and CCSS 2021/2022  - T1FF 2021
 Canadian Vital Statistics Deaths (CVSD) Database

The CJRD consists of three types of files: Core Datasets, Supplementary Datasets, and Concordance Key Files.

 

Core Datasets constitute the base of the CJRD. They are longitudinal, administrative criminal justice system surveys and are updated annually. Core Datasets currently include the Integrated Criminal Court Survey (ICCS) from 2005/2006 to 2020/2021 and the Canadian Correctional Services Survey (CCSS) from 2015/2016 to 2021/2022. The ICCS includes information on appearances, charges, and cases in youth courts and adult criminal courts from all provinces and territories across Canada. The CCSS collects data from correctional services across Canada, including characteristics of persons being supervised and their legal hold statuses. The CCSS Core Dataset includes data on adult correctional records from five provincial correctional programs: Nova Scotia, Ontario, Saskatchewan, Alberta, and British Columbia.
 

Supplementary Datasets are special extracts from non-criminal justice datasets that are not already available in the RDCs in their full form. They contain only records that linked to one of the Core Datasets and may be updated annually or less frequently. Supplementary Datasets include special extracts from the T1 Family file (T1FF) from 2002 to 2021, the National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NACRS) from 2005/2006 to 2020/2021, the Discharge Abstract Database (DAD) from 2005/2006 to 2020/2021, the Ontario Mental Health Reporting System (OMHRS) from 2006/2007 to 2020/2021, and the Longitudinal Immigration Database (IMDB) from 1980 to 2022. The T1FF Supplementary Dataset includes select variables on income, employment, and family composition. The NACRS, DAD, and OMHRS Supplementary Datasets include all releasable variables collected by those administrative surveys, including information on the use of medical emergency rooms and ambulatory services, discharges from acute inpatient institutions, and visits to select psychiatric institutions. The IMDB Supplementary Dataset includes only the landing date and the first permit effective date for permanent and non-permanent residents, respectively.
 

Concordance Key Files allow the Core Datasets to be integrated with non-criminal justice datasets that are already published in the RDCs in their full form. Each Concordance Key File contains only the record identifiers required to merge one of the Core Datasets with one additional target dataset. Concordance Key Files are provided to allow the Core Datasets to be integrated with the Canadian Vital Statistics -Deaths (2005 to 2020), the Postsecondary Student Information System (2008/2009 to 2020/2021), the Registered Apprenticeship Information System (2008 to 2021), the 2006 Census of Population Long-Form, the 2011 National Household Survey, and the 2016 Census of Population Long-Form.

Title: Canadian Income Survey - T1 Family File
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te canadienne sur le revenu - Fichier des familles T1
Summary:
A linkage between the Canadian Income Survey (CIS) and selected variables from the T1 Family File (T1FF) was performed. The current release is the result of a collaboration between the Center for Income and Socio-economic Well-being Statistics and the University of Toronto‚Äôs PROOF research program. A deterministic linkage between the CIS and selected variables from the T1FF has been performed in two parts.

Part 1 linkage uses a single year of data from the CIS and the T1FF. The linkage structure is as follows:
CIS 2018 linked to T1FF 2019
CIS 2019 linked to T1FF 2020
CIS 2020 linked to T1FF 2021
CIS 2021 linked to T1FF 2022

Part 2 is a five-year retrospective linkage, which has CIS 2018 to 2022 linked to T1FF for five previous years:
CIS 2018 linked to T1FF 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016, 2017
CIS 2019 linked to T1FF 2014, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018
CIS 2020 linked to T1FF 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019
CIS 2021 linked to T1FF 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020
CIS 2022 linked to T1FF 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021

The analytical files available include selected variables from the T1FF and an anonymized key to join to the CIS. The following information is available from each respective source of data:
Canadian Income Survey provides information on the income and income sources of Canadians, along with their individual and household characteristics.
T1 Family File provides information on sources of income (from the tax filers) and some demographic indicators (derived from both the tax filers and the non-filers); variables are derived primarily from income tax returns.
Summary French:
Un couplage entre l'Enqu√™te canadienne sur le revenu (ECR) et des variables s√©lectionn√©es du Fichier des familles T1 (FFT1) a √©t√© effectu√©. Cette diffusion r√©sulte d'une collaboration entre le Centre de la statistique du revenu et du bien-√™tre socio√©conomique et le programme de recherche PROOF de l'Universit√© de Toronto. Un couplage d√©terministe entre l'ECR et des variables s√©lectionn√©es du FFT1 a √©t√© effectu√© en deux parties.

Le couplage de la partie 1 utilise une seule ann√©e de donn√©es de l'ECR et du FFT1. La structure du couplage est la suivante :
ECR 2018 coupl√©e au FFT1 2019
ECR 2019 coupl√©e au FFT1 2020
ECR 2020 coupl√©e au FFT1 2021
ECR 2021 coupl√©e au FFT1 2022

La partie 2 est un couplage r√©trospectif sur cinq ans, qui lie l'ECR de 2018 √† 2022 au FFT1 pour les cinq ann√©es pr√©c√©dentes :
ECR 2018 coupl√©e aux FFT1 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016, 2017
ECR 2019 coupl√©e aux FFT1 2014, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018
ECR 2020 coupl√©e aux FFT1 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019
ECR 2021 coupl√©e aux FFT1 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020
ECR 2022 coupl√©e aux FFT1 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021

Les fichiers analytiques disponibles incluent des variables s√©lectionn√©es du FFT1 et une cl√© anonymis√©e pour les joindre √† l'ECR. Les informations suivantes sont disponibles dans chacune des sources de donn√©es:
L'Enqu√™te canadienne sur le revenu fournit de l‚Äôinformations sur le revenu et les sources de revenus des Canadiens, ainsi que sur leurs caract√©ristiques individuelles et celles de leurs m√©nages.
Fichier des familles T1 fournit des informations sur les sources de revenus (des d√©clarants fiscaux) et sur certains indicateurs d√©mographiques (provenant √† la fois des d√©clarants fiscaux et des non-d√©clarants). Ces variables sont principalement issues des d√©clarations de revenus.

Title: Canadian Health Survey on Children and Youth - Discharge Abstract Database - National Ambulatory Care Reporting System
Dataset Title (French): Enqu√™te canadienne sur la sant√© des enfants et des jeunes - Base de donn√©es sur les cong√©s des patients - Syst√®me national d‚Äôinformation sur les soins ambulatoires
Summary: The purpose of this data integration project is to enhance the analytical and research value of the Canadian Health Survey on Children and Youth (CHSCY) files by including information from the Discharge Abstract Database (DAD) and the National Ambulatory Care Reporting System (NACRS). Researchers will use the linked dataset to explore issues that have an impact on the health of children and youth and conduct a variety of analyses using acute and ambulatory care data.

Title: Labour Market and Socio-economic Indicators
Dataset Title (French): Indicateurs socio-√©conomiques et du march√© du travail
Summary: The Labour Market and Socio-economic Indicators program consists of supplements to the Labour Force Survey (LFS) that produce quarterly estimates for the third and the fourth quarters on topics related to forms of employment and quality of employment. Data from Q3 2022, Q4 2022, Q3 2023 and Q4 2023 are now available. In 2022 and 2023, the LMSI surveys covered topics such as additional indicators of job permanence, preference for a permanent job, the stability and permanence of self-employment arrangements and gig work.

Les donn√©es du troisi√®me trimestre 2022, du quatri√®me trimestre 2022, du troisi√®me trimestre 2023 et du quatri√®me trimestre 2023 sont d√©sormais disponibles. En 2022 et 2023, les enqu√™tes ISMT ont couvert des sujets tels que des indicateurs suppl√©mentaires sur la permanence de l'emploi, la pr√©f√©rence pour un emploi permanent, la stabilit√© et la permanence des arrangements des travailleurs autonomes et le travail √† la demande.
